author: ALMSIVI
review: 6/10. Not worth full $60 asking price, but if you can get it for $25 or below I think it's a fair deal.   I have yet to finish the game. I am about 20 hours in.  Fantastic visuals for the most part. This looks like a true next-gen game. The high production value really shines throughout the open world. Hogwarts itself looks AMAZING, one of the best interiors I've ever seen in a game, with beautiful lighting and perfect amounts of clutter and complexity. Combat is much better than most games in this style and there's a good repertoire of spells to draw from. Juggling enemies, making them fly away with depulso, flipping them around and slamming them to the ground - it feels GREAT. It easily s**ts on the combat of games like Witcher 3 or a typical Ubisoft open world game. The way the game uses vibration and how it ties into combat is likewise brilliant, doing something as simple as the basic spell cast by hitting the RT button gives you a snappy sound and visual feedback and just the right amount of vibration to make casting a spell feel good.  This all comes together to make a VERY satisfying combat experience. I really liked the fact the game goes through seasons which changes the look and feel of Hogwarts and the rest of the world. Winter at Hogsmeade gives off a fantastic atmosphere! Speaking of Hogsmeade, you can tell the developers put a lot of effort into it, similar to the effort they put into Hogwarts school. Walking around and listening to conversations that normal adult wizards are having about the state of the wizarding world, seeing students get tricked into eating a deceptively-named candy that makes steam shoot out of their nose and mouth, coming across a group of concerned wizards protesting about the goblin uprisings - they really nailed the atmosphere and believability here. The brief segments when you're in class are very cool, feels like classic HP vibes when Harry was attending class and learning spells in the first few books/movies, wish they happened more often though. Broom flying is visually stunning and controls are good; some of the best visuals I've EVER seen in a game have come from flying around the world during sunset or sunrise and witnessing the auburn glow of the sun bend and smother the verdant landscapes... it's seriously GORGEOUS! however, I was wishing for a bit more character-world reactivity when it came to flying, like having your character get knocked off his/her broom when bumping into an obstacle at high speeds, or having your character cover their face when you're flying through the branches of a treeThere are some decent side stories and characters, my favorites were the mentor/professor and Sebastian. For the most part the other professors and students are endearing as well. I was a little iffy at first on the stark racial and cultural diversity in this game, with tons of African, Middle Eastern and East-Asian people milling about Hogwarts and the surrounding land, which is strange considering the game takes place in early 20th-century England. However I got to a point eventually when I stopped caring and I ended up liking most of the non-white characters.  It's a modern AAA western game with a lot of influence from Ubisoft and EA. Because of this you get obnoxious and unfun mechanics like an unbearably ♥♥♥♥ looting/gear system with common-uncommon-rare-legendary gradings. This is a real shame because you can see some soul and "magic" in Hogwarts Legacy but it's often ruined by how generic the systems are. They even threw in the korok puzzles from BotW, which means if you want to have an inventory that isn't extremely annoying to manage you're forced to fly around and look for these trials. They fumbled the "immersive school experience" that they were trying to cultivate at the start of the game. I am about 20 or so hours in and I've only been to my common room 3 or 4 times total. There's no schedule you have to follow, you don't get reprimanded for being out of bed at night, you're allowed to come and go from campus and pick fights with random dark wizards you find in the woods, professors barely react if you cast an unforgivable curse right in front of their eyes. I was really hoping for something akin to Persona 5's handling of school, with perhaps a bit more freedom. But instead it's like you're barely even a student, just a young adventurer that likes to stop by Hogwarts occasionally. I wouldn't say the optimization is really bad, but it's not as good as it could be. I'm getting around 55-60 FPS at 4k DLSS quality and high preset with raytracing off on my laptop 3070ti. The collect-a-thon aspect is painfully boring. They have a small handful of very simple puzzles that they throw around Hogwarts and Hogsmeade and they repeat these braindead puzzles ad nauseam. I understand this is a game that takes place in the Wizarding world, collectibles have always been present in the Harry Potter games but they could've really done a better job at offering us more unique puzzles. The music is forgettable, which is a shame because the HP movie soundtrack is legendary. There doesn't seem to be a whole lot of choices to make or a very in-depth alignment system, you can either choose to be a Harry Potter-like good guy, or a sarcastic prick... and that's about it. I sympathize with the devs on this one point although it's still a criticism of mine: there are too many spells to neatly fit into the active spells list, at least on my xbox gamepad, which means you can only have 16 active spells at a time. I get that controllers are limited by the amount of buttons they have, but they still made some really boneheaded decisions: like why the hell does the animal brush and animal food take up an active spell slot? Did they really have to make the spells that are only used in the room of requirement take up active spell slots? It ruins the momentum of exploration and combat when I'm having to constantly go in to the spell menu to replace spells in my active slots. Outside of Hogwarts and Hogsmeade, the world is barren and boring. There are some small hamlets here and there that have very little to nothing going on, very reminiscent of the small villages you could find in Witcher 3. The NPCs in general are not very immersive or reactive to the kind of decisions you make. Some of them I believe have very basic schedules, i.e. during certain times in the day you can find them doing different things, at night they'll go to sleep. However there's no repercussion to casting spells on them, they don't say or do anything if you walk into their house and take stuff from them either. I mentioned in the pros section that I thought the atmosphere and believability of places like Hogsmeade were fantastic, and they are: but it's really frustrating that I can't interact with any of the villagers! Speaking of interactivity: I REALLY wished they fleshed out the amount of things in the environment that you can cast spells on! Casting depulso on a barrel and watching it hurtle into a wall and splinter into a thousand pieces is so satisfying, let us do that with all the other crap that's laying around!  This isn't a bad game by any means, but it is very generic. If you're a big HP fan perhaps it's worth full price but for the average gamer I would recommend waiting for some steep discounts before purchasing this.

author: Celia ฅ^•ﻌ•^ฅ
review: I understand this is a controversial game for different reasons, so for the purpose of leaving a helpful review, I'm going to only be talking about in-game aspects:-To be honest, I love it. I'm probably a bit biased from nostalgia, but the castle is beautiful and the surrounding world is interesting as well. --While there ARE certain things you can interact with in the overworld, I do wish that you could interact with more. Right now it's mostly just spectacle (which is valid and fun to look at, don't get me wrong), with intermittent little things like a globe you can spin or a cat you can levitate. **You CANNOT use magic on most things in the game.**-I enjoy the characters quite a bit, but I will admit that the facial animation can range from very good to very uncanny at times. That's neither here nor there in my opinion. It's not perfect, but it isn't heinous. -You can't get any sort of mount until pretty late game, and because of this I do wish the player walking and "running" speed wasn't so slow for the size of the world. You can get around alright, and thankfully the game's fast travel mechanic "floo flames" are there to help, but it can still get a bit tedious since the world is probably a lot bigger than you're thinking it is before you play the game. --Regarding the floo flames: this is a very minor gripe but there's a talking bust at EVERY flame station that has a loud, stupid one liner of some sort every time she sees you, whether in passing or teleporting. I just don't like her, lmao.-THE COMBAT SYSTEM!! I actually really, really enjoy it. It was MUCH faster paced than I thought it would or could be, so props for that. That said, you can die very quickly. Not a complaint, just a warning. -I wish there were more available spells. I'm a little over 10 hours in and at level 13 at the time of writing this, so there is A LOT more of the game left for me to experience and potentially complain about or praise, but for now, I'd give it a solid 8.5/10.***EDIT AND UPDATE!!!***I am now nearly level 19. and the Room of Requirement along with the ability to fly via broom have added at least a half point to my score, putting us at a 9/10. However! this game does not deserve a 9/10. Love it though I do, I would recommend this game to pretty much anyone and just as easily say no, it is definitely not going to be like the best or most well-done game you've ever played. Those games get 9s out of 10s. In any case, I have pretty much the same gripes as before, AND-I wish gear sold for more, and I wish ♥♥♥♥ wasn't so expensive compared to the amount of gear you can even get to sell and then how little it gets you. Curse you, Sky Scythe broom...--Seriously, gear from chests only, and the rarest garbs sell for sub 500 galleons and ONE HEALING POTION IS 100 galleons. To clarify, yes, I know you can make wiggenweld potions yourself, but what I'm trying to say is the cost margin between how much money you can get vs. how much you need is pretty annoying.---Especially!!! since as far as I know by level 19, there is NOTHING else you can sell, and there is no other way to get things you CAN sell aside from finding them in chests out in the world. Then when you do get something you can sell, it goes for like 60-90 galleons. Oh? What's that? The EXACT same robe you just sold is in a shop? selling for like 300 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ galleons? Awesome. -I wont lie, although I am loving this game, the quests are starting to seem a *bit repetitive*. You're not necessarily doing the same stuff over and over again (most of the time ...), but the majority of missions and quests them don't have much life to them. -The graphics are *okay*--Actually, scratch that, they're NOT okay. Sometimes? They're laughably bad. Nothing that effects gameplay, but I'm not going to lower my standards for this game. If anything, I'm expecting more. Let's just say I have better minecraft shaders. So, unless you have a pc that can run the game at high settings, you're gonna be wanting for more in terms of graphics quality. And the faces... most of them look like flesh robots, full disclosure. Again, it's NOT BAD, but it's not good either. --For such a huge franchise, the graphics alone deduct at least a point for me. This ♥♥♥♥ should be blowing my mind, but instead I'm looking at an uncanny robot that gained sentience when I talk to characters. A lot of the movement and the way characters interact with the world and the player's character is one big skyrim npc meme, but like over a decade late. And most npcs will not respond to you at all. ---It is very heart-warming and cool to be able to go around and explore environments I dreamed about as a kid. For the sake of just playing through the game and enjoying the map, the graphics aren't blasphemy. Like, it is only rarely that I see something so bad it messes with my focus. Yet, it is only slightly more common that I see something so GOOD I stop and say wow, this is awesome. If you can't run this game at high graphics settings, your wizarding world will still be lovable, but very silly looking at times.-Unfortunate update about the stupid one liners though: ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ the elf in the Room of Requirement. I am going to go completely feral if I hear "DEEK THINKS YOU SHOULD BE PROUD OF ALL THE POTIONS YOUVE MADE" one more time.--So, I've not just got floo flames lady saying the same 3 lines whenever she sees me. I've got like 5 other characters. If I get any more saying the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ every 10 idle seconds, I'm going to fast track the skill tree to Avada Kedavra and make my own light show out of them.--Most of the npc conversations you can overhear are quite nice though. I speak harshly because I have high standards. I want to strangle Deek the house elf. Spend 30 min in the room of requirement and you too will wish to commit murder. -On a positive note, I just went to beasts class and met a hippogriff. I hope she will be my best friend forever. -Lastly (for now) the voice actor for the groundskeeper? Amazing. Gladwin Moon is easily the most enjoyable voice in the game so far. tl:dr Many hours later, and I still love it. It has decreased in score to probably around 7.5-8/10. Not because it got worse or I like it any less, but because of some issues that I'm not really willing to let slide for a title like this. Cheers, -C

author: Astral_Haze
review: I want to preface something really quick... I DO NOT agree with JKR or her ideology. But PURELY, SOLELY, AND EXCLUSIVELY from a VIDEO GAME standpoint, this is probably one of the best I've played in a while! I loved the fantasy world of HP ever since I was a kid and this game exemplifies that feeling to a T! Highly recommend! Please support the developers at Avalanche for their AMAZING work. They even clearly stated that the development of the game was as far removed from JKR as humanly possible! Regardless whether you get this game or not, though, I highly recommend donating to a charity that supports trans rights. I personally donated to Trans Lifeline and I feel much better now that whatever she would've gotten from me for this game is now offset 2:1.

author: Liner
review: it's not an open world - just flying around in areas for a long time to find and collect some things that don't really relate to the story - you always find the same caves with always the same puzzles and then find a chest with an item that you sell anyway. You open thousands of chests you find money or items that you sell to get money again and you can't do anything with the money, pointless system. You break into houses where people are inside and rob them without consequences. No Quidditch in a Harry Potter based game, even though it's set years before, developers were apparently too lazy to apply that. You're not a fifth grader, you're a child prodigy who can come to class whenever you want for short private lessons to learn a spell in seconds. The side quests are lame, unemotional and uninteresting. You get your owl mail like an answering machine. The game is also way too easy, you have your own room to grow crops and then brew potions that you never use because you are already too strong. You're in a room of 10 enemies, each specific enemy only ever makes one programmed attack, always the same attack, wow! You cast more than 15 spells alone. I don't need to start with the story, totally boring, cheap, the character you play has zero story. Thank goodness I can play a male character with a female voice, Genderly 10/10 we need that so much in our time!*Facepalm*The only good things about this game are the graphics, the music, the magic animations and effects and the fact that they recreated the school almost exactly like in the movie.Absolutely no replay value.3/10

author: Anarchy31173
review: its a No ....!i want it to be a yes BUT, the game has some massive core issues with its design and mechanics, the 6 most noticeable issues I've come across so far.PROGRESSION STOPPING BUGS- there's a bugs that stops you from getting to the highest level in my case the ASTRONOMY TABLE CHALLENGE is the bug that got me, to achieve level 40 you need 100% completion in all challenges and it stops you at 99%, with all that's wrong with the game i don't really feel like replaying the entire game and risk hitting this bug again so I'm completing the story and leaving it at level 39 and moving onto another game till all these things get fixed.BUGS- So far I've found very little bugs, but the few i have found are immersion braking AUDIO bugs, one were my Characters voice constantly sounds like they are a robot talking in a room with echos no matter what surrounding I'm in, and the other is a high pitch noise inside the room of requirement, REALLY annoying. AND also the for mentioned game breaking progression stopping bug. for a heavy story driven game where dialogue is constant, it may be a few small bugs, but very noticeable and needs fixing.FLIGHT- its bloody awful, so bad in fact, that Avalanche software didn't include Quidditch in the game since the flight controls are that complicated and that bad, who ever designed this should be banned from the game industry for life. they have no business in game design. its really THAT bad ! remember GTA5, yeah THAT BAD !PROGRESSION DESIGN- there's a point early on in the game before you unlock all the fast travel points where you run around doing a fair amount of exploring and side questing, and you pass a LOT of locked doors, but don't have the ability to unlock them till much later in the storey line, having to go back to areas to scout around and unlock doors in sections of, well everywhere you've already been, seems a bit counter productive, i think this spell should have been unlocked a LOT earlier in the storey progression. its a really bad over sight in the design.NO NG+- in this day and age, for a game to be created with different difficulties (EASY-HARD) without new game plus, i think is a BIG mistake. personally i like to start a game on the easy settings, enjoying the story and mastering the mechanics and when finished, use a NG+ option to re-play through on a harder setting, to progress to the hardest difficulty settings, so for a game to not include this is a bit of a downer for me.RESPEC- there is no way to respec your character and with limited talent points to spend its hard to explore spells, abilities and builds for how you want to play, once you've selected a talent there's no going back even if that particular talent doesn't work out for a build you might like to try, a massive over sight. this needs fixing soon.even though the game has some major peevs and a few over sights AND a few things that could have been added ( like a personal conjured training dummy for the room of requirement ) and Quidditch. until the game gets a few major fixes i CAN'T recommend buying this game at it current price, these things aside i still enjoyed the game, it has SOLID story with a balanced grind/reward ratio backed up with good graphics, it also includes puzzles that i thought the mechanics of a lot of them could have been explained in a class , since it is a school, but left to figure a lot of stuff out which feels a bit clunky, the combat is smooth and flowing with an engaging combo system. it also has some crafting (personal furniture and work benches) and a simple but good gear upgrade system. I hope to see this game grow into its potential. but firstly Avalanche Software and WB Games your your game needs a few fix's and your flight mechanic needs a mouse flight option or a complete re-design its just really REALLY that bad ! if i could make a suggestion, i think the mechanic you are looking for here is the flight mechanic from Marvel Avengers IornMan character, i think it would work really well here.

author: WhiteWolf
review: A vanilla RPG with basic options and a white-black morale system, no grey in the middle, and a story without any emotion except for maybe the first 5 to 10 minutes. These two points were the most disappointing. However, it is the best recreation of the Wizarding World in a video game yet, with a good variety of puzzles, though in some cases there are too many of the same puzzle. The game also offers a good level of customization and a great combat system (which was my biggest concern before playing it). The game was released with some bugs, but they were not game-breaking for me. In conclusion, it is a fun game to play. If you're a Wizarding World fan, this game is a must-have. Otherwise, it would be better to think a bit before buying it.

author: Nakryn
review: For anyone that love Harry Potter universe, with all it's quirks and lore, I think you'll love this game. it has been amazing so far (haven't finished it yet, and I'm far from finishing it), I loved literally every aspect of it. I don't mind much about slow rendering or graphical bugs (the last never happened to me yet), but whenever a slow rendering happened, it didn't bothered me and was not game breaking. This story has been interesting so far. Not saying it's incredible or something, but they went towards something interesting that I wasn't expecting and they are doing a good job keeping it entertaining. I love the whole open world concept, the crafting system as well, even though it's rather simple. The battle system is rather nice too, even the stealth parts of it. Idk, it is a really cozy game, and I deeply love it. I hope y'all feel the same <3

author: Trevor Fox
review: Sitting at 72 hours in this game--it has been fantastic. When I started, I was blown away by how much is in the game. I said it was my favorite open-world game next to Breath of the Wild (which still holds the torch). Does that still ring true? Yes, but with some caveats. There are some performance issues with this game, but I will be covering the gameplay aspect of the game here.So, how does it fare? Well, I was really worried at first because the story opens up with your character giving you the answer to every single puzzle without allowing you a moment to think for yourself. Then we're shown pointless dialogue trees, a disappointing sorting, and WAY too much HUD information. Every enemy has a healthbar and a level, and we have our health bar and magic meters, and look! Waypoint markers and a path marked on your mini-map! Objective markers hover obnoxiously over NPCs that you need to talk, too, and the worst offender of all, enemies scale with you throughout the game making upgrades effectively limited or worthless.So, this open-world is really just taking a page out of the more generic ones out there. Repeating tombs and secret areas that don't really unlock upgrades but just give you unidentified gear as a reward which might slightly up your stats. It's novel at first but wears thin when you realize that it's all the same and loses its appeal quite quickly.With all of this negative stuff in here, why am I giving it a positive review? Well, for a few reasons really! Because this game is actually REMARKABLY fun!First, this game is banking on the player being a Harry Potter fan. If you're in love with the wizarding world, then getting to run around Hogwarts and the environment is an absolute treat! I can't tell you how giddy it makes me to see the paintings moving, ghosts sword fighting and floating through the castle, Peeves up to his shenanigans, suits of armor moving out of the corner of your vision or interacting with each other. Oh my god, it is SUCH a treat. And the intricacy of Hogwarts itself is SO fun! It can be almost overwhelming at first, but things fit together in such an intricate and nice way, it feels like I really am exploring a magical castle with tons of secrets within its walls! Although I wish they could have made the Grand Staircase more faithful to the books and movies, everything else feels like its selected the best of both worlds. Certain aspects of the castle are more faithful to the movies while others pull a page or two from the books, and it's wonderful to seeSecond. Accessibility options. Normally, this is a source of contention for me because I usually see accessibility impede the vision of the creator and game rather than support it. But the options they have here (while there is room for improvement--where the hell is my one-stick broom control?) do give you a range of customization. And the first thing I did? I turned off the ENTIRE HUD. I kept things up long enough to learn how they work, but I was able to turn off:-The minimap-My healthbar-Enemy health bar/level-Wand SpellsI did that all while keeping the display for items that I pick up and EXP notifications. The problem I have with this game is the problem I have with other Action RPG games. They're not RPG games. They are on the surface level, but they're really more Action/Adventure games. RPGs have a very certain feel to them, and I'm not a fan of western RPGs with scaling enemies. It loses that sense of working hard to get stronger which is ESSENTIAL to an RPG experience. All of the combat has to lead to something and make you stronger. And enemies that scale with you take away from that experience.However, as an Action/Adventure title, this system is PERFECT. And you can achieve that feel by removing the levels and health from enemies. You'll get talents that unlock different effects for spells, learn more spells, get better combos, be able to mix and match combos as you want, and that sort of system works SO MUCH BETTER when you remove the arbitrary health values and levels that enemies have. It puts the focus on you, your wits, your spells, and your positioning rather than on whittling down a red bar until it disappears. I understand that this isn't for everyone, nor do these mechanics bother everyone, but scaling enemies is something I take issue with because of how repetitive it makes games feel, and I'm glad there was an option to turn these elements off.To go along with that, most games that give you those sort of options are unplayable without them. Sure, Witcher 3 might SAY that you can remove the minimap, but the core gameplay relies on it, so if you don't want to pull up your map every two seconds and ruin the flow, then you need to have it on. I would say that this game does a really good job at being the best of both worlds. You can disable these HUD elements, but still have the game be playable. Oh, don't have your mini-map and are lost? Not to worry! We have a pathfinder similar to Dead Space that you can activate and follow to your objective without too much clutter on the screen. It really is wonderful.Third. The combos. Oh my god, the combos. The game gives you a rundown very quickly of it's combat. Attack and shield. Attack and shield. Ohp. Super attack. But this is quickly added onto with spells that you learn in class. You start to learn various spells that you can put into your combos. Hit the enemy, levitate them, hit the enemy, pull them toward you, set them on fire, push them away, hit the enemy, thrown an object. Want to sneak up on that enemy? Do it. Wanna throw that guy off a cliff? Have fun! Oh, man. There's some guys below me but I don't really feel like fighting a lot of them. I'm pretty high up though. I'll just pull them to me and let them fall to their death. I have had SO much fun with the combat in this game. Elements of it remind me of Batman: Arkham Asylum. It's not exactly the same, but you have combos that you do while watching for dodge and counter symbols that flash around your character's head (rather than the enemy's). I willingly look for fights because of how much fun I have playing the game.Fourth. The stuff I wasn't expecting. The extra stuff can wear thin, but I was just expecting a game where I ran around a castle and shot some wizards now and then. The fact that I was provided more than that has been thrilling, and quite an enjoyable experience.And that's my review for the game. There's some faults with it, some things get old, and at the end of the day, the world and exploration is like a lot of other open-world games out there. But the gameplay, accessibility features, and the fact that I'm in the wizarding world have made the experience one that has put a smile on my face the whole way through.

author: NikolasFerreira
review: This is definetely one of the best games in the recent years.This is not only a game that harry potter fans would feel like they are part of the history, but for any RPG, Adventure genre fan.The game is super well detailed, well ambiented and excellent gameplay mechanics. Finally a AAA game that's actually worth it's price.

author: tarebear
review: All the backlash about JK Rowling is entirely pointless. She was not involved in the development of this game whatsoever and she earns money from the franchise as a whole anyway. If you have issues that big, then just shut your damn mouth and walk away from the fanbase. As for the game itself, it is absolutely amazing. The writing is brilliant, all the characters feel real (including your own very customisable character), and there is loads to do. There are about just over 30 hours of gameplay if you rush through the story, but there are hours more in the open world with varying quests with varying rewards as well as three main side quests that I would recommend completing before you finish the main story. Even after completing the story, you can still explore and complete many quests you may have missed. You can participate in battle arena challenges, wipe out bandit, troll, and spider dens, and delve into dungeons in search of whatever might be there. You can ride hippogriffs, grow plants, brew potions, practice spells, and grow your own vivarium of fantastic beasts.Easily one of the best games I have ever played and definitely worth the full price I paid for the deluxe edition pre-order.

author: Boggle
review: Can't give it a thumbs up until they fix the performance. Stuttering like crazy while in combat or just strutting around hogwarts. One second Im getting 144 fps and then WHAM, Im down to 20. Sometimes I can't lock onto enemies or the lock on indication just disappears. Once they can fix these issues this would be a fun game to play but right now I just frustrating. I would get a refund if I honestly could

author: Frituurkoning
review: This game and most of the aspects of it can be summarised as:Voice acting 8/10Amount of voice lines 2/10This game has many small details just perfectly right, but is just lacking in certain areas.:- Hogwarts is just the world setting, you're not actually doing anything student-like, attending classes are just one-off introduction cutscenes for the teachers who after that have no importance other than giving you some quests to learn spells.- A lot of side quests are "I need something from this place that is too dangerous for 5 adults, please go there by yourself 5th year student"- No morality system, me: "avada kedavra", teacher: "hmm, please don't do that", actual consequences: 0- There are 1 or 2 named students who are forgetable at best, but the others might as well have been nameless npc's- There's only 6 potions and none of them are real game changers- You get the room of requirement with a house-elf, this guy is always there, has 1 voice line, and he repeats that line every 15 seconds that your near him.- This game has some kinda puzzles/challenges called "Merlin Trials", there are 95 of these, however your character has 2 lines for when you find one, and 3 lines for when you complete at trial.- The same goes for other things as well, most noticeable: clothing and enemies. Everything has a lot of details, looks really great, however they then give you the exact same thing 10 times in a slightly different color, and they then list it all as separate entries in the collection menu, especially for clothing they are like "this one has 2 thin stripes on the sleeves instead of one so it's a complete new item". (This would have been fine if there were more options) :- Using the voice pitch slider in char creation: you are now a robot, (it's bad enough that it would have been better to have not included this slider)- Allowing us to build (blurry) mirrors in the room of requirements, but the room's walls being invisible in reflections- Random FPS drops, rtx 3080 dlss quality mode, ultra settings, average: 85 fps, walking through a simple hallway: 13 fps, walking the same hallway 2 days later: 70 fps (the game only actually crashed once after 38 hours of total playtime)- Consistent FPS drops: certain cutscenes give you a whole full 8 frames per second, no matter what you do.:- This is probably one of the best looking games I have ever played- Amazing world building <- this especially- Combat is fun (when you unlock more spells to do combinations with, too repetitive at start)- Exploration, there are many challenges and puzzles which is just great combined with how the world looks. There are many puzzles/challenges and collectibles, but I really wish these challenges would become more difficult than they are now.- Altho I want more items and better placing mechanics, the room of requirement is fun to furnish the way you want it with stuff that you buy, get as rewards, or find in chests.- Broom flying is fun- Has transmog feature, I enjoy the game enough to have put 40 hours into it, and will probably play it a lot more before I'm done with it anytime soon, but .And .Many RPG features are partially there, but just lacking in some way or form for what I expect for a 60 euro game.Suggestion for people already playing the game: turn off the minimap and enjoy the game's world.

author: K!netic
review: It's easily the best potterverse game ever made. But it strangely gets less enjoyable the more you play, thanks to the repeated content, boring dialogue/main quest, useless loot/rewards, and everything else you've come to expect from a modern AAA open world game. Worth playing, there's something for everyone, but it's got no depth.First off, the formula here for both combat and learning spells is excellent. Four sets of four-slot spellbars that you can customize as desired, with plenty of extra spells to experiment with. Learning spells is mostly a non-linear series of sidequests, completed by "attending class" or "seeing the prof after class" for a mercifully brief skippable montage before you do the usual gesture minigame to learn the spell. When there's something to interact with in the world, your intuition on which spells (often plural) to use is probably correct. It feels cohesive, and every spell has uses.But the game is also unfortunately very much a product of its time. I'm not just referring to the whole trans nonsense, though that does rear its head in some cringey ways in the game itself -- but mostly in that so much of what you're doing feels like . It's not so bad as an Ubisoft game, but once you realize that every kind of puzzle is both braindead simple and repeated at least 15 times, the magic wears off fast. The whole allure of this world is mystery and discovery, and when you just slap the answer to a puzzle you repeated over a dozen times in the game on a chalkboard somewhere, it's just not a mystery anymore.This setting is popular because of a sense of endless possibility, mystery, and discovery. The game could benefit from giving more (and more interesting) opportunities for self-directed exploration, mysteries that aren't explained to you through some student-you-dont-care-about giving you a gimmie so that you know how the rest of them work. It ought to give you interesting problems (not puzzles) that you have to use and combine spells to figure out. And the rewards could be more than just collection book pages and useless levelled gear.It's maybe not fair for me to criticize like this, because I just want a fundamentally different product than the target audience of AAA open world games. But all of this to say, if you wanted something like an "immersive sim" in the potterverse, this isn't really it. It's worth trying, it's a lot closer than anything else; but it's not it.

author: Para
review: I have not finished the game yet and think I'm still quite a ways off, mainly due to the amount of exploration there is to do in the game and just take your time with it all with no rush.As for story from what I've done so far I am really enjoying it and think its great, gameplay wise its quite smooth, combat feels really fun, the more spells u get the better it feels, with combos and synergies and all that jazz (I play on hard mode so probs/might allow for bigger combo-ing), targeting system can e a bit arsey sometimes but not that much of an issue IMHO.I have heard of FPS/crashing issues for some playe rers and do hope they get fixed soon, (I'm lucky though lmao).That is my take on the game so far, and hope it helps.

author: raixel
review: Its fun. Its minorly buggy. I managed to get myself massively OoB more than once, and have seen some minor graphical glitches. And it has Denuvo. If I had known I wouldnt have bought it. I was wondering why cutscenes ran like crap on High on my beast of a machine. Now I know. ♥♥♥♥ Denuvo. I'm not into Harry Potter at all, and know very little about it. I saw a couple of the movies like 20 years ago and I read one of the books. Comes off like very English "magical" whimsy. I got it because hey, I'm not into Spider Man either and I 100% it on the PS4 because it was that fun. I  had heard about how beautiful this game was, and I'm not seeing it. My machine can handle it on High. Should be able to handle it on Ultra. But frankly, it doesnt look that good even on High, everyones got kind of a wax doll look to them.Its still a fun AAA. And it *is* a typical AAA so expect all the handholding. Ive been playing From Software games lately, so going back I was surprised how easy it is and how everythings perfectly laid out for you and leads you by the nose. But I think thats just games in general nowadays. Still, its cute and fun. Everything is named stuff like Grindleblat and Snorkenplort or weird terms that sound *very* English to a North American. Playing this I can totally see why people got so into the world. Man, if I was 10 years younger I probably would have been into it too when it came out. Its worth a look even if youre not into Harry Potter. If you're OK with Denuvo that is. I'm not. Makes me want to sing yo ho ho and a bottle of rum when publishers put that crap on their games. And I am way not down with piracy. But Im also not down with publishers hamstringing their games for legitimate customers.

author: Tuz

author: Stew360
review: So far pretty good game , the environement are really cool . The game as some level of depth maybe not perfect yet but pretty good . Its the only Harry potter game universe worth mentioning ! A must have if you love this wisard world !

author: [EXDr] Xar
review: After playing the game for over 50 hours, completing the story, and achievement hunting for the majority of the game, I can happily say this game has been brilliant. It is truly a breath of fresh air, considering the amount of s**t we have received over the last few years, to see a game like this is truly relieving and has restored some of my faith on what games development companies can still achieve. The launch was very smooth and I have not really encountered many bugs within the game. I really enjoy the gameplay, but there are a few things that do irritate me. I understand that unlocking the broom riding is the first thing we SHOULD do, but it is the best way to travel around the open world, I feel like once you have the broom riding unlocked, I never even touched the mounts, ESPECIALLY the ground mount for that one story mission. Once you are fully geared up at the end, and upgrade everything to the max it really makes the game WAY too easy. The combat became more boring due to how easy it is, and this is playing on the hardest difficulty. The lockpicking ends up become more of a tedious task than anything, though I understand it being there to add another difficulty element to the game, forcing you to collect for the turn in quest which is fine, as I was planning on collecting most things anyways. The room of requirement is amazing, I had a ton of fun customising my little areas and designing it to how I liked it, the game all in all has been absolutely amazing so far, and I am excited to start my new character and join a new house for another adventure. Oh for those who like to collect things, especially transmog clothes, there is an amazing robe if you do the I hope everyone else has as much fun as me, and gets to enjoy living out their childhood fantasy! <3

author: Spicy Giblets
review: It's impossible to discuss this game without first acknowledging the discourse that surrounds it. If you are unaware the game has been boycotted and almost rightfully so because of the bigoted statements from the original author of the Harry Potter books J K Rowling. Rowling has effectively permanently tarnished the reputation of the franchise and has destroyed what may have been a safe space for trans people to escape the harassment and prejudices they can face on a daily basis. This silly wizard world is now a hot bed for political discussion and is also a breeding ground for far right rhetoric and hate speech. So when this game was announced many people have taken a stand to not play or support it and I 100% stand by those that make this decision, however I also stand by the people who just want to play a silly wizard game and the devs are clearly aware of the discourse and have tried their best to make the game inclusive with the option to make trans characters and also the inclusion of a trans character that is handled very well. So in short J K Rowling is a bigot but she is one part of what makes this game what it is and I feel if you can separate the art from the artist you'll find one of the most wonderfully crafted open worlds you can play.*****PC exclusive issues******Performance isn't ideal to say the least. Another example of a console port ♥♥♥♥ out onto steam. Massive shame because the game is fantastic. Please be aware of this before making a purchase.**************************Now to actually talk about the game, it's incredible and not only an outstanding achievement for avalanche software but quite possibly one of the best open world games out there. ProsHogwarts is one of the most complex buildings I've ever seen in a game. Filled with secrets, lively npcs and fantastic level desgin, it truly feels alive and should be an example going forward on how you make a game world feel alive.The Harry Potter universe is so excellently captured and has clearly come from a dev who understands the lore and world. This maybe the best representation of an existing IP translated into a computer game, the immersion and attention to detail is unrivaled and this could sit next to games like witcher 3 and RDR 2 with the amount of detail this world has.Combat is surprisingly amazing. It was one aspect I wasn't sure on before I played it but it is so varied and fun to pull off combos and with a good range of spells you can get quite creativeThe story is really good, it's better to have an understanding of the lore but I found it to be very enjoyable with lots of really likeable characters Graphics are nice and landscapes look breathtaking The OST is rock solidThe game has so many systems and surprises and it spaces them out without overwhelming you, I won't dive into details because the less you know the better but this game is jammed with content without it being too repetitive Cons As mentioned PC performance is not good, hopefully some patches fix thatWhilst the game is stuffed with content I do wish we had more. More beasts, mounts, gear, customisation options. What we have is good, really good in fact but it could be better.There is no morality system or romance options, no romance is fine but the game makes it seem like certain choices could have a major impact on the story or the way npcs treat you, unfortunately it doesn't effect anything if you use some of the more questionable spells. Conclusion This is a fantastic game that can be enjoyed by fans and non-fans alike. It's one of those rare games that can help people who don't often play games get into the hobby. It also gave me the same feelings I had when I first started playing breath of the wild and Elden Ring. If you choose to play this despite the original source material coming from a bigot you'll be in for a fantastic treat.

author: InuAres
review: Wait for a sale. Not because the game's bad, but because the PC police have very short memories and by the time this goes on sale, they'll have a new thing to be mad about. The game has a few framerate drops in certain areas, but aside from that, the game seems fine enough. Hogwarts is big and mazelike and the game rewards you for exploring it. Don't look up guides for the puzzles, they're actually really easy once you pay closer attention. If you're having a tough time, you're missing the forest for the trees. think small. You don't usually have to go very far to solve a puzzle.

author: burgerpattyy

author: 𝕄𝕖𝕟𝕒𝕡𝕒𝕨𝕫
review: Only downside is that the potions brewing is not more interactive. Would of loved some brewing mechanics rather then just selecting a potion and clicking brew.Other then that, it's a perfect game. 9.7/10,

author: Dindresto

author: Cleadus Jones
review: Never been a "Potter" fan. This game is highly addicting, very interesting and outstandingly immersive. Fluid, smooth and fun. The attention to detail is extremely high in many aspects. The only thing that would make it more immersive is more function as far as sitting in chairs etc. Walking in to the dining hall and standing there while your classmates are sitting chatting and eating away was a bit awkward. Being able to sit in various locations and watch the world around you would be a huge plus.Other than that, it is rare to see an over hyped game live up to the hype. especially at launch. Hogwarts Legacy has lived up to that hype.  #BringOnTheDLC. Bravo.

author: Giblix
review: As someone who enjoyed the many books and several movies taking place in the Wizarding World I was looking forward to this game. At around 25 hours of play it is very enjoyable. However it comes with some caveats.The first one is that I am more of an action based gamer. Gameplay is very important to me and supersedes story. That said the spellcasting is very enjoyable and the combat sequences feel good. Just make sure to delve into the options menu to fine tune elements in order to get the most out of it. Especially if you're playing on harder difficulties. It also seems that harder difficulties make enemies fight more intelligently, more aggressively etc instead of just being more hp/more damage.Through the use of Talents and Traits on gear you can create some fun gameplay. On top of that it shows potential for even more later on in the game depending on how enemy types evolve. One of my setups aims to single target nukes and disarming opponents while another setup changes into more of a juggling combo playstyle.The big caveat from that perspective is the pacing in this game. It is a very chill and slow game where you get to do a lot of exploration and puzzle solving. Combat sequences are far spread out as a result, even if you purely push the story forward. This all takes place in an immersive world. Unfortunately the puzzles are super easy, insultingly so a lot of the times. Exploring of Hogwarts alone can take you a dozen or two hours. Especially since a metroidvania aspect is involved where you need to get spells in order to backtrack and access places you couldn't before. Something I personally enjoy. Once you step foot outside of Hogwarts a large valley, densely packed with content, awaits you for even more exploration.I'm not a fan of Open World games. Very much the opposite. In Hogwarts there are many collectibles, challenges, dungeons, caves, beast dens, bandit camps, forts and many more. In this game it feels quite a lot more organic and less of open worlditis filler junk.To appeal to fans of the Wizarding World there are a lot of things present in the game. Unfortunately no Quidditch, Gobstones, collecting wizarding cards... Instead you can do a lot in the Room of Requirement, catch animals ala Mysterious Magical Beasts etc. My issue with this is more that it means you will receive a lot of tutorial-esque content till deep into the game. While some of these elements themselves aren't super fleshed out and seem to be there more as fan service. Which is fine in regards to shops, but less so to actual game mechanics.Since story isn't the main reason I play games, I read books for a real proper story, it does seem that Hogwarts is delivering a typical wizarding story. Instead of delving into the SLytherin Heir or the Dumbledore Bloodline we're now going to explore the much mentioned Ancient Magic. It is told in a way that feels very familiar to already existing media regarding the Wizarding World making it a nice addition to expand the world building.It isn't a super pretty game in regards to the latest graphical quality out there. I can see how viewers find some of the colors washed out or blend. Yet when playing it all fits thematically and doesn't detract at all.I did experience stuttering and some performance issues. However that was when streaming the game at the same time. If I play it without anything else going on then my I9 9900, RTX2080 Super and 16gb DDr4 on an NVME drive runs really well at High Settings.As for the whole controversy...not even worth listing it as a footnote. Little brains, Little Problems.

author: Artzy

author: Polarcade
review: If you have ever wanted to be a Wizard/Witch then this game is for you. Combat is fun and exciting. The story so far is intriguing and deep. Graphics are amazing! Head, armor, and wand has lots of customization options. Lots to do without being overwhelmed. I cant wait to get my first flying mount. Only downside so far is that it's only single player and you can't play Quidditch. Would have been even better as an MMO or at least co-op with a few friends. Might update once I have more hours.

review: Makes me want to knock Malfoy off his broom

author: كيسي
review: yes. yes. yes.

author: Sorenthaz
review: If you love the universe but are refusing to play this game because you don't like what the author of the franchise says about some things, you're missing out on a game that feels like a love letter for the Harry Potter/Wizarding World universe.  This is easily Game of the Year material and looks/feels amazing.  Finally we've got a AAA game that properly encompasses the books/movies and lets you play your own character within this setting.Not only that, but this game is great for people who are brand new to Harry Potter/The Wizarding World as well.  While there are obviously references and things fans of the books/movies/etc will notice and love, this game is such a great standalone title in the universe.  Game almost feels akin to the Fable games in some ways.  There's a lot to explore, fun puzzles, engaging combat, and a lot to play with here. The only way this could be made better is if you could play with friends and go on adventures together.  Also Quidditch missing (for now?) sucks, but hopefully it gets added in a DLC.  Beyond that though, this is easily the best experience to date for Harry Potter fans.

author: Kiwi
review: The game I've always wanted since I was 8. Rarely has a game gotten me so immersed within a few moments, I've but about 5 hours of gametime in at the time of writing this review and I'm not ashamed to say 4/5 hours were just running around exploring the castle and being in awe at the sights presented. I need to experience more of the game and gameplay itself (I'll update my review accordingly); But honestly I'd give this game a positive review if this were just a Hogwarts walk and explore simulator without anything to do. This game is a loveletter to every wizarding world fan and outside of that just damn fun. Worth every cent.

author: Raspbear
review: actually i expected the game to be a big flop but i'm so glad it lived up to the expectations. i've rarely seen such a beautiful game world with so much attention to detail. the game is definitely worth it. on sale even a must-have.i love that the developers dared to take the wizarding world much further than JKR ever could. adding a trans character to the story and giving the goblins much deeper stories and traits instead of sticking to the anti-semitic stereotypes JKR limited herself to is a good and important step in the right direction. it's a statement from the developers that they clearly distance themselves from JKR's views and separate the work from the author.

Think of it as an arcade-platformer with beautiful atmosphere, great music and lots of collecting of pieces of lore/fan-service. Duels and battling are fine. Puzzles are way too simple. For wizarding world afficionados.

author: Rubat
review: First of all, I'd like to extend a big f u c k you to Warner Bros. and the developers for including anti-consumer ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in this game, such as Twitch Drops, Accounts, Privacy Policy, Exclusive Content for PlayStation and Pre-Order bonuses. (Micro transactions are listed on Steam store page, but I could not find them in-game so far)With that out of the way, I still cannot imagine how the developers managed to convince whoever they had to, to allow this game to be made, and how this development studio I have never heard of before managed to make this game this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ good.If you like the world of Harry Potter (and not necessarily its characters because they are all brand new here) and action adventure games, this is a must play (maybe not must buy for reasons above). Like don't even bother reading further.I think just the ability to explore Hogwarts and its surroundings alone is worth the price of admission for me. But then you realize just how much content is in this game. I was running around with a big grin on my face in the first 6 hours exploring this world.Lots of spells, you can craft potions, grow plants, fly SEAMLESSLY around the entire map on a broom or animals. Just so many things from the HP world are implemented here in such a logical way, you name it - the game has it.Exploration also has many different and fairly unique things to do. Puzzles, camps to clear, collectibles, all present.Combat is also decently fun. Visually and sound design is very good during combat., but you do have a LOT of buttons to press to be effective, especially during boss fights and on hard difficulty.That's really another thing - there are SO MANY keybinds in this game, it's kind of overwhelming.The game also pays a lot of attention to the lore and its details, which you can see from the very first cutscenes. The spells all feel authentic.Music is very good as well.The game is not without its issues, of course. Here are some that I encountered:* No Quidditch* Facial animations are quite bad at times, specifically eyes sometimes looking in different directions, and mount movements transitioning strangely.* For some reason the game really forces you to fast travel in early quests. That's a really strange decision given half of the game is exploring hogwarts* Targeting in this game is GOD AWFUL. Just utterly unusable in tight spaces with many enemies present. The system will target any other character except the one you are directly looking it. It is just might boggling how bad it is. Not only that, in order to change locked target, you have to use arrow keys, and they are the only 2 keybinds you cannot rebind. There's one fight in early game where you are fighting 4 shielded enemies at once in a small room and I really lost my mind trying to beat them on Hard difficult.* Some exploration related spells are locked quite far into the main story line, namely the lockpicking spell. This really hindered by ability to explore much given how many locked doors are everywhere.* Inventory space is quite limited, and for no good reason besides having to upgrade it. But once you realize the transmog system in this game is good, it becomes less of a problem.* Menu animations are very slow and therefore frustrating. I don't understand why so many studio make this simple mistake, it's like they just LOVE wasting theirs and the players time.* Can't look up down while on a broomGraphically the game looks fantastic, but also not without issues:* Raytracing support is lackluster. Reflections are extremely blurry. Toggling RT requires game restart.* It am not sure if its specifically RT, but I have experienced a lot of lighting pop in with it enabled.* Some cutscenes have strange color correction, where one scene is darker, then it is brighter, then darker again, etc.* Severe framerate drops in many areas when the game was installed on HDD, or with RT enabled.* Cannot disable Anti Aliasing at all, making the game quite blurry without DLSS + manual sharpening setting, latter of which doesn't seem to even save across restarts* Ambient Occlusion is quite bad in the sense that it creates "halos" around characters in places, and you can't disable it.

review: Played since early access release.I have never been one for singleplayer RPG games, but I love the HP universe and was looking forward to this. 15 hours in and barely scratched the surface, because I have to explore everything. Love every second of this game.

author: MightyBison
review: Great game, everything i would expect from this kind of game. Shame there is no quiditch tho.

author: covert88
review: I can't recommend on PC until the performance issues are fixed. That's my only complaint so far.

author: Ted
review: Great game! There are a lot of reviews and nobody reads these so to the point as someone who was not a Harry Potter fan, I mostly bought this out of spite as I am sure many people did. Though I was looking for an RPG to sink some hours into and relax with a mindless grind and this game did that almost perfectly. These guys really did an amazing job of creating a beautiful and immersive world with some unique characters, though also some absurd woke diversity stuff that really doesn't fit the setting but it isn't enough to ruin the game. While the game looks stunning and the rendition of Hogwarts is really worth mentioning, there are performance issues as no doubt most people know by now. But if you have a decent CPU and GPU you should still have a great if occasionally stuttery experience. Overall this game far exceeded my expectations, it is the first game I ever bothered to complete to 100% and I can honestly say I enjoyed the vast majority of it. I am well and truly done at this point but I feel I really got my money worth and would recommend this game to anyone who likes this genre

review: This game is everything you's expect of the Wizarding World and more! Very engrossing and makes you lose track of time. 10 out of 10 would recommend to anyone looking for an amazing  open world game with more challenges than you can handle!

author: Wiegraf
review: The world looks great and the early parts of the game give you the best experience in the world of Harry Potter that's been made so far. However, it gets so incredibly repetitive and boring. Quests start to feel like a tedious chore and the only motivation is to complete the story... but the story isn't all that engaging and the characters aren't all that interesting, so the initial enjoyment and excitement begins to quickly fade.I'm going to settle on not recommending the game, but it's very much in the "meh" territory.

author: W1CKED ST1TCHES
review: The Boycott is what inspired me to buy the game in the first place. I must say this is one of the best decisions of my life. Game is beautiful visually, aesthetically  graphically. Combat is alot of fun I was expecting it to be boring ngl, I was wrong. Character creation is p cool, exploring feels rewarding, dialog, facial animations, etc. all wonderfully done. Don't listen to the transformers. You'll miss out on a BEAUTIFUL masterpiece such as this.

author: SolitaryAngel
review: Am just getting going. Still playing around with the controls, not a fan of WASD so still looking for my comfort zone but that aside, My GTX1080 and I7 (32 RAM) is getting me 55-60 fps on average with just a drop to 34 at the sorting hat ceremony cutscene so I am happy with that at 1440p resolution. What happens in combat later may be an issue but combat in the intro didn't seem to be a problem. Character creator was fine, a little samey but fine and I am comfortable with the character I made. No real stuff yet, a few clothing items but I am walking around the castle itself and it is huge. If you love exploration then you will adore this game.Five hours in, done my first two classes in the school and already I find the npcs a delight. From eccentric teachers to the dour administrator Headmaster to the Charms professor who is almost dancing as he walks. Other students all have their own way of speaking, from flaky girls who just love plants to a slitherin boy who is charming and friendly to a girl posed with a problem involving strange paintings who pouts and sulks when you solve the puzzle before her. It all feels very relatable and genuine.I am enjoying myself and I have barely scratched the surface but finally, a AAA game that arrives complete, is playable, is huge fun. Who cares about all the nonsense of the snowflakes trying to eat one of their own who had nothing to do with making this game anyway. The game is good, that's all you need to be concerned about, keep political nonsense out of video games, it does not belong there.

review: I dont care for Harry Potter. The movies or books.But this is a very well polished game and runs smooth. Combat is great. Good game is Good.

author: Bellemort6
review: This game is stunningly gorgeous.  I'm not really a Harry Potter fan, but I can fully appreciate the love and care the developers took to be faithful to the material and create something beautiful for the fans.  Sadly, that's a rare thing these days.  So, good on you, developers!  You deserve support just for that.  But more than that it's a great time so far and truly beautiful.

author: Diecy
review: Ok first lets get this out of the way, we all know about the controversy but why let out side ignorance and hate destroy something you enjoy? Yes the Author of the Harry Potter books is a piece of work but if you boycott everything because of creators beliefs do you understand that you all wouldn't be driving cars, flying in planes or watching TV? I refuse to be told what i should or shouldn't do by someone that doesn't care about me, My family, friends or their health, enjoyment, and happiness at all.****Review Of Hogwarts Legacy Follows****Hogwarts Legacy is a game many have been waiting for, a chance to live the life of a Wizard or Witch In the Hogwarts school. This game captures that feeling at it's core and has provided me with HOURS and HOURS of fun all ready. Building relationships with fellow classmates and exploring the unbelievable world that is Hogwarts Legacy. I find myself laughing and brought to tears in the pure joy that this game installs in me. Why would i not allow myself this pleasure? Politics have no place in games and this game lets me escape into the magical mystifying World of Harry Potter. The game looks beautiful and is just stunning. Yes it's not as pretty as say Red Dead Redemption 2 but it is going for a more cinematic/movie/fantasy experience in it's look and feel. The quest and story are a joy to follow and drive you on looking for that next fix.It's not all a bed of roses though as performance issues have hurt some players but i am not one of them. I am running a i5 12600K 32GB DDR 5 and a GTX 1080 Ti so not the most powerful machine but i am locked at 60 FPS ( my refresh rate ) EVERYWHERE! I never drop below this FPS point and i only have like 4 of the 30 or so Graphics settings lower than Ultra and only one of those is lower than high at medium. I have in fact seen this game use OVER 16GB of ram so maybe the days of "16GB of ram is more than enough for gaming" is over. My User rating  9.5/10ProsIt Hogwarts!Game play is engaging and funVisually stunning engaging story and character creation AND development.Best game i have played in a very long time.Easily Game of the year qualityConsNot enough inv space ( lol ) Some people suffer from unplayable lag and frame rates.The drama surrounding this game is a MAJOR con.no quidditchPossible Memory leak? ( never seen a game take over 16GB before )Please keep hate out of your comments. We play games to ESCAPE the real world.

author: Gamewarden
review: 7/10 A good game. The game has some performance issues.  Most being massive random frame drops here and there.  But I have experienced no Game breaking bugs, glitches, crashes, or freezes.  With how many major games release with countless bugs this is a welcome change.  However, like every game Hogwarts Legacy has it's flaws.PROS[Brings the Harry Potter Universe Alive]  As a fan of Harry Potter this game is amazing getting to go all over the school and outside of it.  There are so many places to explore and little activities to find. You can really see the detail that was put into making this world feel like it came straight out of the books/movies.  [Combat]Combat is Hogwarts Legacy is pretty fun to do.  You have a number of spells to use on your enemies and skills that make them even more effective.  However while combat is fun, it does get a little stale after hours of doing it and for another reason I will have in cons. CONS[School Life] If you are hoping to feel like a student at Hogwarts, I am sad to say this is not it.  You are a student sure, and you will have some classes, but you are going to spend most of your time running around doing pretty basic tasks and quests most of the time.  You don’t really interact to often with students besides the few followers in the game.  Really annoyed me that I could not sit down in the great hall with the other students.  [Enemies] Traveling outside of school you will encounter enemies.  This is another con for me because it feels like you will mostly fight dark wizards/poachers, goblins, and spiders.  There are a few other enemies to be sure, but they could have added much more variety in the enemies or at least made them more interesting.  The bad guys are your typical rough speaking, "We are going to kill you because we are evil" guys. Not much to them.  [Character won’t shut the hell up]  This is a personal annoyance for me.  But every time I go to Hogsmeade my character will say something along the line.  "Seems all roads lead to Hogsmeade.  Is there anywhere as cozy as Hogsmeade?"  Yes, I get it, You like it here.  Stop telling me that every time I walk into the damn town.  Your character will also do this with caves and whatnot regardless of if you explored them or not.  Your character is going to repeat themselves a lot. [Bland animations]  Now a lot of the animations in cut scenes are great.  I am talking about the speaking to NPC's that you will see often.  The characters are pretty stiff and as soon as their dialog runs out their faces go to expressionless.  It is not to bad, but adding more expressions in face and body language would have made the interactions feel more alive.[Choices]  To me a true RPG is not about skill trees, outfits, or even being able to customize your character.  It is about making choices and the world changing and reacting to them.  Hogwarts Legacy does have choices, and you may even here others talking about them.  But it mostly comes down to.  Say something nice or mean.  There is not to much here without a morality system.  This could have also really made the unforgivable spells feel unforgivable.  I get they want to keep it player friendly, but it would have felt so much more impactful if you had to hide your abilities otherwise word would get around and people will react differently to you.CONCLUSIONOverall Hogwarts Legacy is a fun game to play especially if you love the Harry Potter universe like I do.  The game is defiantly an impressive feat and I do think it is worth buying to show other game companies that there are a lot of players who want games like this one.

author: t0rn
review: Updated Short Review: When you fix the performance issues (with the DLSS patch and engine.ini fix) there is solid game. The combat is super fund and there is much to explore, even though it gets tedious after some time. The story is overall pretty underwhelming and unengaging, especially towards the end. It's a clever designed title, with some issues (performance, writing/story, mobile game level lock-outs), but none to glaring to spoil the game (except for performance, which can be fixed by modding). The world is well designed, but at a certain point into the game, there is really no point in exploring any further as you will only obtain cosmetics, you probably don't need or want.My last save has 41h playtime with the main story finished. There is still a couple of sidequests (which rewards you cosmetics) and a lot of collectible stuff as well remaining, but as I don't get anything from it, I don't see any point in doing them.TLDR: This is definitely a work of love, which captures the playful vibes of the movie material perfectly, but the game suffers from performance issues.Performance: Lots of framedrops with a 3070, 5600x, 32gb of RAM, DLSS quality, all on recommended (high) and 1080p (!) (no RT). Framedrops come and go, but seem to be related with loading. Generally framedrops happen during cutscenes or scene transitions, but they can occur in combat as well, usually at the start and finish of combat. Graphics: you can tell it's being held back by it being a cross-gen title, with not many stuff lying around, especially in larger areas. Small rooms are detail rich though.Audio: Soundtrack is really good, but there seems to be a problem with my audio-interface. I can hear some crackling from time to time, which is usually a sample rate issue, I've encountered with other UE4 games like Hunter:CotW. I have my interface sampling at 96kHz.Edit: I found the culprit: It's the steam overlay. Turning it off fixed my audio issues.Other than that: The game perfectly captures the world portrayed in the movies, going for a similar style. Story is kinda meh and all the friendship characters are really not memorable, but there is a lot to explore and the castle is very well designed. The open world does appear a bit empty, but the real stars are the castle and hogsmeade anyway (at least until now).It does feel a bit stale in terms of quest design and exploration, especially in dungeon levels. However, sidequests have a very modern design approach, as in: they are very short. There is lots of busy work, but it does not get annoying, as small tasks only take up a minute or so of your time, which makes exploring, at least until now, enjoyable.Verdict: Wait for performance to be fixed, other than that: great game, even though it is a little bit shallow.(I will change my review to positive when this happens)

author: pN
review: This game is not bad, but its not good either. Being one myself, I cannot recommend it to a true HP fan.I dont get the people who say it is a good game for Harry Potter fans. It is not at all that, on the contrary. I will explain further on. I will also list the good points on this game down below.Now my critique points on this game:- Brutally poor performance on PC:I get regular fps dips and funny freezes, narrowed the settings down, capped the FPS and still they exist. Everywhere I read of players having similar issues, regardless of their PC specs.- Bland, boring story without any depth:It does not fit into the HP universe. Underage wizard gets abused by four old "keepers" to endure pain and suffering to kill a goblin who wants to drill under Hogwarts. What the ...?- Repetitiveness: Quests and challenges (poacher camps, merlin trials etc. all require the same routine over and over)- No character depth or development:You are the good guy, whether you like it or not. No matter how red your eyes are, how slytherin you are, how much avada kedavra you spam. You cannot plunge into the dark arts at all apart from learning the 3 unforgivables (and using them of course).- Unrealistically high amount of different cultures in Hogwarts:Before people scream racism: Mixed cultures and colours in this degree are not fitting in the britain of the 1880s/1890s where this game is set, where people of different colours were not at all as prominent in britain as they are now. If the game was set in the 2010s, it would of course be more fitting.- Now lets explain why the game is bad for true Harry Potter fans (listed reasons):1.) In 7 books there was not a single mention of different villages, castles etc. being right around Hogwarts, except Hogsmeade.Hogwarts and the area of Hogwarts according to the books and movies consists of Hogwarts castle, the grounds (including the quidditch pitch and the gamekeepers hut, the forbidden forest, the black lake), Hogsmeade, and maybe the mountains around it. Yet the game consists of 70% small villages, castle ruins and even coastal areas which do not fit the lore at all.2.)  Poachers are killing animals in the forbidden forest. Of course, every headmaster that would fit the lore would have taken action and banished them from the grounds, and not let an underage wizard do the job.3.)  Every Hogwarts student according to the books and movies arrives by train (Starting in London, no stops inbetween!) every year. Sebastian Sallow, being from Feldcroft, comes by foot then?4.) Curfew. All students, except prefects, have a curfew. In one mission this is in place, but other than that, you can wander around at night fully visible with no worries. Not like in the books and movies at all.5.) The castle. It is beautifully made, and there are lots of spots that remind you of the movies, and a bit of the books. But the castle is just too damn small! I would have wished that they had cut 3/4 of the world and used that space to expand the castle size. Where are the seven floors? Where are the countless classrooms? Why is dumbledores office not on the same level as the room of requirement for example? Where is the caretakers office? Etc. etc. This wouldve been easily done had they just removed all the villages, castles and the never ending land around Hogwarts in the game.6.) Quidditch, where is it? Again, use the space you wasted on the boring villages and integrate Quidditch! The pitch is already there.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Onto the good stuff:- Beautiful graphics- Apart from being way too small, the castle is well made and looks stunning- Hogsmeade is done pretty well- Very fitting, dynamic music depending on where you are and what you are doing in the game, and what time of day it is- Little details (not being able to enter the girls rooms as a male, paintings that react to you, lots of different animals, cats, ghosts etc.)- Common rooms are a big plus, being just as in the books and/or movies, you can enter every dormatory and even the toilets with bathtubs!- The fighting system with the use of all the different spells is very fun to use and opens the possibility to experiment for quirky combos.- The use of the room of requirement as a kind of home base for the new 5th year student is a good move and could fit the lore.- The ability to grow different herbs and brew potions is very neat.- The ability to change your outfits, hair etc. is fun and should be even more developed (facial hair for example)- The possibility to merge your pottermore stats into the game is exactly what I had wished for!- The movie locations are very well depicted and recognizable, even the kitchens are there, even if they are not in the movies--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Conclusion:Well, these are my opinions on the game. The graphics are beautiful. Love the little details. But overall, and I dont get why people keep saying it is, it is not so much a game for true HP fans. There is of course the need for a compromise in such a game, to fit the movies more than the books maybe, and to make the story more worthwhile, but they could have used all the useless space around Hogwarts and made Hogwarts a big castle with all the stuff a true HP fan wanted, including Quidditch, late night strolls to find hidden chambers and corridors, etc. Being able to build relationships based on your answering would have been cool to. And the ability to grow your character into a dark, or a light wizard, depending on what you prefer. It is not a bad game, but I cant recommend it to a true HP fan.
