author: RoboEagle
review: A great game only held back by PC optimization issues. Hogwarts itself is stuttery at times, but on a powerful system (e.g. RTX 3090), the game is still more than playable. It's a ton of fun for even a casual Harry Potter fan. The world is extremely immersive and worth spending time in; which is good because it is a slow burn at first. Overall, a memorable fantasy RPG experience!

author: Janspach
review: Absolutely amazing time for the first 2/3rds of the game. Exploring in the beginning and doing the side quests felt really special. Im not a big harry potter fan but even I really loved exploring Hogwarts and its surroundings. The Room of Requirement was a really fun diversion. Combat is great against most enemies but fighting trolls was annoying because of their ridiculous health barsThe beginning of the game was great but by the end it started to drag on and the story felt rushed at the end. The whole coast portion could have been cut and the game would have felt better.8.2/10

author: joxertm22
review: Not a perfect game.Clunky menus (thanks to retarded consoles), too much of grinding, some annoyances that luckily don't affect the overall game (no need to solve all merlin puzzles and one is bugged on my side), the main story unlocks good stuff instead of passing all that to side quests.And what's with CTRL instead of doubletap? Okay I kinda nitpick now because at least these dev know that M is map, I inventory and J journal unlike some amateurs that map IJKL to emulate console mushrooms. And yet TAB+3 for the broom is kinda retarded.Inventory tetris could have been a tadbit better, especially randomized loot (savescum possibility), but all in all I did not have a problem with trading and buying anything I wanted.The ping on detected bookpage should have been also visual for hearing impaired players.On the totally positive side the world and stories are awsome and full of interesting puzzles and secrets.Combat on PC against trashmobs is easy, but bosses are not easy which is a big plus.I don't know if choices during dialogs matter, but I have seen a few times NPCs mention what you solved - in sidequests! This is absolutely awsome, I generally love sidecontent and this game has plenty of it in different varieties.Finally there is a performance problem if you keep consoley crap enabled (motion blur, film grain, etc). This will probably be fixed in upcoming patches.So, should you buy this?Absolutely! While not a masterpiece, the game is so much fun, beats any aggresively advertised mainstream trash when it comes to having fun.

author: Dr. Demontale
review: IntroI'm going to start by saying I had little expectations and very high hopes for this game. I've never really heard of Portkey Games and this is a BIG IP, with a huge Fanbase and a few haters (of course). In the case of advertising, the haters of J.K. Rowling and Harry Potter all together have done a really good job, of letting EVERYBODY know when this game comes out and made sure that you do NOT forget about the release. I want to thank them for this. I had a few hiccups in the very beginning, the hour of release (7pm, 7th Feb, 23, to be precice). The game was preloaded and just wouldn't unpack itself, even with me manually doing it. So, naturally, I was frustrated. But well, I quickly downloaded Monster Hunter World and killed about 1 1/2 hours before the problem was fixed either by steam, or Warner Brothers, which is a really good time, I must say. And then I started the game. Oh my, my childhood and my teenage years came back as quick as it gets. The character creator was a little underwhelming to be honest. Maybe because I just came from the absolute insane creator of Monster Hunter World, but I would've expected more, yet I am satisfied with it.The GameI must say... I did not expect the game to graphically look so beautiful. I am running it on a RTX 2070 Ti, and even on Medium options and performance mode it looks stunning, if you're not nitpicky. The animations of the characters are fine, sometimes a bit robotic, but I don't care about that one bit. Huge framedrops in cutscene until I changed to performance mode (don't ask me why, I don't know). Having played a good 30 hours right now, unlocked a few spells and must say, they could've done a better job with the UI. Somehow the changing between spell-presets feels really weird to me, but it does NOT take out the fun out of gameplay or combat at all!Let me tell you, and I am so happy to say this, I didn't expect them to go THIS hard on this game. Exploring the castle feels real, the friends you meet are authentic. The overall population is, of course, fantasized to be extremely diverse, which is a really nice detail. Combat feels fluid, you feel the impact of the spells you are casting and getting new, very specific spells is very exciting. The world is HUGE if you travel by flying. There is a lot to do, many cats to be petted, many things to collect and the best thing about it is: It doesn't force the collecting on you. It just happens. Like The Witcher 3, or Breath of the Wild, you are on your way to a quest, and then you see a cave. You explore the cave because it looks nice, you find another note in there, telling you to go to another place, and so on and so on, you get it. It feels natural and absolutely amazing. I wanna thank the team that made this possible. Does my enthusiasm mean it won't get stale? I mean, there is always room for improvement, sure. But I think it will be a few more weeks until I get tired of flinging people through the air by magic. I really hope this is going to evolve to a big serious of never ending, macigal adventure. Well done, 60 housepoints to PortkeyGames. 9,5/10 expelliarmus'ses's

author: Piston Smashed™
review: You receive a letter that says that you’ve been accepted into Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry as a fifth-year student. Starting Hogwarts as a fifth-year student is very unusual and while the use of magic outside of Hogwarts is prohibited outside of school you have been given special permission by the Ministry to hone your magic under the tutelage of Professor Fig. He will then escort you from London to the Hogwarts along with all your supplies in time for the start of term feast and Sorting Ceremony. Before the feasting and ceremony can begin, you have the chance to customise your character, name them, choose to be a witch or wizard and choose the games difficulty. You can if you wish, select one of the preset characters on offer or you can customise your characters looks using the customiser where you can choose from different Face Wear (Face Shape, Skin Colour and Glasses), Hair Styles and Colour, Complexion (Freckles, Moles and Scars and Markings), Eyes and Eyebrows and Voice. There are four game difficulties, Story, this is focused on the story with minimal gameplay challenge. Easy has a light gameplay challenge, Normal is your standard balanced challenge and Hard is where you’ll receive a demanding gameplay challenge. The game begins with both you and Professor Fig preparing to leave London in a flying carriage. A George Osric of the Ministry joins you both, with him and Professor Fig needing to talk about something however it would be better if they spoke enroute to Hogwarts rather than in the streets of London. After setting off Professor Fig and George talk about the Ranrok threat, while some at the Ministry think he’s not a threat others believe that he is a great threat. George had been in contact with Professor Fig’s wife before she died about Ranrok’s activities, and she was wondering if the Ministry knew anything. However, before he could reply he received a mysterious item that he cannot open was delivered by her Owl.  The mysterious item has a symbol which only you can see glowing and when you handle the item it opens revealing a key. Then suddenly the carriage is ripped in half throwing poor George to his death. The carriage is being attacked by a dragon, before it attacks again you both jump as you fall you grab the key which then transports you both to a mysterious cave, it’s from here that your adventure begins... As you make your way from the cave and explore your surroundings, you’ll start to go over some of the basics of the game. You’ll eventually find yourselves at Hogwarts, although you will now have a mystery starting to unravel. You and Professor Fig will work together in trying to solve the mystery but first you must deal with school and the Sorting Ceremony where you will find out which house you will become part of. You will play through a day and night cycle; in the daytime you can take various classes and at night you can do what you’d like, at least I did although I was told at one point to head back to the common room at night but that’s just boring. Taking classes will allow you to learn various things such as botany where you can grow your own plants to be used as ingredients for potion making or you can grow some plants which will help you in combat. Spellcasting, Flying and other lessons can all help you as you progress through the game. The teachers will set you extra assignments along with the main story quests, where you could learn a new spell or unlock something else. Gaining quests isn’t solely with the teachers, your fellow students can also give you quests to complete with various rewards for completing them. You can also complete Challenges such as Time Trials on your broom where you must beat a certain time to complete and earn rewards. You are given a Field Guide by Deputy Head Professor Weasley, anything you find will appear in this guide and there are a lot of things to find. Using Revelio will reveal what is hidden, allowing you to collect the field guides. In the field guides you can uncover some information about what you have discovered. Away from Hogwarts in the surrounding area you’ll find Hogsmeade, here you can buy items for potions and their ingredients, brooms, clothes etcetera. You can also sell any items here with any of the vendors, you can find traders also out in the small hamlets which are dotted around Hogwarts surroundings. You can find areas of interest on your map and once, you have visited an area and unlocked the Floo Flames Network so you can fast travel back and forth at any time you wish. To begin with you only have your legs to travel from one place to another, however, as you progress you will acquire a broom and later a flying mount which are great but not as fast as using the floo flames network. Combat consists of you using what you have learnt, you have a basic attack but that’s not going to do you much good on its own. You will learn offensive and defensive spells, but you will also have at your disposal potions and even creatures such as the Chinese Chomping Cabbage and the Mandrake. Performing combo’s using your magic and taking damage will accumulate Ancient Magic which can be used in combat and can be very helpful especially against the tougher enemies you come across. You can have four quick access spells slots to begin with but once you unlock Talents (Skills) you’ll be able to unlock another three tiers of four slots. In total you have twenty-three spells to unlock but you’ll only be able to select sixteen for the quick access slots. This will allow you to sort out your spells how you like as not all spells are for combat so you can have a couple tiers for combat, one for conjuring items and one for whatever. You can switch between each of the tiers as required depending on your current situation. You will earn one Talent Point for each time you level up your character. There are five categories in which you can spend your Talent Points on, these are Spells, Dark Arts, Core, Stealth and Room of Requirements. Out in the open world along with the Hamlets you will find some Merlin Trials, these are some simple puzzles to complete and in doing so they will increase the size of your gear inventory. You find gear in chests, and you can also buy gear from shops or traders. The gear you collect will add protection and bonuses to your defence and attacking abilities, although to use some of them you may need to be at a certain level before being able to equip the gear to your character. You gain levels through collection of experience points as you defeat enemies and complete quests. The gear also comes in various rarities, and some can be upgraded with abilities.Positives  + Fantastic graphics + Very enjoyable to play + Lots of quests, challenges and puzzles + Has achievements + Steam Deck verified Negatives  - No cards currently Explore Hogwarts, unlock its secrets, fly by moonlight, solve the mystery of ancient magic and put a stop to Ranrok’s plans all while you attend classes and learn spells as you become a wizard in the 18th century. 9/10

author: artfuldodgeram
review: Growing up, I was what one would consider a mild-to-moderate Harry Potter fan. I was around eight years old when the first movie came out, but I didn't read the books or see any movies in theaters aside from the first, second, and last until I was an adult. Despite the controversy around J.K. Rowling and the volatile nature of virtually everyone who feels the need to vehemently simp for a self-conceited billionaire, I purchased Hogwarts Legacy anyway since carving your own path as a wizard/witch seemed enticing. I'll throw this disclaimer out there: I am pro-trans and left-leaning.Simply put, Hogwarts Legacy is window dressing. The game lacks any natural substance and comes off as a storefront for later DLC releases, similar to other WB games. Once you take off the sepia-toned glasses of nostalgia, the game feels dated. The story is mediocre, laden with Obama-era liberal idealism befitting those between the ages of 18 to 22 during the early twenty-teens (coincidentally, the group of people most likely to have Potter-related tattoos). The gameplay is briefly fanciful yet repetitive (similar to Middle-Earth: Shadow of Mordor, although with less reason to pursue varying combat styles absent of unrelenting spell-slinging). None of the choices you make matter in any meaningful way. The player character feels less like an actual student at Hogwarts and more like an observant exchange student. The game is utterly lacking in dynamism. NPCs are wholly non-reactive, both in dialogue options and in general interactivity, the actions you commit and the choices you make have virtually no impact on the procession of the story, and despite a blatant misdirection of presenting this game as open-world with dynamic paths, the only thing open about the game is the map (although not too open since you can't travel to certain places before you've checked the arbitrary boxes the game has placed before you).That said, the writing is the worst part of the game. None of the characters are particularly memorable or engaging, aside from that blind fellow with a laughable name (honestly, who names a child Ominis?). The cast of characters is somehow more diverse than the Hogwarts faculty and student body from the books, which take place 100 years after the events of Hogwarts Legacy. There's no questioning why the goblins are rebelling, just that they are, and they must be stopped. Some of the characters feel like they're written based on politics, like the Merlin researcher who informs you that she is married to another woman for no reason other than standard liberal brownie points or the inexplicable and poorly named trans character, Sirona.Again, Obama-era liberal idealism is laden in every corner of this game, likely for a good reason, since Harry Potter stans tend to fall directly into that category. Combine that with J.K. Rowling's dance with the TERF community, and you appeal to both sides of the political spectrum. Like all who embody respectability politics, you're not alienating anyone. That's not to say those video game developers shouldn't walk on eggshells if they want to. Still, it certainly makes for a dull experience when they do.For all intents and purposes, the game is below average. That's not to say I haven't enjoyed parts of it. The flying mechanics are great, and the game is visually appealing in a Norman Rockwell-Set-In-The-Wizarding-World way. Your eye is drawn to what you're familiar with, like the moon-backed silhouette of Hogwarts or the use of popular character surnames.While I'll take the time to finish the game (mama didn't raise no quitter), I cannot recommend anyone buy it at full price. There's only a little value to be found beyond nostalgia. If you like that, fine. Go ahead and play it.If you're looking for something beyond the surface in Hogwarts Legacy, you'll be disappointed because there is very little.

author: The Entire Soviet Union
review: The set pieces in this game are breathtaking. Hogwarts and Hogsmeade are so well realized and feel so alive. You know what doesn't feel alive? The characters. They are so bland and one dimensional. The longer I played the game, the more I realized how little it offered. The side quests are all bland and unimagined, the ambient objectives are just copy and pasted across the world, and the combat boasts it's in depth mechanics, but shoots itself in the proverbial foot bone by shackling every spell to a specific class, making it redundant to switch up your bread and butter loadout. Also, the lack of any sort of repercussions to using curses is just so, so stupid. The unforgivable curses in this game are akin to doing a "no-no" at Weenie Hut Junior's. Sometimes, an NPC with no charisma might say something along the lines of "I can't believe you've done this!" but that's all that'll happen. This game could've been so good with a Fable style morality system, as well as a trouble mechanic like in Bully, but instead it just says "DON'T YOU DARE DO X" without there being any repercussions for your actions. This game is a Kardashian, on the surface, it's beautiful and interesting. In reality? It's hollow and fundamentally broken.

author: Lewd Komi-san
review: So.Pros:- No Harry Potter.- The plot. And it's not another retelling of books about Harry Potter.- Fanservice.- Actually well written characters.- Some good side quests.- Music is top tier, especially the main menu theme.- Combat system is decent, though it could have more of everything.- Insane character customization. You can become the clown you're destined to be. Cons:- Optimization is really bad. Seriously, don't wear capes.- Overall graphics is kinda meh. All female faces look the same.- Severe level of gameplay and narrative dissonance. I didn't feel like Hogwarts Student, more like a witcher or Cpt. Shepard with a magic wand.- MC is Mary Sue, war criminal and psychopath, but people still like them.- No reputation or punishment system outside of certain quests.To sum up, it's probably the best Harry Potter game out there for now. Feels like there's been a lot of stuff cut from the final release, and lots of other stuff was put there just because it's trendy.If you're a fan, it's the game just for you.Otherwise it's another open world mediocre RPG.Nuff said.

So, I guess I'm the dumb one.

author: Nocturnal Jules
review: While this game has received a ton of flak for people's politics I am not leaving a negative review for those reasons. This game like many other new releases is unpolished and filled with bugs. BUT the biggest bug is the save game issue. What I mean by this is the game will arbitrarily chose to delete your save game. As you can see I have played this game for a hot minute but have lost every single save game and I have tried this four separate times with each house. For this game it is infuriating to reach bugs and have my save that I poured time into to just go poof cause the game decides we are not gonna continue that or even let you finish the game. I would suggest waiting until this bug is polished out of the game and to be honest the game would still be pretty mid. Its fun at first but its very repetitive and has no reply value.

author: Raptorman
review: Hogwarts Legacy is a fantastic game, where you are in the wizarding world but 100 years before the events of Harry Potter. You create your student character, who starts as a 5th year, and travel to Hogwarts with Professor Fig. It does not take long for the story and action to start as you try to learn about the secrets of ancient magic that only your character seems to be able to see and interact with. You develop by learning new spells, exploring the open world and completing quests and side quests. For anyone that is a fan of the wizarding world and wanting to experience being a student at Hogwarts, this is a must have game.The combat system is something you do get fluent with, and you will be well advised to use some of your talent points to unlock more slots for spells to be accessed to during combat. There are a lot of spell combinations that can lead to high damage, or even instantly killing enemies, and some unique combinations that work when specific enemies are about to use particular attacks.  A very enjoyable experience so far.

author: Biggie P Papa Rough Assassin
review: The world kept me busy and making me want to explore while I was heading for quests, which in turn made me pick up more quests and finish them before the main one I was chasing. The game is very immersive and I'm not one to chase 100% completion but by the time I finished all the quests I figured I wanted to also get all the achievements since they were so close to completion. 10/10

author: Mr_Charles
review: As a child, I read the Harry Potter books and always fantasized about what it would be like to go to Hogwarts. This game captures that feeling perfectly! I really enjoyed the exploration of the world and the magic combat without mana costs. The world is intricately crafted; the developers definitely love the franchise. Nonetheless, there are the standard open-world activities, but with very good variety in level design. There are "not just stupid" collection tasks, and you also have to use magic spells wisely outside of combat.The rooster of Characters are solid and the main plot drive in safe waters. But the classmates quest were very suprising and full of "Wow"-Moments.What impressed me the most was the fact that you can cultivate your own magical plants, brew magical power drinks, and domesticate magical beasts, as well as craft your own items and gear as needed. This game doesn't have to hide behind big RPGs like Skyrim.For the first 20h i would have called this game a MASTERPIECE, but after the exploration and fascination drops a bit this game ist still STUNNING. even for muggel-players.

author: Treelo
review: The game itself is exceptional - lots to do, fun combat, and beautiful visuals to accompany it - but there are glaring issues that have to be mentioned -If you have a good pc it runs "fine", still needs optimization though, hard to keep above 60 frames on anything, good luck getting anything higher than 75 to be stable. Required a lot of messing around in the settings to find a playable setup, and even after all that still get huge frame pacing issues at times. RT is straight up unusable, often looks worse with it on than off, huge visual glitching issues with it. Also audio mixing is terrible, no master volume control, and the sliders present seem to hardly do anything, with many elements (such as the basic cast, and certain character dialogue) not responding to them and playing at full volume regardless. If these things get patched this game will potentially be my game of the year

author: BLIИK
review: I wanted to love this game, i really did. And maybe i can change my review to a thumbs up sometime in the future but the actual technical state of the game is just unbearable. As you can see i have about 7h "playtime" from which are about 4h just trying to get the game to work. I managed to play the first hour of the game, got to sleep and then came back the next day to play some more and bäm, nothing, literally nothing works anymore. The game doesnt even start and at this point i´m just sick of trying to fix it. Browsing through the web it seems there are a lot of unlucky guys just like myself just trying to get this game working ... Also the fact that the Developers doesnt seem to be working on the problem adds to the frustration - at least there is no announcement that theyre working on a solution.Buying this game is a bit like Kinder Surprise, you really dont know what you will get and the possibility the game randomly shuts down and stops working all of a sudden is defenitely there. So keep that in mind fellow potterheads. I give up now, after trying literally EVERYTHING i´m just exhausted and sad.Update: After a lot of fiddling around some of my other games began to show the same problems as Hogwarts Legacy, so i decided to reset my whole system (was time for that anyway) and now i can finally play the game. I´m having tons of fun so far, but i have to say the performance ist just really bad. With a couple of additional lines ind the engine.ini and the great FPS fix mod from Nexus Mods i managed to get a stable framerate. Begs the question why the modding scene once more needs to fix a unfinished product and make doing this seem so easy. In terms of gameplay i really love what Portkey games did there, but the technical state still keeps me from recommending the game at the moment. It was just too much hassle to get this AAA product to run and you shouldnt have to jump through hoops to play a game which you paid 60 bucks for.

author: Bassilth
review: I just finished this game.- Character customization is pretty good- Graphics and animation- Voice acting- The story for the most part was enjoyable and captivating. Sometimes I found I could not pull away- Ample side activities to fill in your free time as you explore- Attention to detail is astonishing. Everything we saw in the movies is there. Moving pictures, statues, ghosts, you name it.- Random things sometimes happen as you explore, even if they become old after seeing it more than five times.- We can pet chain-smoker cats!- You can keep pets (beasts) and brush them, feed them.- Gear customization caters to the player's personal preference and does not force you to look like a clown that just left the circus as you wear the strongest gear you could find. You can choose the look of any outfit you found so far on any gear.- Large open world to explore- Combat isn't like Dark Souls. Controls are easy to learn, combat isn't overdone, which serves to make you feel powerful.- Some side-quests are actually quite enjoyable and captivating-------------------------- The developers say that you can choose to be a good or evil wizard. Thing is, with no morality system in place, this is simply a lie. NPCs couldn't care less about you blasting combat spells around them, or picking the lock to their house, steal the stuff of a family sitting by the table, or whichever choice you make at the end. None of these matter. Not even the options you pick in dialogues. The story is as it is.- The attention to detail is indeed astonishing but it is clear they focused too much on this and not on other aspects of gameplay, like allowing our character to live in the world they are put in. You cannot even sit down in a chair, sleep in your bed, eat with the other students in the Great Hall, no curfew. No interaction at all. You simply exist in the game but don't live.- There are a lot of side activities indeed and the map is full of them. But there are the same 6 or so types you can do like 50 times. Good luck completing them.- Ending is a let down. Without spoilers... It doesnt matter what you do, what you choose, what you say... Nothing matters. The ending is meh. Not at all fulfilling. No consequence, no difference. It almost seems like it is incomplete.-------------------------All in all, I did enjoy playing it. But the lack of morality system, the lack of consequences or changes to the plot or flavor of the game depending on your choices was ruining it. Still, I give it a thumbs up because it gave me a good time. I just wish they would have spent less time on the castle and more on developing gameplay.

author: Domi
review: Hogwarts Legacy is decent game. Like thousand other people I was really hyped about this game and when the day finally came, I didn't think twice before buying the Deluxe edition. But looking back ... I think this was a mistake, paying 10€ for playing 3 days earlier than people who got default game. But, I can say that, despite having few flaws and cons, you will enjoy this game if you are fan of Harry Potter universe.Graphic is really awesome, story is really enjoyable and gameplay, especially with puzzles is great. Also the "feel" of this game is amazing.Now, what flaws and cons am I talking about?For  example, the  as this is promoted, is really empty and pretty much unoccupied. Sure, there are few villages, but with only up to 10 people, including one trader,few chest and thats it. Other than that, there are only repetetive challenges, caves, beast spots and enemy camps. The only locations you will propably enjoy and remember, are, obviously Hogwarts castle and Hogsmead. Also, In some videos, it was pointed, that your dialogue choice will have impact on the story. You can be mean, the NPC will react differently, but after dialogue, you are still their friend and hero at the end. is not so forbidden after all. You can loiter around as much as you like, even with other NPCs and nobody will care.And  are, once again not so unforgivable after all. You can cast them in front of other NPCs, but they will only say things like :  and so on ... And at the end of the story, you are hero and nobody mentions that you are using Unforgivable CursesNow. Wandering around castle at night.You can teach yourself  so you can stealth around people as part of one quest where you have to avoid prefects, because, well its night and you should be sleeping. So you do that and quest ends.Do you thing you have to avoid prefects from now on? Nope, that was one time thing. ( There is maybe one other quest like this. ) You can walk, run around castle as you like, while other students are sleeping and prefects ... well they are nowhere to be found. This may sound like silly issue, but since developers obviously spend their time to implement this mechanic into the game and then they decided to use it for quests only is weird. But, at the end of the day, this game is really great and you will have fun.

review: Its a decent game but certainly not a 10/10 game that everyone makes it out to beThe world itself is really well made and would be close to a 10 but then u have the dialogue and the voice acting in this game....... Its really really bad especially from the main character and that for me atleast is the worst part of the game by far and drags the game down by alot.Combat is fun in the start but gets boring towards the end and i would say the story is decent i guess but nothing special.I do have to say that if i didn't spend 70 euros on this game im not sure if i would have finished it.Game gets a bit boring in the end and felt a bit like a chore to finish it and the voice acting is definitely a big part of that. It just doesn't pull me into the story at all.Would probably give it a 6.5 and would advice it to buy on sale honestly

author: WheezySquash8
review: Hogwarts Legacy was one of the most fun gaming experiences I've had in the last year. It provided an immersive world that is a dream for any Harry Potter Fan. The game excelled more than it failed in many retrospects. I beat the campaign and have 38 Hours in the game. Here is my perspective.Successes of the game:1. Immersion. Any building is possible to enter, loading screens are minimal, and everything flows extremely well in the world. I felt like I was in the Harry Potter Universe the whole time playing this.2. The magic system. The way you fight with magic in this game, and interact with the world while using it is amusing and exciting at the  same time. The combat with magic had me on the edge of my seat throughout fighting the various monsters of the world, and the puzzles I had to use my magic on provided entertainment. 3. Flying. This game did an amazing job with flying mounts and flying on your broom. I enjoyed flying around Hogwarts and seeing the size of the world in this game (it is huge)4. Character development. The story of this game does an amazing job making you develop relationships with the characters you see that play a big role in the excitement of the game. Personally my favorite characters I became fond of playing this game were Sebastian Sallow and Natsai Onai. 5. Lore. This game's' biggest strength without a doubt is lore. You see so many creatures described in JK Rowling's films, you see paintings on the walls described exactly like in the Harry Potter books, and you overall can tell the makers of this game took a lot of time to describe the Harry Potter Universe properly.Failures of the game (although the game is far more of a success than failure):1. Empty, but beautiful world. The world in this game is huge (which is another pro) but it is extremely empty outside of Hogwarts and Hogsmeade. Some areas had me wishing the developers spent more time adding details. The Forbidden Forest especially could have been WAY better. The world still maintains beauty but is very empty.2. Slow narration. The start of the game is extremely slow, and it takes a while to get off your feet. Some parts had me thinking that characters were just providing filler in their narration. Some narration was also very boring and had me trying to skim over it as soon as I could.3. Repetitive monsters/beasts. This game has a very enjoyable combat system and I also really enjoyed the aspect of taming beasts, but a lot of the monsters and beasts you interacted with were repetitive. You mostly only fight wolves, knights (pensieves), goblins, poachers, spiders, trolls, ashwinders, dugbogs, thieves, or inferiuses (zombies). For beasts you have like 6 you can capture and put in a habitat and nothing further. 4. Side quests versus the main story. I wanted to start the game doing a lot of side quests but had to do the story because if I didn't I would not have all of the mechanics of the game unlocked (especially lockpicking. You don't get it until later in the main story when you should get it early on). The game pressures you to focus purely on the main story and getting it complete rather than doing any side quests which I think is a negative in a game trying to be free and open world. 5. A game that missed out on a lot of potential in certain aspects. You pick a house when you begin the game, but the house you pick barely affects the plot of the game. I would have liked to have seen houses play a bigger role in the game. You also cannot do much in your house area. Throughout the game, they claim you can customize your character's gear in a unique fashion (including your wand), but the appearance of gear is extremely repetitive. Your wand customization is minimal, although it does exist which is nice. Overall, this game excelled in so many aspects of detail. It's biggest strength in my opinion is immersion and lore. This is the perfect game for a Harry Potter fan. Some points had me wish it went further with care for detail (especially when it comes to repetition of characters, clothes, etc), but it is an extremely great game. I would give it an 8.5/10.

author: Spacesh1p
review: First and foremost, the RPG tag is misleading.  is not an RPG game in any capacity. It has some features characteristic of RPG games, such as leveling up, talents, gear, and dialogues, but it doesn't make it a role-playing game. Name an AAA title that doesn't have at least some of these nowadays.  does not feature the defining thing which makes a game  - choices and consequences. You can run around breaking into restricted places and casting forbidden spells, and no one will raise an eyebrow. Sure, you will make choices in dialogues, but your decisions don't matter. The main story will keep you strictly on the rails, and most of the side quests are just about going somewhere, doing something, and coming back. Dialogues here are for pure immersion, which is lovely, but don't expect anything beyond that. There definitely was a potential for role play, given the nature of the story and the setting itself, but it was never realized for some reason.As for the story itself, it's... okay. It's undoubtedly epic and exciting to follow most of the time. However, there're specific segments when it feels frankly dragged for the sake of dragging. I mean, a dozen of main story quests could've easily been optional. Characters are primarily one-dimensional but still well-written and voiced. If you have a kink for accents as I do, then you would probably find satisfying how diverse the voiceover cast is, which makes every character, even barely presented ones, feel unique. In terms of progression,  is an example for many open-world games out there. Unlocking various side activities, additional spells, and locations is tied to your story and side quest progression, which I found very convenient since the game doesn't overwhelm you with everything it has to offer at once but instead unlocks it step by step. It makes the game more balanced in terms of pace. However, there's one questionable decision, which made my first dozen hours in the game a bit frustrating. You must reach a certain point in the story to unlock talents required to customize your build and grant additional effects to your spells, potions, etc. This mechanic is fundamental for a game like this. However, it's, for some reason, locked behind 5-10 hours of gameplay, depending on difficulty and how distracted you will be by some side activities. Of course, you can speedrun the story until a particular moment to gain access to your talents and then play and explore comfortably. Still, if you're playing for the first time, you're most likely unaware of how long it will take you to unlock the actual leveling up, and without talents, your combat and exploration options are pretty limited. Craft, another crucial gameplay element, is hidden even further behind multiple side quests. This decision is justified from the story perspective but still seems questionable gameplaywise. Speaking of combat. Overall I found it fun and engaging, not to mention each encounter looks spectacular due to the variety of spells and other ways to fight your enemies. The game allows you to wield all the most well-known conjures from books and movies, even unforgivable ones, which you can use in combat, exploration, and puzzle-solving. However, I found battles rather exhausting than fun until halfway through the main story due to a limited arsenal. Only after I unlocked most of the spells and upgraded them did the combat finally shine. Regarding exploration and the open world,  is fantastic, especially if you're a Harry Potter fan like I used to be years ago. The devs nailed it with good attention to the details while recreating the magical world we used to know only through books and movies, especially in Hogwarts castle. I guarantee you will spend hours exploring only the school itself, not to mention Hogsmead and dozens of small hamlets, caves, and tombs. Some locations are breathtaking, which makes the lack of photo mode a considerable downside. However, after a certain point, when you'll explore enough and the sense of discovery becomes dull, you will most likely see that it's nothing more than an average AAA open world with question marks and bandit camps, with challenges and puzzles more suitable for an MMO rather than a single-player game. Still, there were enough moments throughout the game, no spoilers, which were done so well in terms of atmosphere and immersion that it ultimately outweighed all the secondariness of the surrounding activities. From the technical side,  is far from perfect. I experienced constant fps drops and stuttering here and there while my rig was more than decent to run the game with the settings I used. Facial animations are weird outside of pre-rendered cutscenes, and most of the dialogues are just talking heads with occasional gesticulation. However, overall,  looks beautiful, primarily because of design, attention to detail, and visual style rather than graphics quality.In my book,  is a great game. I admire how devs recreated the wizarding world and used every advantage of the setting beloved by millions to create a massive interactive experience, which, despite being rough around the edges, is good enough to stand in line with the genre's best.

author: Smiley1715x

author: Kazzy | Team K4L
review: Incredible, absolutely incredible. One of the best open world games I've played since TW3 and RDR2 and honestly, one of the best games I've played in recent time. As a BIG HP fan, this was everything that I wanted for proper full fledged open world RPG HP game. Fully immersive, attention to detail is incredible, gripping story, lovable characters etc.. Avalanche absolutely hit the nail with everything in the wizarding world and went above and beyond! Missing Quidditch and not being able to freely visit Azkaban was a HUGE missed opportunity thought and I wasn't happy about that but hopefully in the future we'd be able to experience those in a sequel or DLC.Performance wise it was great, the BIGGEST issue I had was the constant FPS dips when visiting certain areas such as Hogsmede or certain areas in the castle. No crashes or anything else on my end aside from those FPS dips which definitely need tweaking. After finishing the game I honestly feel sad the adventure is over. It makes me want a sequel even more and I'm certain the amount of money the game has made already is already swaying WB to get Avalanche prepped up for a sequel and I'm absolutely down for it and in full support!

author: Eve 2.0
review: Great as a story driven game, horrible as an open world game.A big world filled with so many repetitive things.Every cave is built practically the same way, 1-2 chests, 0-1 basic puzzles, 0-2 enemies and the loot inside is usually useless. They're bland, boring and pointless. Over 50 of themMerlin trials. Boring extremely simple puzzles just to increase your gear capacity. A whole 95 of them.Dungeons are just there only for side quests, no point in exploring them beforehand. There's only a few anyway.Camps are there so you can kill a few enemies and not die of boredom while roaming. And for collectibles.Collection is just a chore with no real reward unless you enjoy decorations.Money is purely for buying spellcrafts/seeds at first, after that there is no use for money. All gear sold by merchants is useless, all materials can be obtained in the room of requirement for free of charge. All potions can be made for free.Thank god for fast travel and brooms.Anyway 11/10, I like the combat.

author: ♿The Merker
review: I’m actually lost for words describing this game. The whole concept of becoming a witch/wizard, exploring not only hogwarts (which is HUGE), but a whole map of various places, is nostalgia central for fans who grew up with Harry Potter, and so beautifully interesting for those that haven’t. I’ve read the bad reviews on this game and they’re honestly complaining about the smallest things! Sure, there’s a few bugs. They can be fixed with update releases from creators. Sure, the voices aren’t what was expected - but I’ve definitely heard worse and it absolutely does not ruin the allure of Hogwarts Legacy. The visuals are STUNNING. The game is HUGE and SO versatile; it’s an open world RPG with great combat, a variety of items to collect (no, it’s not repetitive - each item has their own way of appearing and some you have to actually go and search for with little or no hints), there’s treasure maps, flying on brooms and mounts, pet collecting, potion making, base building (to an extent), secrets to discover without being told where they are, there’s honestly SO much to do! The story line is intriguing and I’m so glad they didn’t just make another Harry Potter game! If you’re a fan of fantasy RPGs that’s enough for you to try this game out for yourself, hats off to the creators.

author: MirusBhergh
review: I must be too old for this game. I've heard nothing but rave reviews, but on the whole, the combat just doesn't work for me. Telegraphs overlap, leading to impossible situations, Enemies teleport across the battlefield for no discernible reason. Many times I can't solve a puzzle because spells don't work the way I imagine that they would work, but rather there's a static solution that I need to do. The character won't jump up 2 feet if it's not the solution to the puzzle, but they can jump 15 feet to climb a wall if it is the solution. Stealth is useless about 50% of the time, which would be great if I could just respec out of that talent tree, but I can't respec talents without starting over.

author: GOMENASORRY
review: edit: holy sh*t this review is waaay too long. I won't be writing any reviews as long as this anymore.~TLDR; 7.5/10 game, amazing graphics, stunning world, beautiful details, passable story for the most part until the end where it falls a little flat. Not many choices to be made in dialogue and the combat is the best part of the game imo.~Game of the Year? Not really, kind of far from it actually. A damn good game for Harry Potter enthusiasts and the adventuring sort alike? A must play for sure.I'm in an odd category when it comes to the Harry Potter franchise. I've never once shown any interest in Harry Potter in the past despite my love for anything remotely high-fantasy (magic, dungeons and dragons, knights, orcs and whatever). As someone who's been looking for a breathtaking open world to get immersed into and lose myself in a world full of magic and mystery, this game almost hits that spot.Unfortunately, this game is one of those games that gives you the illusion of choice. A lot of the dialogue gets routed back to a set script and there's only about 3-4 choices I can think off the top of my head that actually matter to some extent. The rest is there for your character to say what is essentially the same thing differently (at least for the vast majority of the main quests. Some of the side quests might actually have some impact with different dialogue but I wouldn't hold my breath).Easily the best part of the game in my opinion is the combat. When you start learning more and more spells, you slowly come to the realisation that in a 1v1 scenario with any normal enemy, you will NEVER lose. You can infinitely juggle an enemy to oblivion and different spells interact wonderfully with each other. Need to throw your Incendio at the enemy you're juggling but they're flown too far? Just throw an Accio their way and they're suddenly in range for a full force of fire. Want to lift someone in the air, slow their momentum to a halt then slam their face into the ground? Leviosa, Arresto Momentum and Descendo will do the trick.The fun in combat doesn't end there, however. There are actually multiple ways of killing specific enemies that aren't just hitting it until it's dead. When a Dugbog's about to lash it's tongue out at you, you can actually cast Leviosa on it’s tongue and leave it hanging or cast the severing spell Diffindo to cut it, dealing significant damage. You can also cut a few enemy’s charging spells short by either disarming them with Expelliarmus or a quick Depulso and the spells will blow up in their faces, killing them instantly. Trolls have an overhead attack that can be parried OR you can block/dodge it and Flipendo the club back to its face, giving you ample opportunity to deal massive damage. The normal combat is fun and engaging by itself but the gameplay is elevated by experimenting and playing around with different spells for different enemies. You’re rewarded for your time and knowledge mid-combat with satisfying kills and interesting ways to manipulate the battlefield. I got the game 85% for the combat and it most definitely delivered.Of course, the game has its glaring flaws. The story is honestly quite lackluster for the latter part. As I was enjoying the world for the first few hours, experimenting with new spells and taking in sights I’d never seen before, the story was a nice vehicle to get me to my next destination/spell. Again, as someone with zero knowledge on Harry Potter and its universe, I was immersing myself quite handily for the first half of the game, learning things I’d never even heard or seen of before. Once you start to learn more about the world and familiarise yourself with the setting, however, the lack of choice in dialogue starts to wear itself thin. I was also excited to live a life as any student would in Hogwarts but your unique circumstances in the setting makes you feel less like a student and more of a vigilante who seeks out crime and punishes evil doers (and maybe attends school every now and then). It’s fun, exciting and certainly cinematic but you only really feel like a student for the first part of the game, where your worries are little and the stakes aren’t so in your face. You only visit each class maybe once or twice, learn a new spell then never do anything there for the rest of the game aside from gathering Field Guide pages (collectables). Despite all this, I’d still give this game a 7.5-8/10. It’s got a lot of charm in its world building and the tiny details honestly make up a lot of the overall score here. It’s rare to see a game polish their open world, decorations and small details to such an extent and it helped my immersion a lot for a good majority of the game. Seeing each different house get their own common room that you can explore (with a character in that same house, mind you) and have their own sidequests is such a treat. Hell, you can visit Azkaban for a short time if you pick the right house.At the time of writing this review, I’m level 34 and completed 67% of the challenges which I plan to turn into 100%. We’ll see if my rating of the game changes by then.~SPOILER: There is an additional scene for the main story that I see as a mini-epilogue. However, I learnt that you can only access this scene at level 34, which is ironically enough the level I was at when I defeated the final boss (I did a lot of exploring and sidequesting beforehand). So, the momentum from the final boss into this additional scene wasn’t lost and I was somewhat satisfied. However, I can imagine this scene falling a little flat if you aren’t level 34 by the time you get there and you have to grind out levels just to see a cutscene that didn’t really deliver an awful lot on its own. Not entirely sure why it’s level locked but it is what it is.

author: [FRD]Foxtrot
review: Regret buying this game for such a hefty price. Though the environment and graphics are good, it is just "lifeless", it should be renamed to *"Sebastian's Legacy"* instead, as it was the only questline that made me play this game till the very end.For example (and with minimal spoilers) - Your character and "someone" else is running out of a place that is collapsing. They find something and instead of rushing, they just stand there. Looking dead in the face and hands clasped, they start talking about life instead of running!And the performance, OH MY GOD this is a stutter simulator (RTX 3060ti + R5 3600). I believe developers/testers just run stuff on flagships and don't even bother testing it even on recommended hardware.It might be good for the fanboys who adore Harry Potter, but not for everyone else like me. It is just too early to hail this as a GOTY and I would really love to see a better game than this one to sit on the 2023 GOTY throne, not out of hatred for this game, but the throne deserves something better and much more polished than this.6/10 - Not worth the price.If this is the GOTY, gaming is dead. I will leave gaming altogether.

review: 2023 Started with a little magic, for Harry Potter fans and RPGs enthusiasts this game ticks a lot of boxes. The game is not perfect but its a very good game.Combat is quite enjoyable, at lease on the hard difficulty there is some challenge and also the unique spell interactions with each other and also enemy type makes the combat very fun and more strategic.From a story point of view the writing is good and got me invested in the story but there were a lot of instance where it could have been better.As for performance, I had instances where there was staggering and also sometimes characters, mainly professor Fig, gets pixilated and stays that way even after restart which was quite odd.The world is beautiful, not Elden Ring beautiful but its close. However, Hogwards castle is nearly perfect, when exploring you feel how much work was put into its recreation and is very very close to the books and movies.To conclude, I really like the game and it surely is the best Harry potter related Game in existence (although in the recent years there wasn't any completion)  and its also a very solid RPG, would recommend.Edit: Review submitted after 100% completion with all Steam Achievements

review: I highly recommend this game. What a wonderful escape to a world of fantasy and adventure. This is the most fun I have had with a game in a long time. The story, the adventure, the action, the combat, and all the little tid-bits and nuggets of lore bring it all together so well. The main story was interesting and I liked how the side stories interlinked and lived in the same world with the main story rather than being almost totally disconnected as in so many other games.The combat was fun and varied especially once more spells open up - plus the fact there are multiple ways to go about it. (spells, potions, plants, throwables like barrels, etc)Overall I felt like I was really in the Harry-Potter universe and I can only give thanks and congratulations to the developers for such a rich game world.Cheers - have fun.

author: Sacred
review: Really good, lots of good screenshot potential here, especially around Hogwarts, which has been beautifully recreated, the castle looks incredible, and the neighbouring villages have their own 'Cozy' personality as well. However, this game does suffer from open world syndrome, apart from the castle and villages the landscape isn't that enticing, mostly just hills and trees, the usual open world stuff, it all looks really good, just not exciting.Great, the spells all sound how you would expect them to sound and the explosions sound nice and heavy. The voice acting is pretty good here as well, especially with some of the goblins, there are however some repetitive voice lines that your character will repeat many times throughout your playthrough that get old quickly.The story is alright, It's pretty standard but engaging enough to keep you going, the game really shines through on some of the character side stories, specifically Sebastian and Poppy. I hope in the future we get more questlines like these two, they really display the creativity of the Hogwarts universe, interesting relics, spells, creatures, and relations.The gameplay here is solid, but is let down by some interesting systems. First off, the combat feels great, combing spells is fun and there is lots of room for mixing and matching, unfortunately the number of enemies is limited and the number of unique bosses even more so. The levelling in this game is okay at lower levels, but gets weird towards the end, you ONLY get exp through challenges, so after killing 100 spiders you will never get exp from killing a spider ever again, this means it's time to go collect some scrolls and do other open world stuff if you want to level up. If you want level 40 gear, then you need to max your collections. I'm not sure how I feel about this, I like the idea, but perhaps it could be tuned in the future.The open world activities are mostly pretty good, but it does feel like they ran out of time or ideas and just stared slapping merlin trials all over the place, I think you only needed 40 to finish the collection challenges, but there are a total of 95 in the world. Every time you finish a trial, you need to watch an 11-second cutscene, doing all 95 would equate to around 17 minutes of cutscene time, I will never know how this made it through testing, and to rub it in, the trials get old, and repetitive, after the first 10-15.   *pretty good story*Unique combat that is fun to master*Great audio*beautiful world*Some top tier sidequests*Default controller broom controls are awful*Weird levelling system*Too many merlin trials*Small enemy and boss variety Overall, I think the game is worth your money if you like open world games or the Harry Potter series. If you're not in that boat, then I would wait for a discount. Hogwarts and the villages look fantastic, the open world looks good but is pretty standard. The story is interesting enough to keep you engaged, levelling is broken towards the endgame   The game is worth your time, not bad, not amazing

Overall its  recommend buying at full price game!

author: JMP
review: Okay so I'm at 109 hours ... I've managed to complete all in game content and achieved all of the achievements.My honest review is, besides the occasional glitch/bug i.e: loot being under the floor, NPC's / Quest givers not showing up when they should be, the player clipping to objects they shouldn't etc this game runs smoothly and performs like a dream. The graphics are beyond anything i could have hoped for and goes a long way to really immersing you into this wizarding world. For me growing up with both the Harry Potter films and books, this game has brought a lot of my childhood dreams alive. I only hope they continue to work on this game, bringing out more content in the form of DLC and or a multiplayer mode to summarise my experience with this game i only need one word OUTSTANDING! i would 100% Recommend this game.

author: Abjurae
review: Very detailed world design that makes the setting come alive, combat is much more fun than the generic systems might leave on first impression because the way spells combo off each other and the enemy and environmental design give the player many opportunities to use their kit in unique ways. Some of these aren't the most innovative (color matching spell types with different colored enemy shields) but others are more interesting (destroying a platform enemies are standing on so that they fall to their deaths, then repairing it to cross yourself, disarming an enemy while they charge a spell so that it backfires, transforming an enemy into an explosive barrel and then throwing it at another).The attention to detail keeps the core gameplay pretty fresh all the way through the main story, though it can get a little stale if you decide to go for 100% completion.

author: eternal
review: Great gameplay, graphics and soundtrack. 8/10 Worth to buy.Apart from the PC performance issues on launch, good optimisation.It's super fun to makeup your own combos and jiggle your enemies in the air, push them off the cliffs or into voids, throw explosive barrels or even turn enemies into explosive barrel and then throw them into their friends.Traversing open world  feels smooth and fun on the broom, hippogrif, graphorn or even on foot. The world is beautiful and feels alive.The "companion" relationship quests are nice, sad you are not able to play with them all the time as they bring uniqueness which some of the quests lack. Being able to catch your own beasts and nurture them is very unique and brings a lot of fun to the gameplay.The gear system is uninspired but it gets the job done. You get your defence, offence stats and some minor boosts to your spells and defences.Story wise, I didn't yawn but I wasn't amazed either. It works, it takes you through the world and has interesting plot twists even if predictable sometimes. Side quests were fine, you have couple go to point A and comeback to point B. They are couple minutes long so it doesn't get boring. Others like mentioned are more in depth and bring joy as the "companions" are quite fun to listen to and watch their reactions. All together Hogwarts Legacy brings a surprise to 2023. After finishing the first Harry Potter games decades ago Hogwarts Legacy was able to bring back the joy, nostalgia and that feel of being lost in a wizard world almost perfectly.

review: This Game is Awesome! You don't even have to be into Harry Potter to enjoy it. The fact that the characters that everyone knows and loves are not in this game make it so much better. There's nothing to distract the player from themselves, you are the most important character in the this world.Gameplay: Fun and Intense - when you start out, just learned a few spells, don't quite have the controls down yet, its a nice challenge to play. The game becomes much more fulfilling to play when you start mastering combos, You feel powerful and its a very satisfying feeling.There are tons of secrets and farming style aspects to sink your teeth into, Stability: Great! Great average fps. I have some frame drops in heavily populated areas but they mostly smooth out. RTX on, mostly High/Ultra settings 5120x1440I had to remap my bindings to fit with how I have my mouse buttons set up for other games. I broke wingardium leviosa. I cannot turn items, up down is fine but further closer and side to side do nothing. I've had no other glitches worth talking about.It would be Silly of them to NOT make this an MMO or at least CO-OP in the future, its the perfect IP to play with your friends.

author: Cheesy
review: It's clear that Avalanche have put a lot of time and effort into making Hogwarts Castle very faithful to the source material. Exploring Hogwarts was an awesome experience, spamming Revelio every 5 seconds, the game encourages the player to explore Hogwarts, unlocking “You wouldn’t believe how inconvenient travel was before I invented Floo Powder!” (pls be quiet) allowing for the use of fast travelling, it just doesn't get old and I still keep bumping into corridors that eluded me, still finding new things. Besides the castle, the open world is absolutely stunnning. The world is pretty big, a lot of puzzles to be solved, caves to be explored, enemies to be culled and people to be helped. Each village you run into is never the same, somehow different each time, it never felt like a repeat of the previous village.I played on Normal difficulty to just test the waters, I must say the game isn't difficult, rather relatively Easy even after switching to Hard thinking that it would pose more of a challenge. I found myself always full on Potions and Plants, the combat is satisfying, finding and choosing spells that synergises with each other well allowing you to min max your combo's. Parrying and Dodging attacks are very easy to perform, as the game give you an indicator on whether to parry or dodge. There isn't much else to build your character, unless upgrading and putting traits on all your gear, nothing too ground breaking.The story is alright nothing too extravagant, you learn that your character can see traces of ancient magic which leads you on a path to pursue this calling, however there's a faction of goblins and their leader who are after the same thing, the knowledge of great magic that's only rumored to exist, very few people in the past knew of its existence and could wield it. The game presents sense of urgency while also intentionally slowing you down, but you can argue it is doing so for you to slowly master this magic and uncover the whole truth.Side-Quests, you have the usual fetch quests most of the time, which is carried by the setting of the world that made doing them interesting. I never felt annoyed doing a side quest that was simply "deliver" or "find and bring" as it had led me to discover new places each time, and again was carried by the setting of the world.Some Side-Quests are more convoluted and eventually lead you to what could be described as collectible chains. The game slowly introduces collectibles and series of puzzles for you to complete through side quests and it kind of feels natural. Though it sucked when a few collectibles were locked behind spells that you get through the main quests such as 'Alohomora'.Flying is pretty fun, screw fast travelling, though it feels slow for how big the map is (Yes I know you can upgrade your broom to go faster). Game places very few restrictions on where you can and can't fly, practically the whole world is traversable on a mount.Room of Requirement, very easily customisable, design the room however you want, and by exploring you can find more decor. One of the coolest things in the Room of Requirements is to be able to groom, feed and breed the many different beasts in the game.Beast catching, I found the best way to make money was to poach, sorry not sorry. I did keep a few beast in my Room of Requirements but all those Puffskeins, thanks for funding all the upgrades I ever needed. There are many types of beasts to catch and bring to the RoR out there in the world, some are easy to catch and some are harder.3 Game slots even though there's 4 houses? lolVoice pitch, yea dunno why it's a feature, just leave on default if you don't want your character to sound like an echoey robot.I recommend this if you like open world and action RPG games, a lot of things to find enjoyment in the game. This game isn't just for Harry Potter fans, but for everyone, this game is pretty much a HP Fan's wet dream, the game's not perfect, but still a good game nonetheless.

review: The amount of content within this game is indeed worth the pricing it's listed as, I've already spent hours upon hours exploring the world in and around Hogwarts. There's only a few things that are missing imho, I.E.: becoming an animagus, a great number of spells that I have read about in Pottermore Lore, and Quidditch, but I'm sure those things will be added in the future with the inclusion of DLCs, at least that is my hope. I look forward to playing this more and more, since I will continue to have fun with it. Thank you Avalanche, and WB for all your hard work, and continued hard work.

author: Incredibly average
review: It's pretty good! I've seen a bit of most things this game offers and I can already tell it's well worth playing this title. It leans pretty heavily into both being "experience" and a little less on "gameplay", but does both at least decently well. This game must have also been a dream come true for technical artists. Magic means lots of pretty shaders. I can't judge the accuracy of the universe much because even though I did read some of the books, I'm not big into the franchise.The world is this very whimsical place where everyone is either really courteous or not - and in case the latter that usually hints at there being slightly more depth to them. It's a common trope in both the books and films, so I guess that translates well. The personalities are also accompanied by recognizable motifs to further enhance that feeling of being in this quirky yet mostly lovable wonderland. It does cut into more mature themes enough to cause tension.Graphically speaking the game looks good. It didn't blow me away however. The facial animations are good, but a little robotic at times. The animation blending often causes some really weird looking results as well. The environmental design is where Hogwarts Legacy really shines. The amount of detail found in the world are great - with little useless animations for various misc objects. I'd describe it as very ambitious but not groundbreaking in any way. Sound design is great. Implementation of spatial sounds seems good (even though audio is not often my main concern). The music is appropriate.Gameplay wise the game has some issues but does make a real attempt at being something noteworthy. It just doesn't quite reach in my opinion. The flow of the gameplay is fairly simple: you chain together spells according to the opponent's current weakness, while deflecting or avoiding incoming fire. The color coding is excellent (finally!) and the game does clearly visually convey what the challenge is. Parry options are clearly highlighted, and thus fix my number one concern with the Soulslikes; a tremendous amount of visual ambiguity that can only be combated with excessive experience. Unfortunately the game doesn't always flow perfectly and struggles with the camera at times. Actively aiming circumvents the need to auto-lock, but is extremely cumbersome to use. Auto-lock comes with your usual issues like different objects obscuring one another. The auto-lock is also very visually unclear, showing only a small white outline. This is unfortunate as the rest of the game does such a good job at communicating its intent. Swapping between spells also feels like it could have been done better. Of course being able to use 4 spells at a time is completely reasonable; any more and the game would become very difficult, or at least carpal tunnel inducing to play for KBM. I think swapping between the sets could have been streamlined a bit more however; perhaps with a circular wheel rather than another button. I'd save on three potential button presses.Combat itself also suffers being a little to static in my opinion. All fights I have encountered so far are a matter of "repeat the same thing until you win". Now there is quite a bit to unpack: the idea is to chain spells according to their inherent combos (casting the same spell), stun recovery and range - with some additional gimmicks later as I've heard. But once you get the routine down it kind of just repeats itself.My main gripe with the gameplay is the camera: there is absolutely no reason this game is third person from a design perspective. The only justification would be to show all the fancy animations. There is no cover mechanic involved and it adds nothing to the already boring stealth sections either. Unfortunately the result is Hogwarts legacy suffering the common problems associated with this camera: it often obscures your view by intersecting with geometry and makes things harder to read because your own character is constantly in the way. This hurts the game too, because I have already gotten hit several times because I couldn't see the parry indicator as it was obscured by terrain.Overall I can pretty confidently recommend Hogwart's Legacy - even though it did not wow me. It's certainly not on par with Elden Ring for example, but then again the target audiences are probably quite different anyway.

author: Plaidygami
review: I think it's worth full price, but if you're hesitant, you can get it on discounts through various retailers, or just wait for a sale. I will update my review later as I see fit, based on how I feel the more I play this game.🎮 --------------------------------Hogwarts Legacy is an open-world RPG. Similar to other games of the genre, you do things to gain exp and level up, which unlocks which areas you can go to, or which gear you can equip, etc.You've got the main story missions, as well as side quests, treasure puzzles, collectable items, and more. You can also ride your broom and have a pet of sorts. You can craft potions and learn recipes, and you can explore and find points of interest. There are collections that you fill out, like a fantasy version of a Pokedex, including receiving rewards, usually cosmetics that you can apply to your gear.Character creation is pretty nifty. It's not as customizable as some other games, but still enough that you can make your character look like you.🎵 --------------------------------The game sounds beautiful. The music is well-orchestrated, sound effects are well-designed, and the is fully voiced. Speaking of which, the voice acting is top notch for most characters (only a couple here and there that seemed a little bit off).⚔️ --------------------------------There are several difficulty levels you can choose from. I went with Normal, which feels well-balanced to me. If you want more of a challenge, you can really crank it up, and if you want to focus on story and exploration, you can definitely lower it quite a lot.📖 --------------------------------So far, the story feels like a standard fantasy story - main character is intercepted by an evil entity for a mysterious reason, and now is working to become stronger and face that foe later in order to save the world. It's nothing special, but it's not terrible, either. It's been adapted for the Harry Potter universe, of course, but it's still pleasant.🖥️ --------------------------------Honestly, once the game-ready drivers dropped in, the game has become buttery smooth. I am running the game on ultra and FSR 2 turned to Quality, and my framerate is 100-144 fps on average. No stuttering of any sort. Very few areas with framerate drops, which will most likely improve with future updates.My main specs as a reference are:- AMD 5600X- Sapphire Pulse 6800 XT- 32 GB 3600 Mhz RAM🏞️ --------------------------------This game is beautiful. It's not hyper-realistic, but it's more than realistic enough that it feels immersive. You can see the texture of the materials, and the skin blemishes. And the animations feel realistic as well. They're not janky or awkward. The studio did a fantastic job working on making the world look and feel alive.🪲 --------------------------------This game just recently came out, so there are a few minor bugs here and there, and maybe a rare crash when it compiles the shaders at the start. There will be plenty of updates and patches to take care of any bugs and issues.

author: bananas
review: There are things this game is, and there are things this game is not.This game is not a proper RPG, it doesn't feature interesting dialogue choices, a branching storyline, or different endings based in your decisions throught the game. The "RPG mechanics" such as character stats, upgrading/enchanting gear, crafting, trading, exploring, etc are very VERY basic and uninteresting. Combat is ok, it is better than what I thought It would be (tbh, when I first saw the trailers I thought the combat was going to be trash) but it is  very easy even in the highest difficulty. This game is clearly meant for casual players, it is constantly handholding you, telling you where to go next and displaying markers for everything. So if you expect a challenging game or a fleshed out RPG experience you will get kinda disappointed.What this game is, is a Harry Potter simulator/fantasy, and it is very good at being just that. You play as a "chosen one" type character, a Hogwarts student that has innate powers no one else has, and who's quest is to save the world against the impending forces of evil, of course. Never seen that one before.What this game really excels at is in its world design and art direction. Hogwarts and Hogsmead are really well done, with tons of very neat details and references to the source material. You really feel as if you are there, exploring in the HP universe. Sadly, this level of detail and nuance doesn't really exist outside the two aforementioned areas. The rest of the world is awfully generic and boring. The "dungeons" (apart from the ones you go for the main questline) are just empty caves with a chest, and the enemy roster is pretty lacking.The open world is one of those "collection checklist" type of worlds, with a lot of collectibles and repeating puzzles.If this game was not set up in the HP universe I would probably not recommend it. However, as it is, it is the ultimate Harry Potter fantasy game. It brings to life the magic of the HP world in a way no other game does, and for that, I recommend it. In truth, there are a lot of fun things to distract yourself with, like exploring Hogwarts Castle and discovering its secrets, capturing and collecting beasts, decorating your room, or just flying around with your broom.It is a fun game and it does really well what is supposed to do, which is bringing to life the HP world. No quidditch thou.I would give it a 8/10.

author: Yaoyao ♥
review: It's marketed as an open-world RPG but it's really not. Exploration is highly repetitive and the combat/gear/progression systems are not well-designed. There's also not much room for personalisation, no morality system and none of the dialogue choices actually matter, so as a result you can't really relate much with the main character throughout. In a nutshell, it delivers the basics of what is expected of a game set in the HP universe, but there's a lot of wasted potential as an open world RPG. If there's going to be a sequel to this, I hope it can be developed by a studio who's more experienced in designing RPGs.

author: JoOngle
review: Hogwarts Legacy is going to be legendary, and this is why:Many people who have reviewed this game after 2-5 hours gameplay are missing the incredible changes in the game, I will not spoil it here, but I can tell you it's full of surprises, you're going to see "Demoscene" like experiences in this game (look that up if  you don't know what Demoscene stuff is), it's like this world of graphical effects and splendor to a degree you don't expect in regular AAA games.I'll be short, because the game is just too big:- Endless amounts of side quests and dialogue.- The graphics can be amazing at times.- Full of surprises, once you think you saw it all after a few hours, it all changes.- Pretty decent stories, it captivates you enough to want to continue the next day.- Lots of little hidden secrets.- Big complex experience system, you can chose the direction of your focus.- Long lasting game, sure you can run through it in 20 hours, but you'll miss out on 90 percent of the game, so expect 100s of hours here. I'm in the 30th hour so far, and 29% complete, and I think I did everything pretty darn fast.- Very forgiving if you just follow the story, you can literally press random combos and not know the first thing about it and you can still succeed.- The game can be a little dull and tedious in the beginning.- Lots of stuff to remember and learn, if you're not keen on 100+ different combos to learn, this can be quite daunting and exhausting.- The menu system can be utterly confusing, it's pretty obvious it was made for a controller and not foremost a keyboard, this can be super frustrating, it took me hours into the game realizing I need to press "G" to use the healing potions, and it took me even longer to understand the value of upgrading clothes with the loom.- If you're suffering from a bit of misophonia like me, then the repetitive music can be annoying in the long run.- The dialogue CAN be a little bit of a long stretch for impatient people, you know that friend you have that goes ON and ON about the LEAST interesting things in life, well - there's a lot of those here, and just like real life there's no SKIP button for that. If your keyboard comes with a "" function, then USE IT! You're gonna find yourself in a hectic spider battle randomly switching spell menues while franticly pressing 1,2,3 and 4, Q, R and mouse clicking aka bullet-hell, so during the heat of the battle, you will no doubt encounter your windows menu helping your enemies to defeat you. Other than that, this is the game your friends will be talking about the next 14 days, and then it's gonna be legendary. You need a ton of patience, good memory, lots and lots of energy, finger muscles and you def. need to stop talking about this game to your friends if you want to keep them.
