author: impressively large hero pool
review: I don't really play RPGs anymore but this one got me so hooked!I think it's a great example of what 'open world' should be. Doesn't feel grindy or tedious, and it makes you actually want to seek out these things in the open.I completed the main story at 80 hours because I was enjoying just living in it; Tending to my plants, caring for my beasts, talking to people, interacting with everything in the environment, and just zooming around on my 600g broomstick.I think the combat is very fun and enjoyable. And a lot of the puzzles were challenging but fun.The story is engaging and the music is phenomenal!The main (actual) critics of the game I've seen are the stuttering and the depth of the story/characters.Personally, I tuned everything down to Medium settings and have had no performance issues, and the game still looked great.And I believe the depth of the story was designed in such a way so that it is enough to guide you through a narrative, but whilst also letting you inject your own story and personality into it. Allow you to make the story yours. So I appreciated that.If you like open world RPGs, this is a pretty good pick up.If you are a HP fan, then this is a must have. I wouldn't be surprised if this is GOTY.I can't wait for the DLCs.9/10

author: games33
review: + Great graphics (even on low quality)+ Great story+ Perfect amount of grindability, without it being a chore+ Several ways to get ur eco going to buy them looties (or to craft it)+ Great cosmetic system where you can have the stats of piece A and the looks of piece B+ Being able to collect cute creatues+ The world really feels alive. Some AAA games have this massive open world, but it doesn't really feel like people live there+ Different kinds of enemies to fight+ The fun interactives with your classmates from different houses and teachers- The sorting ceremony feels cheap- Choosing your want doesn't feel as special. Change the length or wood material doesn't seem to do anything - Shamefully no co-op (which if fair for a single player game)- No quidditch- Catching several creatures is cool, but it does feel a bit underwhelming, especially with the last quest (would love to have 1 massive creature like a thunderbird. Would be cooler to fly on than a hippogrif/thestral)- Flying on mounts doesn't feel that special compared to a broom- Is there even a point system in play for you to get point for your house?- Story choices don't matter that much. Just be a dck and go for money, ending doesn't change.8/10 would recommendGame of the year material

author: Parallax
review: This is a message to everyone involved in making this game, be it as Software Developer, a Writer or just simply as the coffee guy...thank you!Thank you for recreating what can only be described as a childhood dream for many of us! author: Miri
review: Finally a game that doesn't make me hate the main character right from the start and through the whole experience. In my opinion Hogwarts Legacy is a game of the year contender because you can feel, see and hear the efforts that went into it at ever corner. So much love for detail!The castle is just magnificent. As a child I always dreamed of going to Hogwarts and played all the "old" Harry Potter games of the time. It can't be described how awesome the castle is, it needs to be experienced.The surrounding areas are just as amazing, the love to detail is plain to see everywhere.The story is interesting and the devs truly managed to make sure, that the player never feels overwhelmed with quests or activities. The combat system is also to my liking but I know that this part is very different from player to player. It might help  that I am a Soulsgames veteran. Yesterday I took down a lvl 31 troll, with my character being lvl 23 :)I highly recommend the game. It feels finished, it feels polished, it feels like it was created with care and respect for the world it's set in. Thank you to developers! You did an amazing job and created a game that will give a lot of people a lot of joy.(english is not my mother language, excuse any errors please)

author: Quiet.
review: TLDR: Its good.Dont go into this game expecting it to be like a Hogwarts student sim.right off the bat you're a 5th year with more liberty to take than Bush Administration USA. mentally adjust your expectations for like, a less expansive but more detailed skyrim set in the wizarding world. once youve done that this game delivers on so many levels. when the side quests alone can keep you occupied for dozens of hours and never feel boring you know you have a deep game. main plot is interesting, again not what i expected but its a fresh enough take on old stories. theres plenty of lore so that diehard potter fans will appriciate it but its not so obscure that casuals cant enjoy. Combat can get a bit repetitive. also if you dont like spiders youre in for a bad time. but theres enough spell variety to keep it interesting. i wish they didnt limit you to 4 spells a hotbar on the PC version as it adds an annoying element to combat that does not need to exist for PC users.Suprisingly theres very few of the telltale signs that the game was unfinished on release. something thats very common these days with big releases. perhaps the brevity of lessons and the lack of quiddich. these probably got cut as deadlines loomed but in general the games still very fulfilling. Definately worth a buy if you can afford 70 bucks.

author: Marcy.
review: Honestly one of the best story game that's probably gonna come out this year, the story was actually really fun to play, I enjoyed this game and grinded it. I had a lot of fun, even though I lost my whole save 3 field guides away from finishing the game entirely... Anyways, The world was beautiful and being able to explore around it was honestly so fun, me being a big fan of the universe I'd give it a 10/10 just for how big and beautiful this game was, honestly worth it.

author: Rodingen
review: It is rare to see a game these days which seems complete at release. I looked forward to this game, but was wary of getting my hopes high; we all know how easy it is to be disappointed in games these days. So I was very happy that this game actually delivers.The world is as magical as you would want it to be; the experience of Hogwarts itself hits that book/movie itch which you remember, and just exploring the castle and finding the locations from the books and movies, sometimes with little small nods to HP events, is just what I wanted to see. But just as important, this game has its own story and characters, although you certainly recognize some family names.The soundtrack manages to be similar enough to the movies that it brings you into the world, although I think it's mainly the Hogwarts and Hogsmeade music that really make any impact. I enjoy the combat system, where you use different types of spells to hit combo bonuses and juggle many several opponents at once. While I am far from an expert, I do however think I will be trying out a higher difficulty level for the rest of my playthrough since I find myself exploring higher level areas too early and feeling like I shouldn't be able to. Once you get the hang of the spellcasting and upgrade some spells it does sometimes get a bit too easy.The various puzzles are entertaining at first, although they do get repetitive after a while. Luckily you can skip most of the challenges if you don't enjoy that part.The big thing I can see with this game, which I am already not looking forward to, is that I can't really see that much replayability. I was thinking that I would do one "good" and one "evil/less good" playthrough, but the only real difference I see so far is if I learn the three curses or not. Throughout the game you are often provided with dialogue options which are either "I'm a nice guy" or "I am selfish and mean", but there doesn't really seem to be any significant difference to what you choose to do. You are sometimes given the choice of doing something you are not supposed to, but there doesn't seem to be any lasting impact regardless of your choice.If, for example, I choose to help a student steal some supplies during class, it would have been interesting to see more impact than just getting scolded by the teacher. Maybe implement detentions? You can come across students getting punished, so why not you? It would make for some more immersive gameplay. Similarly, some quests have you sneaking around in the school at nighttime. You are reminded of the importance of avoiding detection while being out past curfew and while exploring forbidden parts of the school during the quest, but outside of quests you can walk around wherever you like without consequences. I would have liked it if you really had to sneak around school at nighttime, avoiding teachers, ghosts and prefects; something which would also have made it more exciting to find and collect some of the things you need to find around the school.So, I do recommend this game a lot. However, after finishing it, I do not think that I will be playing it again anytime soon if there aren't any major DLC or changes to it. But maybe that is okay; remember when games just came out, were played and enjoyed once, and then you just left it at that?Also: I know that the magical world has a strange sense of morality sometimes, but Deek, I do not think "rescue" means what you think it means.

author: Slayy
review: TL,DR: This game has everything, it's so good, cop it.Hogwarts Legacy is a game I've been sitting at the edge of my seat to get for the past few weeks, and am glad to say I have not been disappointed. The game features so many familiar aspects from the Hogwarts world, the castle, the magic, going to class, it's all so familiar and welcoming. But it continues into new territory not explored by the books or by the movies, through new characters, and unexplored landmarks of the wizarding world that have never been touched upon till now, mixing both the old with the new in an exciting new version of the Hogwarts universe.First and most enjoyable to me, the combat. The combat in the trailers looked diverse and incredibly fun and satisfying to use, and to my satisfaction, this is exactly the case within the game. You are able to string together combos, unlock powerful spells and then upgrade those powerful spells later through your connection to ancient magic, on top of using potions and plants to assist you in your rivalries. Pair that with the fact that you have ancient magic that is completely new and refreshing, making your character feel incredibly powerful and unique, you have an amazing combat system that never fails to impress with the countless combinations of spells you can encounter.Next, the open world. Another amazing part of Hogwarts Legacy that has not failed to deliver. The world around you is full of life, including the students that roam the halls and gossip about their daily lives, to the abstract and hilarious interactions you see between ghosts, and the countless enchantments on paintings, statues and armour around the school. You never feel bored or left without something to think about or be interested in, because Hogwarts is just so active. Once you head outside the castle walls, you see Hogwarts, and man, it's just like the books and the movies... HUGE! When outside and viewing Hogwarts from a distance the school is just as big and as beautiful as ever, which was a very important part to enjoying the game for me. Moving outside of school grounds there are many familiar locations including Hogsmead and the forbidden forest. The forbidden forest gives off the same scary and evil vibe from the movies and books, as well as Hogsmead giving the same vibe of comfort and happiness as well. To make the game even better, there are loads of places you explore that are entirely new areas to discover for the first time only within Hogwarts Legacy, just increasing the beauty of the Hogwarts universe.Lastly, the music and dialogue in this game are well done. The dialogue is rather straightforward and nothing to write home about. It isn't amazing, it isn't bad, it's just good. The music however has been cleverly done, as you hear the main important sounds from the movie's music, however in different notes and rhythm's, helping us be familiar with the sounds, however still different as the game is set in a completely different time.Overall, this game has been amazing so far while I have played it, and there are so many different aspects to explore and experience. All the experiences that you would want to have at Hogwarts, from flying on a broom right outside Hogwarts and taking in the amazing views, to demolishing foes in duelling battles, and sneaking around the restricted section of the library, Hogwarts Legacy has everything the movies and books had to offer, and more, and so with that being said I think it's pretty clear where I stand. Get this game, it's a must.

author: Mars
review: Phenomenal game. Stay away from the community at all costs. 90% of them are on two violent opposite sides of the political spectrum and they will both do whatever it takes to ruin this game and it's community. Play it how it was intended, as a single-player experience, do NOT go on the forums, you've been warned.As for the game, it's a great RPG! While it currently has some weird issues, like lack of skin tones for the main character, and sometimes odd frame dips that show the game might possibly have a memory leak, it's nowhere near as buggy as mostly any new AAA game in the last year. The characters are all very enjoyable, the combat is amazing, and the art design is absolutely insane. As for the graphics, they're very good, but don't be expecting the best looking game ever, it's made on UE4 which makes this very understandable considering the age of the engine.Overall 9/10 so far, aside from the issues I've listed, I really have no issue with how this game turned out. I'm very surprised this managed to be good despite the overwhelming amount of political extremists on both sides working against it, and shame on JKR for making the IP like this. It's definitely well worth the price.

author: Archer97
review: I read the Harry Potter books when I was 9 years old. They were one of the first book series that got me into reading and I've been a huge fan of them and the world of Harry Potter since. This game absolutely does the novels justice. Hogwarts and the surrounding areas are beautiful and alive. Being able to go around the school see, and experience all the things I read about as a kid makes me incredibly happy. I'm not very far in the story but what I have played has been immensely enjoyable. Bravo to the devs and studio who brought one of my favorite childhood fantasy worlds to life. P.S.  If you are struggling with frame drops in the game try turning off v-sync in game, exiting the game, and turning on v-sync in NVIDIA control panel. Then load back into the game and give it a minute to load everything. This was suggested by u/Happy_Hues on Reddit and it pretty much fixed the frame drop issue for me.

author: Elian
review: How to recover lost game data1. Go to your Desktop and press  WIN + R, a Run window will open, type %AppData%2. Navigate to C:\Users{YOUR COMPUTER USERNAME HERE}\AppData\Local\Hogwarts Legacy\Saved\SaveGames\ , you're going to see a folder with some numbers on it, press CTRL + X3. Go to your Desktop and press CTRL + V, this is going to paste your save folder to your Desktop. Open the folder.4. Look for your last autosave by paying attention to the "Date Modified" column, the autosave file you need should be around the same time of when the crash happened, it should be named HL-00-XX, press CTRL + C.5. Open Hogwarts Legacy and create a new character with the same name as your previously created character. VERY IMPORTANT!6. When you get to the first cutscene. Go back to C:\Users{YOUR COMPUTER USERNAME HERE}\AppData\Local\Hogwarts Legacy\Saved\SaveGames\ , except this time you're going to enter the folder with all the numbers, you're going to see a file called HL-00-XX, take note of this name and delete the file.7. Press CTRL + V, this is going to paste in your autosave file from your original game folder.8. Rename this autosave file with the same name of the file you deleted from Step 6.9. Go back to Hogwarts Legacy and press ALT + F4, once it closes, relaunch it.10. Load up Hogwarts Legacy, you should see the new character you created at level 1 at the main menu, click it and start the game.11. Once you load into the game, you should see that you're back to where you were at before the game crashed and corrupt your game!

author: ☥ Docdra ☥
review: First, game runs perfectly fine.  Not a single crash, no FPS issues, no game breaking bugs, no minor bugs so far either.Playing with "Ultra" settings on the following:Win 11 ProGPU:  RTX 4090RAM:  32 GB DDR5 6000 MHzCPU: i9-12900K (yeah, I know...)Installed on a NVME Gen 4 x 4 All of the manufactured controversy around this game is a bit of a distraction, but as someone that isn't a fan of the HP books and that only marginally liked the movies, I'm more excited about having a quality RPG to play.  One professional reviewer trashed the game, but partway through his review he revealed his true intentions - trashing Rowling, someone I don't know enough about to care about.  She had no input into the game and other than getting her residuals, has no other involvement with it - so I could care less about her political views in relation to this game.  Now, enough of that...+  Game runs great, but from what I've seen mid-range systems seem to have the most issues+  No major bugs, crashes, or stuttering+  Whether or not you are an HP fan, the game draws you into the world+  The open world gameplay is nothing like Ubisoft's tired formula thankfully-  Seems to be some odd audio issues with my character's voice, an odd vibrato or echo+-  There are a LOT of unexplained things; usually doesn't bother me, but some things you may need to look up+-  Sometimes the voices don't seem to sync with the animation+-  Some voices (one in particular) don't match the character+-  The game doesn't really open up until more than 10 hours in, longer if you do side-questsIf you like RPGs that feature a magic casting in an open world fantasy setting, you're probably not going to get anything better than this in 2023.  Hopefully, they'll add expansions that are of the same quality that expand the story and world even more.I will say that even if this had a demo, two hours is nowhere near enough to determine if you'll like this or not.  The beginning of the game, before the world and all of your skills open up, is just that long.  So, if you want to try it, be aware of that fact.

review: My personal favorite game that can only be matched by Witcher 3. The game exploits well known mechanics like floo flames, which are very similar to towers in Assassin's Creed; points of interest of different kind, but the main difference from other games, here they've managed to reach exceptional quality. In each location, would it be the main castle, the forest, or any hamlet village outside, I could feel the vibes of Harry Potter movies and book series. Some emotions of sensation might be hard to express in words, so I recommend to try out Hogwarts Legacy and see it for yourself.

review: Great game, vast exploration, these developers really put in effort and it shows. This really is just about the greatest HP based game fans could ask for. author: Owlcoholic
review: I have not been this addicted to a game for a while!And just a note, I'm not even much of  Harry Potter fan. But the game is still great fun regardless.Positives:Hogwarts and the world itself are so detailed and fun to exploreFun combat system comboing spells togetherFluid and fun flyingSome characters have interesting and unique backgrounds and storiesGreat mix of established looks (and music) from the movies, mixed with some different takesA lot of customization when it comes to your outfit, and the room of requirementsLong game if you plan on doing a decent amount of side activitiesMay positives (things I enjoy but I know others may dislike):Huge worldA LOT of questsEnemy level scalingRandom lootSo much to do, easy to get distracted with side content and collectiblesNegatives:Some characters are quite 2 dimensionalLinear storyline (ie, no branching story paths, good/evil system)Occasionally drops to a low framerate for a few seconds, only happens every couple hours for meHogwarts is too empty at night, even the dorms are emptyIt feels like a nighttime curfew system may have been planned but ultimately scrapped, now it's only in a couple missionsOverall I'd give the game an 8.5/10, May change once I've actually finished it though, but for now I'm really enjoying it

author: Hahkobo Hwinskivak
review: Hogwarts Legacy is a magical and immersive journey into the wizarding world of Harry Potter. The combat is both challenging and enjoyable, providing a fresh experience that never grows tiresome. The graphics and attention to detail in creating the iconic world of Hogwarts and its surroundings are stunning, making the player feel as though they are truly exploring the castle and its grounds. The storyline is engaging and offers a new perspective on the familiar wizarding world. Overall, Hogwarts Legacy is a must play for Harry Potter fans and gamers alike, offering a truly enchanting experience.

author: VisualTaggy
review: Wow, where do I even begin with this game?! Hogwarts Legacy has completely exceeded my expectations and then some! The graphics are mind-blowing, and I felt like I was actually living in the wizarding world of Harry Potter. Every detail was so meticulously crafted, from the iconic castle to the intricate spell casting system.The gameplay is a perfect balance of action, exploration, and puzzle-solving, with each element complementing the others to create an unforgettable gaming experience. The story is gripping, with well-developed characters and a main storyline that will have you on the edge of your seat. And the character customization? Let me tell you, I've never felt so invested in my own avatar before. Choosing my Hogwarts house, wand, and personal story added a whole new level of immersion to the game.And let's not forget the side quests and activities! They added so much depth and replay value, I'm still discovering new things every time I play. I can't even imagine how much time I've spent in this world already, and I'm still not ready to leave.Now, I know there's been some controversy surrounding the game, but I'm here to tell you that it's completely unfounded. This game is a masterpiece, a true celebration of the Harry Potter universe and all its magic. If you're a fan of the franchise or just love action-adventure RPGs, you owe it to yourself to experience this game. It's an absolute must-play for anyone who's ever dreamed of attending Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry.In conclusion, I can't praise this game enough! I'm so grateful to have been a part of this journey, and I can't wait to see what other adventures await in the wizarding world. Thank you, Hogwarts Legacy, for the memories and the magic!

author: Crisis
review: So far it's a fun game, and  I am enjoying it a lot. the only thing I dislike a little is the limited inventory space and the potion brewing times. combat is fun even more so once you unlock more spells, and there are plenty of those. The game also has a lot of thigns to find, in and around hogwards So it's fun to explore around.However there are many collection quests type of things wich that are a bit overused and not as rewarding as the effort you put in to complete them.First you have the Mirrors (Paintings) that you reveal a location with a spell and you need to find to locationto find a bug and lead that bug back to the Mirror to complete it for a little xp.Then you have small statues you need to find for one of the professors to unlock the spell to unlock doors,You have 3 versions of that spell version 1 you get when you first do the quest but to unlock doors that require version 2 or 3 you need to have the upgaded spell it's worth doing it for. but it's really hard to find those statues. Then you have the merlin trail quests that are simple puzzles you complete for 80 XP, And they are all over the world. And a few more that I won't name but most of them play similarly. I believe there are atleast 2 more of those types of quests.The biggest problem I have with them is the rewards, they are at this point not worth the effort,but overall the game is all good fun, and you will get a lot of enjoyment in the combat and flying around.I do recommend this game for all those that are harry potter fans, there is a lot too see and to do. And it's well worth it. For me the game ran without any problems I am running the game on a 3090 all settings maxed out.After finishing the game.It's a good game with fun combat, but as an RPG is fails it's a liniar story with no real choices. that inpact the game as a whole,

author: Dovahkiin007
review: GOTY 2023LOVE IT 10/10 This game is a true dream for every Wizarding World fan, extremely Immersive and atmospheric, a dream come true. Performance-wise no complaints. Playing it at stable 80fps ULTRA and RTX enabled. Well worth the wait. The game exceeded my expectations 100%

author: raz3r
review: In Howgarts Legacy it's kinda of impossible not to smile at every corner. It's the little things, like a beautifully animated Quidditch model, Pix joking around or why not, just stopping by on your broom to awe at an an amazing view of the castle at dusk. It ain't a perfect game, but unless you are an unemotional husk it WILL make you happy. When you start getting old, sometimes you just want to feel like a child again And in an industry plagued by greedy practice it's good to know that we can still find magic in this medium.

author: Sir Noob Wulf
review: Hogwarts Legacy so far has been a no nonsense gaming experience, No MTX, No ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, Just a well made game.I was expecting to say something like "Its gonna be a good game in the HP universe" but no, This is just a good game. Avalanche games hit it out of the park in their first attempt.As for the performance, I have heard reports of issues that people were having, But I didn't have many issues outside some minor stuttering in hogsmeade and flying.I am playing on 1440p High with DLSS set to quality and textures on ultra. I have a 5700x and a 3060 and am playing on an SSD with 16 gb ram. So I am not the the common case here. Just because I don't have issues, Doesn't mean there are no issues. SO I would still say maybe find a benchmark for whatever hardware you own just to check the performance on it.And that's it for the written review. I am yet to finish the story and thus a full review will come later.And to any people who rhyme with AJ Bowlings are receiving some of the money from what I paid, May they choke on it.

author: Benji
review: Multi-combat was a fun experience where at the end of a fight I felt like a badass. Though it makes your fingers twist and turn doing some criss-cross-apple-sauce maneuvers on your keyboard, it made me feel like I was casting a spell with my hand. Combat is really straightforward and it teaches you early on, though there were moments where dodging and blocking incoming spells were happening so fast I found myself just dodging most of the time in the multi-combat situations till there were just a few enemies left. They are a large amount of variety when it comes to things you can fight, and best of all they all have unique ways of handling the fight. Weaknesses play a huge role in any fight you get yourself into, and exploiting your opponents weak points is such a fun thing to pull off in rapid succession.Playing through the story I really enjoyed myself and found the story captivating and wanting more. The characters in the story had an alright build up to them, though some can be forgettable shortly after meeting them. For myself there was a moment in the story where pure joy took hold of me so much that I felt like a kid again, giving me one of the best moments of my gaming history.The map is large and filled with so much life when wandering around in any part of the map. From the little things you do via story, side missions or even just exploration. The environments in the area were well done, everywhere I went I felt like it was a screenshot.Throughout the whole playtime you are faced with many types of puzzles, none that are excessively hard in fact quite easy. Though the variety of the puzzles was enjoyable.In this game there is so much to read that I found myself wanting to find more. For me this was the first time I really enjoyed reading lore pages and it made me want to search for more in between exploring and missions.Fantastic!!! The music track was wonderful and made the experience so much more! The sounds design for the spells, environment, creatures and atmosphere was just spectacular.In the 3 day early access playtime I had encountered 3 “bug/glitches” though some might not be harmful rather than funny. Falling through the map and dying (Once)Enemies spasming all over the place after being defeated as if they were team rocket blasting off again. (Harmless and goofy)During a story mission a character whom I was meant to follow was walking backwards and got stuck on a rock forcing me to reload a save to fix. (Once)Something that I found a bit annoying though not harmful was the constant repetitive talking when on a mount.Again some of the characters do feel forgotten or ignored.In one side quest I had chosen a “bad” option that upset them and later on that same character had thanked me for helping them.Hogwarts Legacy is fantastic experience in my eyes, once engrossed into the lore of the game it truly becomes magical! I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys this universe and to anyone who enjoys a good fantasy game!I would give this a 8.5 out of 10 At the time of this review!

author: Frostillicus
review: 7/10 Running around Hogwarts is exciting and nostalgic, it looks great as the seasons change and for the most part it feels alive (until all the students go missing at night or stop talking during the day 👀). Hogsmeade is equally pretty. It's a double edge sword because you're expecting to see all these things you know from the franchise, and sometimes they're there and you love it, but more often it's missing and makes the game feel a little more empty.Then everything beyond the areas we know is either bland countryside or a cave/tomb where you see the same assets and enemies constantly reused (spiders, goblins or evil wizards) and engage with the same open-world filler content/puzzles over and over 😴The main quest was only just barely interesting enough to follow along (a bit like the fantastic beasts movies lol), and I didn't really like any characters in the game except Sebastian and Ominis.There's also a lot of key HP elements missing and I think a sequel could improve on the formula.

author: Scythe08
review: Its an extremely shallow game. Its obvious they cut out alot of parts to not have a delay upon release. Very limited enemy types, the worst loot system that I have ever experienced, and the most boring, repetitious puzzles that I have ever seen. Seriously, move block here, activate lever there, rinse and repeat.The vast majority of the 'open world' is lifeless. You cant interact with the majority of the NPCs. You're force fed a storyline that you cant influence. You're a student trying to stop the forces of evil, yet you walk around killing goblins and dark wizards without a second though of the morality of the situation and have a higher body count than they could ever dream of. In the begining they captured the magical feel of the harry potter universe. But it quickly becomes stale when you realize there are basically 5 enemy types and they all act the same with the same spam attacks.The majority of the content is collectibles. Find 10-20-30-50 of these and get.........nothing of any value.The loot is random. Go through a dungeon and the last chest with a worthless item that is worst than any you have. find a chest in a bush outside somewhere randomly and find an amazing high tier item. It makes zero sense. There is no point in finding the treasure chests as their is only garbage in them.I goit 30 hours out of the game and was interested for about 15 hours of it. The last bit, I got to my second trial and after the 3rd mob and fighting the camera as well as the boss, I uninstalled. This just isnt fun anymore and I have no interest. Wait for a holiday sale.

author: lynn.sabin
review: These comments are generally directed at seniors and others with physical challenges.I am 73 (as of this writing), and I'm blessed with RA and a horrible tremor in my hands. This game is generally playable as there are settings for degree of difficulty. I play in Normal Mode most of the time, but when necessary I have gone to Easy and even Story Mode. One component I do find very difficult is flying -- because of the DOWN controls, which can be done with the CNTL Key or the "B" Key. Every other game I've played has simply controlled elevation changes by the camera angle (look up, you fly up; look down, you fly down). The CNTL and B key mechanic is *very* awkward for me.Graphics and animations in HL are superb. These make the world a place you want to hang out in. Cut scenes integrate almost seamlessly, and this makes the game's story lines much more enjoyable. Gathering resources, Beast collecting and tending, and Crafting are integral to the game. As an inveterate crafter, I suppose the process could be a bit more involved, but I think HL generally hits it close to the mark for all players.My PC is a Lenovo laptop, with 11th Gen i7 running at 2.30 GHz; 64 GB RAM. Graphics: NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3050. In default mode, the game plays very nicely, with rare instances where the image can be a little jerky.Overall, I'm quite pleased with HL and I imagine I'll be playing it for a long time to come.

author: Analog Pill
review: This is a wonderful game made with a clear passion by people who love the source material. I personally always found the world of Harry Potter much more interesting than the characters, if you are anything like me then you will feel at home here. The only problem as others have pointed out, are the optimization issues. I am also 95% sure the game has a severe memory leak. It will start off running wonderfully and progressively get worse and worse as time goes on.

author: Curious George
review: I'm glad some people aren't just mindlessly throwing positive reviews out there like most of the reviews. I will admit I love the game and enjoy the story so far, but there is a reason why this review is negative. I will not post any spoilers in this review, as I want to focus on one main thing. I want to focus on the performance, as with most of these negative reviews. This game is not optimized and suffers from issues like stuttering, pop-ins, and frame rate issues. This brings me to this. Companies do not care about the consumer as they know people will buy the game anyway. It's almost like common practice now to throw terrible ports or poorly optimized games at PC players. They throw these games out there like a fresh pile of sh*t, then clean them up later (Like Cyberpunk 2077). I'd like to know why they had to push back the original release date because they obviously didn't use that time to optimize this hot garbage. The game isn't entirely unplayable for me, but I do have some terrible stuttering once and a while. But that is just for me; many players have the same, if not worse, issues than I do. It seems like the "day one patch" hasn't done anything to address any of the problems either (if it was even our day one patch as it was only 300mb for me). I will leave this review negative until they fix the performance issues. Also, another point/conjecture is that the game runs fine in the beginning, almost like they just optimized that part so that you hit your 2-hour playtime and can't refund the game after you realize how terrible the game runs later. Very scummy, if true, but I digress; if you can't wait for the game to get optimized and want to play now, go ahead. As I said, I like the game; but I am sick of PC players getting sh*t on.Also, if you want to know, here are my PC specs (at least what I think is relevant):CPU: Intel i5-12600kGPU: ASUS TUF RTX 3080 Ti OC EditionRam: Corsair Vengeance LPX 32GB (2 X 16GB) DDR4 3600I use/run the game on a 1440p 144hz monitor. I kept the games resolution at 2560x1440 but capped this game at 75 fps to reduce stuttering when frames drop. (I sometimes dip into the 60s or lower). Still get pretty bad stutter here and there.Settings I toyed with to get a better frame rate:Running the game on a mixture of high and ultra settings.DLSS: BalancedRay tracing is all off - I'd suggest you turn that sh*t off if you are having issues as it was what killed my frames.V-sync: Off in-game but turned on with Nvidia control panel.Low latency: on+boost

author: Maria<3
review: As a fan of the magical world of Harry Potter this game is an absolute must buy.  There is a lot to discover and do. And a tremendous amount of lore and world building.As an RPG alone though, the game is enjoyable, there is a whole lot to do. But there's a whole lot of the same to do. For example, there's a inventory increasing mechanic baked in a short little puzzle. Known as a Merlin trial. There's like a 100 of them across the map, but there are only a handful of different kinds. So it gets old quick.It feels like the world is full of things, and in a sense it is. But it's mostly the same type of things. And this is fine, the open world and the hidden combat mechanics keep things interesting enough as far as combat is concerned.A lot of things feel tacked on, as if there was just a box being ticked. Gear progression for example. You'll end up doing many of the aforementioned Merlin trials, because your inventory is very limited and you'll get buried in gear. Most of which you'll sell, because the aesthetics of the items are then unlocked and saved (I do like that particular part) other then that, the gear progression is very meh.Another thing that feels tacked on is the talent system, I found myself not really caring for the talent upgrades. There are a few useful ones. But I would have loved to see a more robust talent system, possibly with new spells.There are a great many things missing from the game too. The obvious one is Quidditch. But simple things like the ability to sit at your house's table and eat, emotes, photomodes, actual secrets that don't reveal with Revellio, but require you to immerse yourself in the world. For example, the one-eyed witch, you get told about it, at which point it unlocks. Same with Herodiana (depulso lady) they unlock once an NPC tells you about it. There are very few secrets you just get to discover on your own. Near the Hufflepuff common room for example are the kitchens, if you walk by that particular portrait an interact symbol is visible, telling you to tickle the pear. There's almost no secrets you really discover on your own. And those that you do are obvious and very much the same. The arrhythmic door puzzles for example.You start as a fifth year, and you need to "catch up" and catch up fast. You however only learn a very select amount of spells, and spend almost no time in class. Outside of missions and side missions the only people you can talk to repeatedly are shopkeepers. Not the students, not the teachers (though the teachers get two stages of dialogue outside the missions, and then they never speak again) the minigames are also basically a one shot. If you beat the opponents, you can't beat them again. The flying is repeatable, but you'll end up competing against your own time. Early on, you get to choose to help a first year with her Gobstones (a game in the series) and you are presented with a choice, keep the stones or give them. If you keep them, nothing happens, she still plays gobstones in the courtyard and her dialogue changes, if you give them back, the same thing happens. But at no point can you join. There aren't any minigames you can repeat. There are a LOT of collectables, all cosmetic unlocks within your Room of Requirement. Which you can go nuts at, it's pretty good as far as housing goes. And a decent surprise.But the RPG mechanics are very barebones. Too barebones if you ask me.It's clear that the world itself received a LOT of love, and an incredible amount of attention to detail. It's incredible. It is obvious to me that that is where the team spent most the development time. And it shows, the world is absolutely gorgeous. I just wish there was a bit more game.I still recommend the game, I absolutely adore it, despite me sounding rather negative. If they get to add more classes, overhaul the way you interact with NPCs add more repeatable things. Wizard Chess for example, even more duels after the "crossed wands" duel club is over. Anything to make the world feel more alive. And not just going around unlocking doors to get collectables because you finished everything else. Then Legacy 2 would be one of the best games. As things stand. It's a good game, good for a single playthrough, and 3 short ones to see the one unique quest and common rooms.

author: Nephritic Hypnotist
review: I wanted to love this game as an avid Harry Potter fan.  Unfortunately this game had some major flaws.  First of all the game did not feel like you were attending school but rather were playing some sort of open world game while doing a Hogwarts cosplay.  Second the puzzles were lackluster and boring only to give you a new piece of clothing or furniture.  Third the graphics at the best level were barely better than Skyrim while requiring a better computer than my one year old gaming machine leaving many cut scenes as nightmare fuel.  Also the game felt far to linear with to few choices that you could make.  It greatly saddens me that this game did not live up to my hopes.

author: King Andres
review: Everytime I run the game I mean every ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ time, it loads up then closes right away. I have to restart my pc, restart steam, run it as a admin, and verify the game files just to get it work every ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ time I want to play.

author: Mythrandyr
review: I rarely write a review for a game but this one just simply asks for it.Running the game on a Ryzen 7 3700x, RX6800XT with 16GB of RAM, I appear to be one of the lucky few who haven't had a single issue related to performance. With medium to ultra-settings, ray tracing off I rarely drop below 90 FPS, and since it's not a shooter game this really doesn't bother me.Graphics are great, effects are nice. Most sound effects and NPC voice acting are good. The world is pretty.Yet I'm fairly certain only diehard Harry Potter fans will see the 'master' in this piece of software. And those people will not be objective nor honest enough to tell you that they mainly think that way because the game remains true to the source material. Either that, or they don’t have any experience with RPG games since before Skyrim. Sadly, I’m not that big of a harry potter fan, so a lot of the lore and story isn’t ‘finally in a game’ for me.Story is simple, it all revolves around you being the Chosen/Special/Foretold/Destined 'one'. Kind of lame, but the main character has got to feel like a main character so let's remind said main character they are the main character every other dialogue, or rather, every other sentence during most dialogues. Speaking of dialogues, after my first ten hours in the game I pretty much felt like the only thing Hogwarts had been teaching me is that every conversations consists out of about 10 sentences during which you get 2 to 3 'choices', which usually are either a confident 'Yes Sebastian I would enjoy not listening to the teacher and doing some stupid thing with you' or a doubtful  'I'm not so sure if we should Sebastian'. The latter usually unlocks a third choice in the conversation where you can either change your mind and still choose 'yes, let's go mess around' or doubling down on thinking it might not be the best of idea's.Doing Jack Harlow's quest was the point it went downhill for me, which is a quest quite early in the game. during this quest, every chest you find is unlooted and the braindead main character you are repeats about a million times that Jack wasn't very thorough in his search, even though his body is found exactly where the item he was looking for should've been. Jack is (or was?) either a man of sheer will and focus for not bothering with all the other trash in that cave and simply heading straight for what he even came for, or our main character forgets Jack has been dead for at least a hundred years, meaning those unlooted chests might have been emptied and filled a few times before we even set foot in that cave.I understand we are RPG players and want to loot every sparkly item or chest Revellio shows you, but half of the bags and chests give you an item which is worse than what you've been wearing  since a few quests before, or less gold than what the lowest quality items (green gear, sells for 60 gold each, everywhere, anywhere, to anyone) get you when you sell them.Then add the starting 20(!!) gear inventory limit (of which 6 are used by the 6 gear items you've got equipped) meaning that after about every 1/2 quests you'd be wise to head to a merchant to sell all the items you're not using, otherwise you'll be destroying (thus getting no gold) gear during missions/looting just to be able to pick up the new ones you find, which are usually still worse than what you're already wearing.Clearing Poacher/Goblin/Ashwinder/Dark Wizard camps is a waste of time unless the quest your doing is requiring it. Second reason it could be worthwhile is if you're trying to complete a challenge in which you have to defeat x amount of Poachers/Goblins/etc. What do you get out of these challenges? Cosmetic items you can use to make the meh-gear you're wearing look a little less 'meh', or a different kind of 'meh'.Having gear other than your school robe makes you look like a main character out of an anime, since every other student will still be wearing the robes with no hat or glasses, nor a scarf. You look like you've come straight out of an asylum during the cutscenes in Hogwarts wearing a Celtic cape and Porcelain mask with a top hat. Speaking of classes, these take about 3 minutes each and are basically just tutorials either teaching you a new spell or foreboding the new spell you will learn NEXT class. When you explore the world you will quickly find caves, tombs and other POI’s that are shown on the map, which you will not be able to enter even though you have the required spell since they are related to a quest. Sounds fair enough, until you notice this is the case for basically every cave near the school, thus meaning you will have to go further out into the wild far before you have all the skills, spells and gear you need to really be able to explore. The ‘open’ in open world game is rather closed to me.Other than a few random lines of dialogue a NPC will spit out when near them no one reacts to your presence or even your actions at all. Aiming at a student, casting Confringo straight through them? Their body will spasm a bit like you ran up against them, they rarely say anything about it and just keep on walking or talking on. Getting them to really react to you requires you to either be on an active quest relating to them, or having completed a quest relating to them.There’s a certain woman in a certain hamlet which tells you about her missing brother and 2 goblin camps. Clearing the camps and telling her will make her thank you during the cutscene and unlocks a line of dialogue outside of the cutscene in which she thanks you again for what you’ve done. Once you completed the quest related to her brother too she will first cry during the cutscene, exiting the cutscene back into the world will trigger her to either start crying again (you just were already???) or thank you again for clearing the camps. Had I already said our main character is brain dead? Wait until you go to that hamlet for the 3rd’/4th time to complete those quests and talk/trade with her and hearing our main character say the same thing every time he/she enters said hamlet. Much the same as with the chests in Jack Harlow’s quest as I said earlier. If it were a different line of dialogue each time, or a few different lines of dialogue shuffled around, this would’ve been way better. But please don’t act like you are seeing this hamlet for the very first time, saying ‘ah, that’s a cozy enough looking place’ when you fly in for the 4th time? My granddad had dementia and not even he would ask me how soccer practice was going the 4th time I entered the room, all 4 times. He would sometimes even remember what I told him the last time I saw him. That’s a lot more than our teenage main character seems to remember at all.I think I’ve rambled on enough now to give you an idea of the Triple A RPG game your looking at.if stupid and perhaps little things like these don’t bother you, great. I hope you  feel the same after ten, twenty or like me, 26 hours. I’d give the game a neutral review if it was possible, but since I can only choose Thumbs Up or Thumbs Down, I’m gonna have to go with Thumbs Down.

author: Cyridius
review: Spoiler free Early Access review.I never liked the books. I did grow up and age with the movies and I enjoyed them all. So you can say I'm someone familiar with the lore of the world, gets a lot of the subtle references and world building, and understands pretty much all the terminology that the characters will use. Hogwarts Legacy is a good game. It's good in that it's faithful to the world that it comes from, but more importantly it's good from the standpoint of game design. It's extremely well done, thought-through, and feature dense. I am at level 20 (out of 40) and in some senses I feel like I'm still in the tutorial stage of the game, with a number of features still being locked. This is a double edged sword; On the one hand, this sense of continuous progression is something most RPGs deliver and players have come to expect, but I also feel like it's distracting me from the core gameplay. Every few levels there is a huge new feature I need to stop and take a look at and then decide if I want to derail my questing to go learn. I'm never sure what the use-case for a particular feature is going to be, because often it's not all that well telegraphed by the game. The Viviary is one of them, and I would have held off on doing other content first had I been aware that this was around the corner. This kind of progression system feels like it got the worst of both flexibility and railroading, but still somehow managed to come out with a satisfying overall loop. Your mileage may vary.It's not the end of the world by any means; Hogwarts Legacy is a very flexible game when it comes to a player's progression path. But that flexibility also results in confusion and it's something players who are going in blind are going to have to figure out on the fly like I did.I will also note three other weaknesses with the game; The motion capture on character faces is wildly inconsistent. In some cases it is extraordinarily life like. In others, it's comical. Unfortunately, for your character it's going to be comical. You will immediately notice this from the first scene of the game and you will not be able to unnotice it, because your character is the entire focal point of this entire rodeo. The second weakness is something that wont effect people on a good PC that much, but will be brutal for people on mid-low end specs. I run an RTX3080, a very good SSD etc etc. I still hit very brief loading times on doors. I mean so brief that by the time I register it's happening, it's usually done. Ultra graphics. On slower computers that is going to wreck your immersion, extend your travel time around Hogwarts and result in you just leaning on fast travel mechanics instead of immersing yourself in the extremely well-crafted setting.The third problem is that the character creation in this game is confusing and lacklustre. It took me a good few minutes to figure out what its layout was (maybe I'm dumb), but that aside, the hair options are very poor, and the skin tone is weighted too dark - particularly for a game set in Britain. People are pasty as hell over here. I don't mean this in a political sense (those people can go cry), but I know I also design my characters to be on the paler side, and I just didn't have that option at all. This is easily fixable, but if it ever is it will require a new save as there is no changing of fundamental characteristics of appearance in this game. This to me is a missing feature and should be fixed.Pre-Early Access, people did complain about backgrond NPCs. I'm sure if you're the kind of person who cares about that kind of stuff, it's still bad. I didn't notice it even a little bit, because the game does not incentivise you to sit around and look at NPCs, it encourages you to be constantly on the move. There is never not something to do.I didn't include it in the other three problems, but to me the Early Access package is egregiously predatory in terms of the exclusive content it offers. It really is very bad. It is qualitatively worse than industry standard for a single player game and will just encourage piracy. Actual game content should never be locked behind pre-orders in a game like this - once you're thinking about even going beyond cosmetics, you have to take a step back. But they already have my money so it's not like they'll care.The stealth mechanics in this game are one and done. No point in doing them unless you're forced to, which you are in a handful of quests. Otherwise you can just blast your way through everything, and you are going to want to because the combat is by far the highlight of this game. It's brilliant. The combos, the feel, the pace - it is perfect. There are some technical issues - for example, Troll attacks are clearly bugged and cause them to teleport on top of you on their second swing, making them unavoidable if you do a teleportation-dodge on the first attack. But generally speaking in 99% of the combat I've experienced, it is seamless, impactful, extremely entertaining and there is not a fight that I wont pick just to experience the thrill of combat. The game is worth purchasing for it alone.Thankfully, Hogwarts Legacy has a lot more going for it than combat. The story is compelling, and I want to find out more about the background of what's going on, and what's going to happen next. The side quests link up with the main story well in terms of colouring in the edges of what's happening. The writing is good, the voice acting is above-average (if we account for the bug with voice pitches that urgently must be fixed), the characterisation is decent, and the quests are fun. What I will say is that it misses meaningful choice and consequence. The story and your character morality is definitely railroaded (at least where it's important), at least up to the point I have played. However, this is the case for 95% of today's RPGs, so I can't knock it too much for that, but it's nonetheless something all RPGs should have and this doesn't. In that sense, Hogwarts Legacy is a bad RPG - but it's a top tier Action RPG, that is beyond dispute.Aside of the amazing combat and quality story telling, this game is jampacked with a whole load of features I did not expect but was pleasantly surprised about, features that you can sink considerable time into. I can definitely see the Room of Requirement being a big thing for the more creative players amongst us. The transmog system is perfect. Resource gathering is multifaceted, links with the lore of what's going on in a way that makes sense, and has plenty of side features that you will not want to miss.Hogwarts Legacy gets a deserved 9/10. There's very little you could do to improve this project within reason. It's a great tribute to the fans of the franchise, and more importantly it's a very solid game.

author: SpaceAce
review: Hogwarts Legacy is exactly what you expect it to be, its utterly mediocre, derivative and unimpressive in its delivery of complete and utter genericness. It has the same energy as the hundredth Assassin's Creed game while being the first game in its series. It is formulaic, constantly referential to Harry Potter canon for seemingly no reason than to make the audience scream like baboons at the thing that's familiar. The game looks like ♥♥♥♥, and runs like ass, so its a pretty fitting combo. At best you could say its at least somewhat grand in scope but its only as grand as revisiting the same locations over, and over again can really be. Character customization is pointless and at times simply odd. As a Slytherin character there are very few moments that feel particularly Slytherin besides just a general idea of "you are ambitious but only sometimes." Instead, I feel like a discount Gryffindor, with the male voice attempting their best impression of Daniel Radcliffe. There are a myriad of outfits and cosmetic options in the game but all of them feel out of place. Every single student is dressed nearly identically but you can walk in looking like a Scottish Monster Hunter and its so bizarre I don't even understand the reason for it beyond just having options that don't really mean anything. Exploring rewards nothing but generic God of War style looter shooter gear that you slot the bigger number in. And with how slow and monotonous opening the menus are, it quickly becomes a chore you won't want to even bother with. I was originally intending to do a breakdown of which individual components are bad about the game, that was until I realized... Everything was pretty terrible in some way. Menus are clunky, numerous and filled with needless animations that bloat the time you spend navigating important menus such as quests and challenges, all super immersion breaking, but placed within an idea of a magical book your character is handed. Why not just make it a real book that doesn't take you out of the experience? The map is awful to navigate, it seems like it would benefit from a top down view, but instead you get an awkward side angle that gives you no real depth or perspective on what you're zooming in on. Combat is dull, its just a color match game of purple shield means use purple spell, red shield means use red spell, orange circle means block, red circle means dodge. Its ♥♥♥♥♥♥ God of War with such a small selection of spells, most of which are useless and the majority of which are unlocked through tedious side content that has no meaning, impact or interest. Drink 3 potions to unlock X spell. You get the idea. Where is the promised deep spell combo customization? ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ spamming is more effective for most enemies since they die fairly quickly with 0 challenge. The only difficulty coming from how annoyingly binded the dodge key is initially to actually avoid red circle attacks. Its very pretty I'll give it that, but it has the depth of a puddle. Flying is fine, but that's all you can say, its barebones, stiff and feels straight of a modern MMO than a singleplayer RPG The narrative is horrifically terrible. With a predictable, uninteresting story surrounding characters with 0 compelling traits or motives. Which is kind of disappointing when you consider how interesting the opening of the game was, only for it to be immediately explained via obvious contextual clues the characters spend 10 hours contemplating when you've already figured it out based on the obvious. I hope you enjoy almost every enemy having the exact same 3 voice actors, no personality, and just a complete lack of any motivation to actually fight anyone besides being told to fight X amount of people for a challenge in the dumb magic book. There is nothing to discover or earn besides more ♥♥♥♥ pointless loot that will be replaced within an hour anyway. The puzzles are similarly serviceable but uninteresting, boiling down to just pressing the right spell on the right widget. Is Hogwarts Legacy transphobic? I don't care. Its just a bad game. Pretending like you're owning the libs by buying it ain't that impressive chief, considering you're funding libs by doing it. And for the other camp, JK Rowling is already wealthier than Harry Potter at the start of the series, forwarding her transphobic agenda isn't hinging on the sales of Hogwash LegassFundamentally, I think the question is whether Hogwarts Legacy is a bad game, and my simple response is, Hogwarts Legacy is a game completely bathed in mediocre corporate product. It has nary a sliver of artistic vision, and presents a world I understand many people love in the most derivative, pandering and generic fashion that I find it to be the greatest weapon against Dementors with how devoid of soul it is.Edit: After fully completing the main story, I have absolutely no revisions to add except that the story is even worse than I had imagined. I held pointless hope that it would at least try and have some nuance in its storytelling but I got exactly what I knew in the recesses of my mind I would. A narrative so devoid of significance, consequence, or even basic thematic qualities that punctuate any good story, that I genuinely feel anger at the conclusion for being so completely watered down into nothingness. Like moist cotton candy, unappetizing from beginning to vanishing conclusion.

author: Lanfear LP
review: Als Spielerin, die bisher nur 2 Bücher der Reihe gelesen und die Filme erst als Erwachsene zum ersten Mal komplett gesehen hat, bin ich auch ohne Nostalgiebrille total begeistert von diesem zauberhaften Spiel, in dem man eine lebhafte und liebevoll gestaltete Welt erkunden darf, in der sich allerlei magische und interessante Charaktere und Wesen finden. Zudem sind alle Dialoge vertont und die deutschen Sprecher sind keineswegs unbekannt. Die verschiedenen Zauber, die man nach und nach lernt, sind alle auf ihre Weise nützlich und vor allem die Kämpfe, die man mit seinem Zauberstab und etwas Körpereinsatz bestreitet, wirken sehr dynamisch und spaßig. Die Sammlerin in mir freut sich besonders über die vielen Klamotten, die man finden und kaufen kann. Nebenbei kann man sich dann auch noch um den eigenen Garten kümmern, Tränke brauen, Tierwesen aufziehen und auf seinem Besen oder Tierwesen durch die Welt fliegen. Ich habe unglaublich viel Spaß und kann dieses Spiel auch denen empfehlen, die wie ich keine Harry Potter Fans sind. Wer noch unsicher ist, kann gerne in mein Video reinschauen:

author: Rei
review: Hogwarts Legacy is honestly a lot of fun.This is the kind of game I would have absolutely adored to have when I was 10 years old, but that doesn't mean I'm not enjoying it as a working adult. Far from it.The game lets you explore a lot early on and got TONS of references to locations, creatures and whatever stuff from the Harry Potter movies, Fantastical Beasts movies and original books.The combat is fun, not too difficult, but also not a cakewalk.Exploration is honestly the best aspect, with aesthetically designed locations, hidden caves and secrets, charming music and the aforementioned references scattered all over.I have a serious problem following the main story, as I just get sidetracked with running around and checking every nook and cranny.There have been some minor bugs. DLSS caused everything to stutter, although my PC wasn't even stressed, a minor graphical bug (the autosave icon turned into a white square until I restarted the game), there have been some minor stutters even after turning off DLSS, but that was fixed as well after updating my Nvidia Drivers.But now that it works perfectly fine I have next to no gripes with the game, ton of fun!

VERY EMMERSIVE ! the only negative i can really tell is the performance of the game and i hope they will optimize it in the future with up-coming patches. i have a rtx 3080 and i also have issues. But it's still a playable exp for me! If you are a gamer, you are gonna have fun with this. If you are a Harrypotter fan and gamer this is the game you have been waiting for!

author: Dodohttp
review: Honestly quite disappointed at the preformance of this game, more and more triple A games are coming out on launch with moderate or terrible preformance. And there's just no excuse for it, if you're going to charge 90 AUD for a game I should expect it actually runs smoothly without the immersion breaking FPS drops and constant stuttering.

author: ArchWizard
review: I have been waiting for this game my entire life. There is nothing bad thing to say. It is just the pure Harry Potter video game we all wanted. When launched, I played for 14 hours non-stop and didn't even do the main quest storyline, I was just out there exploring the world and the world has incredible details like they thought every small detail, I couldn't believe it. Even if you are not a HP fan, you can still be amazed by this game. There are many references to the movies, but the main design comes from the books and let me say this: It couldn't be done better.The Hogwarts we have seen in the movies is nothing compared to Hogwarts Legacy's Hogwarts. Of course, the main outline, and design of the castle comes from the movies but the interior... I mean...they did something beyond what I could have imagined. Ghosts, Peeves, armors that whistle while you pass them and knock his fellow, sculptures that wave at you if you wave at them, decorations, interactive knickknacks...The combat is so smooth, so artistic. The wand movements are designed incredibly realistic. Spell slots are easy to use but it takes a little to get used to. You can do almost endless combinations with spells it is totally up to you... or... you know... you can just cast . There are potions and plants that will help you in battle. You don't necessarily need to use them but they add a layer to the fights. The dodging mechanic is amazing, you could either dodge with  or roll, ancient magic, and sometimes you have to dodge according to your enemy's mechanic sometimes 1 is enough but sometimes a well-timed 3 dodge is required.The story is well-written but could've been a little longer. It's nothing groundbreaking I must admit, but it's enjoyable. I really enjoyed the characters and their stories as well. Sebastian's story is my favourite.Ultimately, it's my favourite game of all time.

author: Empress Mira
review: I am the chosen Witch, you are all just NPCs. AVADA KADAVRA!But seriously, Ive finished the Main Story twice now good and evil, not that its that simple. Enthralling game, very fun and varied combat. Intensely great story... gorgeous Graphics. Game of the year. 10/10

author: zealor
review: Besides the combat; all else is sub-par. In the Age of Red Dead Redemption 2; its disappointing that Hogwarts doesn't have the same level of engagement with NPC's. The world feels scripted and unnatural compared to RD2.Developers need to raise the bar.

author: Krauzern
review: Хоча гра і вийшла досить суперечлива, хотілося б залишити все ж таки позитивний відгук. Почав би з її найбільшого мінусу - технічного стану. Через це спочатку хотілося навіть оформити рефанд. Дуже дістає рандомне падіння частоти кадрів і статери. Хоча і граю з лептопа, але далеко не з найслабшого. При чому зміна внутрішніх налаштувань майже не впливає ні на що. Короче будьте готові копирсатися у обоговореннях гри в пошуках милиць для підвищення продуктивності. Але хороша новина - вони не складні і наспровді допомагають (хоча я так до кінця і не вирішив свої, та хоч досяг іграбельного рівня).Що до самої гри, то це десь 4 із 5. Купляючи я очікував на атракціон в декораціях Гаррі Поттера за заклікуванням ворогів. Але геймплей здивував у доброму розумінні. Може і не найглибша бойова система, але досить цікава. Гарне оточення і цікаві персонажі. Якщо ви фанат цього всесвіту, то ви вже її купили. Якщо ні, то краще почекайте на знижку і патчі. Задоволення гра безперечно приносить

author: Scarlett
review: As a HP fan, this game is amazing, it gives you the opportunity to make your own Hogwarts story and I loved every step of it. Many nods to the movies or books and the music.... amazing. As a non-HP fan, I think many people would enjoy this game as well.Great game, the story is dent, the characters are nice (though the companions could be better, maybe an update or DLC to add more is needed), the gameplay actually works super well, the casting feels good an natural. I dare say the combat reminds me of God of War a bit. I have never actually 100% a game (and I don't mean achievements), but I did everything that could be done in this game in one playthrough (the game shows you your progress and all the collectibles).

author: Saber-x-wolf
review: Graphics:9Visually impressive, large expansive areas filled with character that all feel lived in. Some flaws when character faces emote and other common glitches involving cloak physics.Gameplay:9.5A fun Arkham style combat system that relies on a wide array of spells and counter attacks. Outside of the combat there's a lot to do: raising fantastic beasts, mini-games, flying, potion making. All of which feel very refined.Sound:9.5The original soundtrack is tremendous, it hits all the right emotional and high adventure beats. The characters are generally very well voice acted.Story:8The story is serviceable, the characters are fun and interesting but I would have liked to have seen more of them.Replay Value:8.5Solid length game, not too long not too short. A good amount of content to bite into, I would definitely come back if they added more content later down the line.Verdict:8.9Great, but just shy of masterful. It needs a little more nips and tucks to get to be among the Red Dead Redemption 2's, but if this game is like the Mass Effect 2 to the Mass Effect series or the Arkham City to the Arkham series then this has potential to be a really incredible series as it progresses.

author: artwaste
review: Let me preface this review first by letting everyone who reads know that I do not care about the politics circling this game, or what anyone's views are regarding said politics. I am interested in this game as a fan of Harry Potter, and of fantasy rpg games. That being said, I will only discuss game-related content and/or issues in this review.Graphics & Sound: 9.5/10Sadly, I am playing this game with a graphics card that falls short of minimum requirements. However, I'm of the NES/SNES generation, so a game's graphics have never been the sole reason for me to play a game. Even on low settings, I still find this game to be extraordinarily beautiful, and the world feels like a real place, and very lived-in. The music is enchanting, and several times during my play-throughs I found myself standing around just listening to the music. The only thing I didn't like, is the player character's voice. It sounds odd, like as if the studio didn't record the dialogue in a proper setting. I've heard the same thing while watching other streamers' game plays, and possibly only irks me as I've not heard anyone else mention this.Gameplay: 9/10While the game's mechanics and controls are easy to learn and easy to master, there were a few glitches/bugs that I experienced, though none were game-breaking. Certain side quests would get glitched, and a quick reload from a previous save quickly fixed the issue. I'm sure with a few updates things would probably run smoother, but the glitches that I encountered in no way deterred me from continuing with gameplay.Storyline: 10/10The main storyline is definitely engaging. I found myself dying to get to the next part, whether it was the main storyline or a side quest. You get a pretty good sense of the characters, their personalities, and even the world.Overall, I'd say this is one of the funnest games I've played in a long time, and has certainly left its mark. I think this game will go down as one of the greatest fantasy rpg games of all time. I've completed this game 100%, and I am very glad I bought it. I cannot wait to build a new computer so that I may play the game with the visual impact the developer's intended. I also want to give kudos to the developers, and add that I had almost forgotten how fun fantasy rpg games could be, but this game certainly reminded me why I love fantasy.

author: Chig Bungus
review: After completing the game, I think it's time I give a proper review of my experiences with the game.(For reference, specs are i7-10750, 1650ti Q-Max Design, 16GB RAM)Pros: The game itself is wonderful to play. The main story line was not dry and was exciting throughout (my personal favorite quests were with Sebastian and Poppy).The Hogwarts location itself blew my mind with how how many rooms and hidden items were scattered around (that I have found so far). The combat in the game was interesting to me. From one side, I enjoyed the combos while fighting endless goblins and poachers and keeping them airborne for days on end. The use of all the spells and Basic Cast made the combat more exciting and creative, from my perspective. The Room of Requirement was one of my personal favorites, allowing so many opportunities for customization.Cons:At times I still experience stuttering, nothing too extreme to where it's game breaking but is still a persistent issue.During combat, using Protego would not register sometimes, along with dodging by using the Ctrl button.The ending to the main quest with Ranrok was a let down. I feel personally there could've been so much more that could have been done besides what is already implemented in the game. The FINAL ending when you take your O.W.Ls is downright pathetic. It seems that it was very rushed towards the end and there was no significant attention to detail that was present in other scenes of the game. Overall, while I very much enjoyed this game, it has a few bugs that are still present throughout the game, and from what I have seen that the dev team is continuously looking into fixing all bugs that are reported. I hope that in the future, more content is added to expand to the Hogwarts Universe. P.S. Deek thinks you should be proud of the potions you've brewed.

author: Fanciful Imp
review: + Beautiful looking game+ Combat can be fun for a bit- Empty game- Boring quests- Repetitive open-world design- No real challenge- Tediously bad puzzles- No replay valueA beautiful game with absolutely zero substance. It's almost like the developers took every thing that makes an open world game bad and compiled it into one single game. Well, congratulations to them because that is exactly what they achieved with Hogwarts Legacy. Hogwarts is EMPTY. Imagine making a game "Hogwarts" Legacy and the majority of the playtime is OUTSIDE of Hogwarts. That wouldn't be such a big deal if the developers actually made you do stuff in it, but guess what? It's EMPTY. There is no incentive to be in Hogwarts whatsoever other than collecting Ubisoft-eseque collectibles or interacting with main characters to progress the story. And boy, oh boy, did they put every piss-poor type of collectible that is present in open world games all into this one. There are no engaging mini-games in Hogwarts, no fun activities, no interesting lessons, no house cups to compete in... absolutely nothing to do in such a otherwise highly detailed castle. It's beyond underwhelming and confusing as to why I'm even roleplaying as a student, and the House you go with serves no purpose other than "Hey look, I'm Gryiffindor... Yay?" You don't even learn spells during classes in Hogwarts; instead you have to perform mobile game quality quests to earn new spells (kill x 5 times in this way). It's not like the spells are fun to use anyway considering the majority of them achieve the same results.As for the open world exploration? EMPTY. It's a collectible fest. What were they thinking? The side quests are garbage fetch quests, there are bunch of pointless, boring and tedious activities plaguing the map. Don't get me started on the below average quality puzzles, which would be fine if there weren't too many of them, all of which are there to simply waste your time and pad out game time. It's incredibly unfortunate because the world design is phenomenal and one the best I've seen. But nothing other than shopkeepers can be interacted with. This whole game is just "see but don't touch".The combat is fun for a while but eventually, its gets old real quick. It was never challenging to begin with and you just get more and more powerful the more you progress your stats. New spells won't be enough to keep you interested. I couldn't care less about the story or any of the characters I have interacted with. They're all agreeable, one dimensional characters, and the main character, YOU, is the best wizard/witch in the whole universe. There are no consequence to anything you do, even if you choose an "evil" dialogue option or use forbidden spells.I feel like their design philosophy for this game was "Let's put everything so that players can't complain that there is nothing." What I mean by that, is that they did way too much than necessary to the point it started to affect the game's quality: Too many upgrades from too many sources, too much of the same spells, too much of the same quests, too many chests behind too many locked rooms (which, unsurprisingly, also needs too many upgrades to unlock). It seems like they did too much of all the terrible open world design combination to compensate for game's emptiness.This game has NO replay value and frankly, I don't even feel like continuing playing anymore. You can plough through the main quests and probably have a good times, but as for completionists like myself, this game is a nightmare to explore. I don't recommend the game at full price, wait for a sale.

review: Pros:+ great looking game (sometimes)+ combat is pretty fun when you get the hang of it+ the world looks great and Hogwarts is pure nostalgia for people who grew up with the books/movies and always wanted to explore the school in a videogame+ story is predictable but fun enough+ cool little minigame that lets you customize everything about a room, expanding as you progress the main story+ cool little monster catching minigame that lets you capture, breed and take care of beastsCons:- lockpicking minigame that will get on your nerve- your actions have no real consequences, neither does your house (only some quests have a different ending but it's minimal)- best skills are locked until you are almost at the end of the game- assassin's creed style open world, it's full of repetitive tasks - performance seems to vary for people, was having major stutters until I upgraded to 32 GB of ram (recommended system requirements is a joke and it should be 32GB of ram)- voice acting of your character is a letdown, everyone is dying around you and he just talks like it's no big dealSidenote:Overall a 7,5/10. The game is fun if you like the Harry Potter world, just don't expect a Witcher, Mass Effect kind of game where your actions matter.
