author: BrianH1988
review: Overall pretty good at times, incredible at others. This game has little bearing or care of the movies. It's very interested in the lore of the Wizarding World as a whole, and it never feels like it's trying to do anything more or less than be a vertical slice of the Wizarding World set to the backdrop of a fifth year attending Hogwarts. In a day and age where games try to do everything and be everything so often with the open world formula, it's entirely refreshing that nothing you do when you go out into the open world outside of the main questline will be copy and paste, though a lot of things will feel like familiar iteration quite often. Hogwarts itself is a treat, Hogsmeade is a joy. The open world between and around them is teeming with things to do ranging from 'I solved a complex puzzle for one chest' to 'I found a labyrinthine maze almost at random full of stuff'.The main story is, with a few notable exceptions, almost entirely forgettable, and the final stretch feels like it was flat out unfinished in parts compared to the rest. Where this game truly shines, and shines hard, is the excellent overall VA, writing, and setup and reward for the side quests, some of which net you cosmetics, others are downright mandatory due to giving you spells, and still others are just a joy to complete. Even the average fetch quest in this game usually has some pretty compelling reasons to see it through. What I'm saying is, you don't play this game for the main story to begin with. You play this because all the rest of the content is gonna scratch that wizarding itch games like Elden Ring just couldn't quite provide, in a world where there is no melee combat and everyone flings spells at each other.Those spells, by the way, have very varying effects. Early on you'll feel like they become a bit redundant- and then you get your talents and realize that by the time you fill out your trees all of these will function radically different than they did at the start. Considerably negative marks go to the fact that there are relatively few crowd control spells that give reasonable effects given how the AI reacts, and this means that once the game starts throwing 10-20 enemies in multiple waves at you, which it will, combat overall becomes a tad cumbersome. The decoupled dodging mechanic and enemies that guaranteedly home in on whenever you see the circle indicating to press the dodge button means the whole flow of combat is quite stunted later. The fact that enemies level with you means you will never truly be allowed a power trip. Sadly this is not just a few enemies, but almost the exclusivity of them. No Oblivion dichotomy here where some enemies level with you, they're almost always exactly at your level. I know more than a few people for which this would make any game a deal-breaker so it's certainly worth mentioning here. There are also myriad difficulty spikes in even the main story, much less in the content and sidequests. Gear will not make you into a walking tank by the end given what the game throws at you, take that as you will. More often you're going to feel like things ended very quickly or took far too long.All things said and done though, with the level of quality so much of the game has, I would consider it heinous for me not to give a game developed with such a clear love for the source high marks, when it generally coheres so well.

author: YT TharionDrake
review: I do recommend this game... However I feel that a lot of content in this game was either half removed/made and or not optimised.- Good amount of quests that also played on your morality.- Fight scenes were fun, Remove the lock target and you'll improve the fight scenes greatly (I used controller). - The puzzles and side quests were engaging and fun.- I played my only play through on the hardest difficulty, I have not 100% the game but its already taken about 69 hours.The things I feel they need to add into the game or fix:- Fully bring in the curfew system.... Literally only two missions forced me to sneak around. Using invisibility was almost unused for at least 98.5% of my game play. With this I also feel your house/dorm room really isn't utilised at all. I think i spent less than 30 minutes there the whole game and that was mainly at the beginning. - Why is my character the only one wearing a different style of house robe? It would be nice to see other students wear a variety... I did see a single student wear a quidditch outfit, which was very out of place (because its its banned at hogwarts this year).- I won't get into a quidditch rant, obviously thats been touched on many times over.- Some voice lines get very over used, mainly the Hogsmeed one (we all know what this is). - I would also love to see more races/time trial's for the brooms.- More duel's would also be awesome!- The evil ending didn't seem as flushed out as the good ending, it was very glazed over it seemed (I did both endings).- Maybe a year 6 DLC?Over all, I would be happy to come back to this and see if their has been more updates to the game play, maybe some optimisation. I don't feel like its game of the year but I had a very fun time playing it! I'm Excited to see what the future holds for this game!

author: 4th
review: A magnificent game sadly ruined by poor performance on PC, I only purchased it here so that I am able to mod the game which I hope one day will be worth it once the performance has been patched.I played this to 100% challenge and map completion on PS5 and it was honestly an incredible experience. Highly recommended if you can play on PS5/Xbox or at a future time when the performance issues are (hopefully) fixed.That said, if you're already a Potter fan you'll probably enjoy this on PC even with the performance issues, it really is a love letter to the fans filled to the brim with nods to the books and movies. I'm interested to see what they do with it from here because despite how amazing this game is it's only scratching the surface of possibility.

I can't even imagine what they can do with this title in the future, the potential is endless.: It seems many people are experiencing issues most notably constant stuttering and huge frame drops likely caused by Shaders loading in which we PC gamers came fond of. I highly recommend checking out this  which has smoothed the experience. tbh I haven't experienced that many issues even without the minor tweaking but it helps.Anyhow, please stop reading the reviews and just buy it already. it's a f*cking

Every single penny.Buy the game and go live out your childhood dreams (also you can pet the cats, what a time to be alive)

author: Naozomi (Twitch)
review: It's been breaking records for a reason! 🤩In full disclosure it WAS a gift from a follower that wanted to see me play it on stream BUT I DID take the opportunity to purchase it on Playstation 4 as well for the exclusive content.I have been having SO much fun streaming this game with everyone, it's everything I wanted!💜 There is so much gorgeous art to stare at everywhere, the music and sound design is TOP tier, great special effects, has run perfectly smooth for me with my GTX 1080 (my vtuber avi lags a bit but I'm fine with that XD), the whole thing feels like a new interactive movie in the franchise. I'm at 17 hours it seems and I feel like I'm only scratching the surface (8% achievements). Everyone that comes into stream is falling in love with it too. Can't wait to explore the Forbidden Forest next stream finally 😆If you want to see my reactions to everything before you buy feel free to check out    but if you like the franchise, puzzles, taking your time to really immerse yourself and absorb it all....I really do think there is a LOT here to love. You can feel the passion from the creators emanating from every inch of the world. People have even started making mods for it already! I wouldn't be surprised if this was the next Skyrim if they release a dev kit!Graphics : 10/10  Especially on reflections* 🤤Audio : 10/10 I wouldn't accept anything less from a game of THIS franchise, even the unnamed npcs have lots of interesting chatterCombat : 10/10  The most fun I've had with combat in a LONG time, I live for that hack & slash fast pace. Choose normal or hard only, thank me later. Difficulty DOES spike after a certain early point in the main quest though.------GUI : 9/10   I have to take off a point for not being able to preview owned gear at the shop and the counter blocking my view, but I see mods fixing that soon-----  EDIT: GUI : 10/10    I've been made aware that once you unlock gear you can change to it's appearance at any time so you don't actually have to worry about accidentally selling anything that looks cool, the counter in the way is still a little lame though, use arrow keys to turn the camera.Character creation : 8/10 Without mods the lightest skin is still mid tone and the darker skins are a little greyish/reddish but mods fix it. Doesn't have enough eye colors imo, I wanted red lol. Have to choose a premade face shape. Also the hairs aren't my favorite and the lighting in creation is misleading to what it looks like in game. Once again...mods..Puzzles : 8/10 Some are a bit simple once you learn the way they work (arithmancy and moths) but they still feel magical. Mods could make them crazy 😁 I understand they didn't want to make them too hard for people lolLore  : 10/10 There is SO much that isn't in the movies, and I imagine not in the books even sometimes. The whole world just feels so fleshed out. I actually want to go to Universal now XD* Appears to actually run better on older gpus at least at this timeTLDR; Play normal or hard. Immersion. Future GOTY if they make it more stable for 2k-4k gpus. Geeky VTuber heart go brrrr💜Also, the Slytherins aren't evil, you can totally play as a good Slytherin. 🐍P.S. Real life politics have no place in game reviews, playing a game isn't going to kill anyone, you don't get to control/bully others. Also if you see goblins and think "Jew"...you need help...Power to the gamers! 👋😄

author: Razz_The_Spazz
review: One of the best games I've played in years. Amazing characters, graphics, and storytelling. Nearly everything is intractable (it's rare to find a door that doesn't open) and the cast is diverse and lovable, or at the least characters that you love to hate. Every area of the game is vibrant and unique, from the dark nuances and stories of ancient times, to the overall cheery atmosphere of the castle and it's students. Not to mention the combat really encourages skill over spam, with quick and impactful duels. It was worth ever penny if you ask me!

author: Max Harvey
review: BEAUTIFUL but BORINGIncredible work which is ultimately boring.  The artwork and design are amazing.  Every element of the game looks beautiful, right down to the menus.  The voice acting is superb.  The magic and crafting system is competent but nothing special.But the game is BORING.  The combat system is simplistic and not much more than button mashing, and where other systems would require tactics, this one just needs you to hit the dodge button at the right time.  You can explore the open world, but it's BORING.  There's not much variety and enemies just inhabit limited zones until you choose to go attack them.  And everything is far to spread out so you waste masses of time pointless running from place to place.  Plot development is GLACIAL and padded out with pointless BORING side quests.  And once you have interacted with a character, such as competing against another student, they will say exactly the same 3-4 lines every single time you interact with them.It's a great pity - the art design, voice acting, visuals, etc are AMAZING.  But game play was completely ignored. Once the novelty of being in a brilliant depiction of Hogwarts wears thin (which happens quickly), the game basically boils down to one long dull grind.I'm glad I've seen inside it, but I  really didn't get my money's worth.  Wait for it to go on on sale.

author: gh0stly
review: This game is highly addictive and as a Harry Potter fan it definitely checks all of the boxes.First and foremost the level of detail is insane. From the lore, music, cast of characters, magical creatures, and the castle you will not be disappointed. Speaking of Hogwarts Castle, you can and will most definitely get lost inside of its walls 10x over and never get bored of the sheer amount of content and secrets hidden for you to find. At first glance you almost couldn't believe they really went the extra mile and made it as fleshed out and lore accurate as they did but boy, you'd be wrong. There was definitely a labor of love put into this project and it certainly shows.Now the game does start off fairly slow. But once it opens up the exploration is great. You'll find yourself wanting to scour every inch of the map because there's always something to do and people to see. Loot however does leave a little to be desired. With most of what you unlock being purely cosmetic you would think there isn't much incentive to grind out gear but I still found myself being compelled to. However, once you unlock the Room of Requirement that's where things start to get very interesting. You'll be able to fine tune your gear to your exact play style so long as you have the required items to do so. Plus let's not forget potion brewing, caring for magical beasts, and so much more.Combat in this game is fun as hell. I can't see myself getting bored when it comes to mixing and matching different spells to pull off some flashy combos. Also utilizing the many different spells at your disposal to solve puzzles both inside of Hogwarts Castle and out in the open world is such a great touch.I did get the 72 hour access so what I will say is this. The game is surely not without its flaws. I'm by no means running this game on a potato PC yet some pretty poor optimization has forced me to have to finagle with my settings to find the right combination just so I can maximize my frames without them consistently tanking. I do experience some frame drops running around Hogwarts Castle and some towns occasionally so that's mildly annoying. But again, pre day 1 patch so this is pretty much to be expected. I have no doubt in my mind that as time progresses these minor issues will be addressed and this will be a thing of the past.One thing I will say though is this game VERY loosely reminds me of a Fallout 4 morality system. What I mean by that is, if you so choose to go the evil route you never quite feel fully evil. More or less you start to feel somewhat like a pretentious smug ♥♥♥♥. By all means I was not expecting a fully fleshed out morality system to begin with and I knew going into this game there wasn't going to be one included anyway. However, I just personally felt that regardless of my actions and decisions in the game I still ultimately feel like the good guy.In truth I absolutely love Hogwarts Legacy and I'm for sure having a blast. I've done so much at the time of writing this review and yet I haven't even scratched the surface of what's to come. I can't seem to put the game down and whenever I press play for that first session of the day I lose countless hours immersed in this world that was built. I guess you could say that's always a good sign. I can easily see this game taking close to if not well over a hundred hours to uncover all of it's secrets. I'm certainly here for all of it!So do I recommend it? Without a doubt. Whether you're a fan of the franchise or a newcomer this game is a must buy. If you're on the fence maybe wait for a sale but even at full price with the amount of love that the developers added to this game I can safely say it's justified. After all, there's certainly been worse that's come out within the past few months at a much steeper price.

author: burkblz
review: Empty and generic.  Just imagine a Skyrim without all the side quests / parallel plots, just the Main Quest, thats Hogwarts Legacy. 15 hours played and I don't think I will launch this game again, I get bored at the thought.  Performance is okay at launch, some drops but nothing too bad for my pc (12600k, 32gb, rtx 3070, 1080p screen), and that usually gets fixed within a few weeks of the launch so I wouldn't worry about it. The game is pretty, not beautiful like RDR2, but pretty. Combat is enjoyable (I play M+K). Flying feels pointless without Quidditch (yep, no Quidditch). The plot is meh (at least from what I've played, I did not finish the game, stopped just after finishing the first trial), and from what I've seen there is no side quests (of the kind that actually adds and enriches the plot), just optional tasks (ex. dodge 10 times, kill 5 spiders, collect 10 scrolls, that kind of stuff) the closest that I saw was  maybe there are more side "quests" like this, but even so it still would not be enough, not by a long shot. I must disclose that I'm not a big fan of Harry Potter (the most powerful and villainous Dark Wizard of at least the century, who wields the most powerful wand that ever existed, can't conquer a school, really???), but I do enjoy a good RPG, and unfortunately this is not it.  And for those who played the Dragon Age Series, seems like there is way more interesting stuff to do at the Circles than at Hogwarts, where mages are free, weird huh? If I were a mage I would 100% choose to be beaten to death by templars instead of being bored to death at (this game's) Hogwarts.I wish I could refund this.EDIT: Got the refund, yay.

author: 🌴 S h a d o w
review: This game already kicks major ass. I had low expectations for it at first but when I got my hands on it and played the first 2 hours of it I was just mind blown. Hogwarts castle had so much detail and on top of that the game is beautiful, especially if your RTX settings is at max. I'm so happy this game did so well on launch day and I'm gonna sink more hours into this masterpiece. I'm a huge harry potter fan and just walking through the castle of hogwarts and the outside just kept making me smile, but for those who don't like harry potter but interested about picking this game up, then don't worry this game is beginner friendly and is not gonna throw things at you that you're supposed to know if you ever read the books or seen the movies and I like how they did that. I urge you to pick this game up, trust me you're gonna have a fun time.

author: sapnu puas zld
review: By FAR one of my favorite games of all time. You can tell the devs were trying their best to make the Wizarding World game of all of our dreams. I do wish Quidditch was in the game but that can always be added at a later date and time.Pros:- Fantastic open world- Very fun to explore- Combat feels super fluid- The spells are really fun to use- Customization is great- Clothing looks incredible- HOGWARTS (it feels so amazing to be able to walk around in the place we all wanted to go to school)- Secrets (so many secrets)- Broom travel is what I've always wanted from a Wizarding World game Cons:- Optimization at launch is really bad, hoping for it to be fixed in upcoming patches- Some Quests feel lackluster- Your choices don't matter as much as I hoped they would- Gives Rowling more unneeded publicityAll in all this is the game I've been wanting since I was a kid and the devs delivered more than I could have imagined.I'm looking forward to any DLC these devs throw our way.

author: Zenfull
review: I feel this game will lose it positive rating as more and more people get through the game. Graphic are good but the ray tracing seems to cause some frame skipping even after the Nvidia updated driver. The story starts off really strong and gets you hooked, which is why I assume it started off with really good reviews, but looses its steam fast and tends to meander through plot holes and plot twists you see coming a mile away. The voice acting is off on some of the quest giving NPC's, the mouth is not sync'ed with the voice. I would put this off for a sale game, in its current state its not worth the 60 dollars.

author: Supgad
review: I must start this by saying, I adore the game. The world the developers created is ripe with nuance and detail that any fan of the franchise will appreciate, and this world is an easy one in which to feel ‘at home.’ I played for nearly 12 hours on my first day with the game, and I only skipped off for sleep at the insistence of my husband, who was incredulous I was still up at 07:00. I was transfixed, transported, delighted. It’s the Harry Potter game some of us older folk have been wanting for actual decades.It’s easy to get lost at Hogwarts, both because the castle and its grounds are positively enormous and because the small touches make the place sing. It’s a joy to stare at every painting, statue; it’s fun to even traipse through the various lavatories, to find bubbling cauldrons and other gadgets in some of the stalls. It’s the Hogwarts we came to know and love from the books and the movies, but it’s one built for us, and it’s one that we can and are, in fact, encouraged to explore. The Field Guide, while a gimmicky crux of the core story, is great fun to fill out with Pages, though I suspect once you know where and how to collect them all, the lustre on subsequent playthroughs will be thoroughly diminished. I also must laud the developers for the combat system. It’s surprisingly challenging, even on Normal difficulty, and there is a frenetic pace to larger encounters that genuinely keeps me on my toes and ever-so-slightly stressed. While I do believe one could just as easily get by with simply Basic Casting between shielding with Protego, the ability to weave, synergistically, various spells in our arsenal into a visually arresting, almost gymnastically choreographed sequence creates for great, nearly endless fun. (An aside: I recommend erring on the side of simplicity when it comes to selecting your wand ‘style’ at Ollivander’s. There is a deeper wand customisation feature in the game in the form of wand ‘handles.’ Unless I’m a proper git, I wasn’t able to change the ‘style’ after I purchased my wand, and so many of the wand ‘handles’ I collected during my travels looked terrible with the ‘style’ I initially chose. I ultimately created a second character and opted for the Classic ‘style,’ simply so my wand could carry many more ‘handle’ options without looking utterly horrific. You might prefer a hideous wand, though, so… to each their own.)That said, this game is, by no means, perfect, though the bulk of my complaints is nitpicking.For starters, it must be mentioned that there are numerous performance and graphical issues on PC that I encountered, at least at the time of writing: trees or NPCs would vanish and then snap back into place and violently shake about as if throwing some epileptic tantrum, causing my frames to drop into the single digits; the game would crash reliably at certain cutscenes, or randomly and abruptly for no reason; Professor Weasley during my first day at Hogwarts got stuck on a door frame, thrice, and I needed to reload a previous save and pray just to leave Ravenclaw Tower. Turning raytracing off ameliorated many of my issues, though the fidelity degradation from doing so was noticeable. That said, the majority of my time in the game has been smooth and seamless, but when the game suffers an issue, it’s positively unenjoyable. From my very first moments in the game, I came to believe that the character creator is a bit underwhelming. It seemed at first blush to have countless permutations that would allow each of us to create a player character that as closely resembled ourselves as possible, but my characters almost always end up looking the same, regardless which starting model I choose. We aren’t even permitted to tweak or change our body type, always playing someone with a slender build. For a game that touted itself as one that sought to deliver a Hogwarts experience unique to us all, I’d have preferred the chance to really mould my player character myself, with a creator similar to… I don’t know, Dragon Age Inquisition, for example? And while I can understand the logic of not allowing Dumbledore-length beards on fifth-year Hogwarts students, short beard or stubble options would not have been out of the question for teenagers, I don’t think, and would have been a very welcome addition, indeed. My next gripe is with how lifeless so much of the castle feels as it relates to NPCs. So many NPCs are installed simply as window dressing, having neither names nor any meaningful dialogue on tap. They simply stand about and ignore me, even as I barge or bumble through them or their group of peers. I’d have liked if they at least had unique names, similar to other large-world games that name literally every NPC, no matter how irrelevant; or I wish they were actively playing Gobstones, or wizard’s chess, or were dueling—something!  As it stands, many NPCs are missing something that would make them feel livelier and as if they were an actual part of the environment. Next to that, I think so many of the typical RPG elements are a bit light. The vast majority of quests are of the ‘go here and cast this one spell’ variety, which feels both overly pedestrian and woefully underwhelming, and the classes we attend are glorified cutscenes wherein we do one quick tutorialised cast sequence for our spells, and that’s it. Further, it’s abjectly aggravating, indeed, that, during a quest, we aren’t able to venture too far from the discrete quest area, or from whichever NPC we’re supposed to follow—if we do, we get a horrid red splash screen telling us to wander back, and we are confronted with a ‘game over’ if we choose instead to ignore it. Often, during a quest, I would see something off in the distance I wanted to explore or collect, but I was barred from doing so, making the need to traffic back at a later time just for some lacewing flies rather tedious. Even the moth puzzles around Hogwarts and Hogsmeade alike, while mesmerising and charming at first, were a bit thin when you realise you don’t need to pay much mind to what’s in the frame, so long as you’re willing to run around the immediate vicinity with your Lumos-activated wand aloft. Hell, the dialogue options we are asked to choose from during conversations with students or faculty amount to little else than the impression of choice—they offer very little by way of asserting a particular personality for our character, and no one seems to have any pronounced or discernible reaction to the various options we can select. It’s all a bit illusory, and shallow—a missed opportunity, if you ask me. All of this is to say that the calibre of the quests and the NPCs stands in stark contrast to the game world in which those quests and NPCs are set: the quests and NPCs are largely dull and lifeless, while the world is rich, varied, gorgeous, and teeming with seemingly endless possibilities. It’s my earnest belief that the open world, and our ability to traverse virtually unimpeded through all of it (i.e. if you see a door, it’s practically doubtless you can pass through it) is really the selling feature of the game. For some, this might be precisely what they’re after; but for others who might have anticipated a richer, choice-driven, story-focused game, it may land with a thud of disappointment. Oh! And the camera in this game is a shambles. It feels claustrophobic at times with how narrow the field of vision is, even if you opt to max it out. I find myself, even after this many hours, desperately scrolling backwards on my mouse wheel to zoom out, only to be stuck in semi-third, semi-first person perspective.Put simply, the game is fun. It’s gorgeous. It’s staggering how much detail and how much life the developers breathed into this open world. It’s still, in many ways, a dream come true. It just isn’t perfect, though expecting perfection is folly. I highly recommend!

author: 5LoX5
review: Had high hopes but overall badly executed game. My overall score for this game is 6/10.I dont know where to start from so i am gonna just list all the negative stuff i encountered while playing the game.Firstly the main storyline is pretty badly excecuted, especially at the end of the game after the final boss fight there is no interaction with the keepers to conclude the story, the game just ends there.There is also a hasle of a sidequests to unlock some spells, mainly for alohomora felt like the most useless spell, completing the quest to get alohomora lvl 3 felt rly bad, all the rewards i got from opening lvl 3 locks is just a couple gold and maybe a item which feels pretty bad because all that time spent on the quest just to be able to get a couple gold felt pretty demotivating, the only use for aolohomora lvl 3 was to get one of Hogwarts secrets.A lot of things felt like they were there just to give you options, like catching beasts just to be able to put 4 of them in farm when it shows having much more slots, without the option to upgrade all for you to get some materials to upgrade items which felt worthless because they are lvl based meaning you upgrade the item and the next item you get is already better than it, not to mention upgrading stats just unlock the other stat to upgrade. Meaning if you have attack item upgrading it you get defense so it didnt felt usefull to upgrade items, making the pet system worthless.Combat felt nice at first but then you notice thats all there is to it, all the boss fights are pretty much the same in execution. During combat with multiple enemies the warning to parry/dodge isnt showing always you need to listen to audio que and even then you dont know are they targeting you or the ally you are fighting with.A lot of QoL are in need, don't know why they arent done yet, especially for selling items it feels demotivating to explore since you dont have a lot of inventory space and need to go sell items every so often, and selling requires you to hold the button for each item individually and yes i had inventory fully expanded.Exploration, yes it didnt feel good, there are a bunch of caves that i thought at beginning to be dungeons but all they are are you unlock the gate enter pick the item and thats it, in some there is sometimes puzzle but yeah thats it most of times. Good thing is if you revelio while in the air it shows you all the places you can go, except some, but there are very little fun adventures most of them being side quests.The game starts strong but falls down very quickly, had to make myself play in order to finish it. The game feels like gujian 3 but executed much more badly.

author: NikoNikoREE
review: This game is literally so much fun, so much to explore and uncover :)This is the kind of game you can spend hours on and not get bored.

author: Evoattack
review: So for the potential it has, it's actually a terrible game.Yes, the graphics and the size of the world is beyond amazing and professor Garlick seems to be the new #1 cosplay target for e-girls.BUT, the immersion... the true hogwarts experience, nope. Not at all.- The quests are absolutely AFKable. Talk to person x. Bring me object y, defeat group z.- Collectibles/Challenges (100% achievements) are boring as hell. Merlin challenges are too simple, Items are completely random and there is no real value to selling them- Professors give housepoints, but the hourglasses don't do stuff and there is no housecup.- No quidditch regardless of there being a field (probably a future DLC, but the studios already said theyre not in a rush to make DLCs)- The repetitiveness of dialouges are terrible; seems like all roads lead to hogsmead.- The main story is boring up untill the last quest. The Sebastian storyarch is more interesting than the main story.- Combat is WAAAAAAAY too easy.- Room of requirement is useless. Because if you loom your gear to do more damage combat will just get even easier and who really needs potions apart from doing quests to get more spells.- The restricted section is only restricted when you go there for a quest. The forbidden ain't so forbidden at all and roaming the halls at night is also only a problem when you do it for a quest.Get it on a discount, but definitely not on full price.

author: Peacekitty
review: Starting off on the first point, I have say visually Hogwarts Castle was very fun to explore, finding its secrets and getting lost while searching for various collectibles. However once the magic was gone, I could not help but watch my disappointment grow ever more as the game did not pursue a normal school year as I was hoping for. Most of our activities take us outside of Hogwarts and little is spent inside the castle itself except for hunting down its secrets and collectibles, while our house is virtually non-existent. Only 1 student plays a bigger role in your house of choice, while others barely show up at all. We do nothing to help in earning house points, participate in house activities or even see our fellow fifth years in the dormitory room at all. The game has a shallow point in building friendship, but we barely ever do that except for only 3 students of which only consist of Hufflepuff, Gryffindor, and Slytherin. Ravenclaw is sidelined to side quests and a major story quest but does not even have an achievement at all like the 3 students which is poor planning.Hardly do we ever engage with our house or have any gameplay or story points that ties us to our house curriculum and we barely get to know any of our house students from 1st to 7th year. I wish this game had a companion system, which allowed us to build friends and be able to explore the world with said friends, from inside our chosen houses or making friends outside of houses, using their knowledge to gain access to more secrets or learning new spells but none of this ever happens at all.All of the time I am spent alone travelling around the world that feels empty because the magic is mostly visual, not gameplay aspects nor storytelling aspects. The only times that students do play a part, is only in a handful of major story quests and it feels more tacked in than genuinely feeling like I am exploring and tackling on the current threat to the world with friends I have discovered within the school.On that note, the magical experience of being a student in Hogwarts is sorely lacking. It feels too much of an generic open world RPG than an open world Wizarding World RPG because Hogwarts just does not play a bigger role than I expected. Choosing your house, doesn't matter because you don't do anything with your house. This game just steers the wheel conveniently pushing you from one plot point to the next without ever making sure that the whole school year is the focal point of your adventure. I wish there was more in this game that had to actually do with you being in Hogwarts, going through the school year and slowly uncovering the current threat, the fated adventure you have to take without being rushed into a generic Route A then to B style open world RPG that simply has the Wizarding World tacked into it.A final note, would be the Curfew in Hogwarts. There is none. Only 2 quests touch upon Curfew and it is promptly forgotten. There is stealth in the game, but it barely does anything except making it easier to clear an area. The game would have been more exciting if exploration during the night in Hogwarts you had to navigate around prefects, teachers and Peeves to collect the collectibles because night time in Hogwarts frankly was dull and boring with the occasional peeves just doing random things. Tied to the 1st point, this is another big disappointment. The classes are simply there visually but we barely take any classes at all except for the times when we need to learn a new spell. Even then, the classes do nothing but push us to completing a quest where a teacher just teaches us a spell then disappears until they are relevant again, if ever.It is perhaps the biggest flaw of this game, as much of the collectible system, combat mechanics and the exploration aspects should have been tied to the classes you take and sidequests could have been tailored to the Extra-curricular classes you can take. Even major story plot points should have been handled through classes, instead of you running off to the wild blasting things left and right without a care just to push Plot A to Plot B.An example would be the Astronomy class, which only plays a small role in you running around the wild finding Astronomy tables to collect Astronomy signs that don't even have a collection tab for them and only exist for the sake of padding the game. The only other thing it does is to introduce a character that plays a role in a story quest and nothing more. Astronomy and Divination could have been tied to talents, allowing us to unlock talents based on the celestial signs we uncovered, learning more about them through classes and forging our own talents as we travel through the story. Defense against the Dark Arts should have played a MAJOR ROLE as we spend most of our time blasting things left and right. Magical History also should have played a MAJOR ROLE in the main story, helping us discover the past more, learning hidden story points that could have helped us take an alternate route through the story.Even then, I wish Magical History was able to do more, as the Cairn Dungeons we find for gear are just randomly found walking around or zooming around. Instead of this, Magical History should have been tied to this system, in that advancing this class would have allowed us to learn more about the random caves and Catacombs we end up stumbling into as well as research and uncover new hidden areas that were lost in the past. Charms and Transfiguration could have been useful to expand the volume of spells we have to use in solving puzzles in the game as most of the puzzles only revolve around Accio and Flippendo with the occasional good-old blasting objects out of the way.Charms and Transfiguration could have also played a major role in expanding the inventory, instead of us having to complete useless Merlin Trials.Potions play a woeful role, as the teacher should have been more ingrained in the story itself.  We don't even have to study the ingredients for it, we don't even have to study the damn potion itself because we can magically make it instantly without having any nuances to it. Hell they make you go through the steps with Wiggenweld but they don't make you work for the other potions which doesn't have a gratifying feel to it, when you are just looking at a timer ticking down on when it will be finished. With only 4 potions in the game, it feels as though the potion mechanics were an afterthought and not properly implemented to the game. Herbology is the same as Potions, with only 3 plants being combat items. Again, same point with Potions.Flying Class is pretty much a dead class, with the class only useful in being a tutorial on how to use a broom ingame. The rest of the broom mechanics is done through a student in time trials and an quest from a shop to upgrade the speed of your broom. You don't ever get to learn any advanced mechanics or be able to do cool stunts on a broom and instead just acts an alternate method of transportation. Again, like the rest of the classes, there should have been more effort to fine tune this area.Care of Magical Creatures is tied to Room of Requirements, which honestly was handled wrong. We should have progressed through the classes, learning new magical creatures and discovering their habitats through the classes instead of being able to just randomly go out find the beasts to "Save" instead of a house-elf hand holding us.

author: Aartee
review: That is not how 15 year olds act or talk. Everyone is friendly and wholesome, game lacks moody conflict characters (sometimes looking at someone makes you a target in school). Traits of each house are out the window everyone is the same character. Being a man/woman or LGBTQ should not be someone's entire characteristics. I can explore Hogwarts afterdark without getting punished or expelled :( everything is lit which makes lumos less useful (I am sucker for dynamic lights). RTX should be more optimalized, there are huge fps drops in many locations.

author: AFX
review: The word RPG should really be removed when referring to "Hogwarts: Legacy"I don't know if an open world and putting points into your character is already enough nowadays for a game to be called a ROLE-PLAYING-GAME. It's even in the name ffs, but you can only play your wizard/witch like the developers intended.You can't be a dark wizard/witch (no "good/evil"-morality system)Choices (if there even are any, I don't think so), don't matter at all...Standard lifeless open-world (like the Ubisoft-"formula"), filled with worthless copy-paste crap collectibles. The people in the world won't react to anything you do, not even when you break into their houses.I was really into it at first, and I thought after the slow start, there might be some more to it and I was waiting for my first "evil" choice I could make, to form my own "young Voldemort", but it never came.In the end after nearly 30hrs, I'm really disappointed and I'm sure if they would have focused on traditional RPG elements like "choices", "morality-system", "interesting side-quests and dungeons" etc. etc. and would have scrapped all that modern open-world bullsheet, then it could have been really amazing...I'm curious if Hogwarts Legacy 2 will be better, but I doubt it because the reviews are so positive and they made a sheet-load of money. They won't care about these few negative reviews...

author: SteffiSyndrome
review: It's just like magic! This is legit one of the best games I have ever played! That truly brought back the childhood magic of being in awe and amazement when playing games. I don't think I ever stopped smiling - stumbling upon enchanting little detail over enchanting little detail, from honking flowers to beautiful unicorns and SO MUCH GOOD FOOD! The sheer amount of detail in this game is incredible! It adds so much! It's literally a magical experience! A lot of work and love went into this!Great combat, tons of exploring, fantastic beasts, interesting characters, humor, intrigue, suspense, mini-games, this game has it all and more! The graphics look fantastic (I tried ray tracing, but in all fairness, except for a big drop in FPS I saw no great improvement looks-wise, in fact, the surface reflections were rather buggy with its overly-glittery.sparkling effect - it looks plenty wonderful without any of this) the controls were easy to get used to, albeit a bit clunky at times. It had a few glitches but nothing game-breaking. The occasional bad guy and/or loot bag being stuck in a rock and/or underground, immaterial voices (but it IS Hogwarts! Could have been anything ;)) the biggest annoyance was the Polyjuice quest - without any spoilers, it just took me several re-loads to get out of the castle to the objective. Other than that - smooth sailing. I can shamelessly, wholeheartedly give this game a solid 10/10! I enjoyed it from the first second I started, to the very last collectible and quest. I'll most certainly be doing many more playthroughs as for the different houses alone it has, to me, immense replay value!

author: Zydrate
review: I’ve never played a Harry Potter game before this, because they  all seemed to just play through the book and movie plot lines over and  over again. Sometimes as Lego people. I read the books, watched the  movies, and therefore held no interest in the franchises foray into my  favored hobby. Legacy has quite literally the game I’ve been waiting for and that’s a shared sentiment I’ve seen.Story wise, we play a newcomer to Hogwarts but we’re inducted as a fifth year. Extremely rare but not unheard of. Your custom character’s backstory is completely obscured and the story nor dialog reveals a single iota of information about who they are and where they come from. It’s up to us to fill in those blanks.Immediately in the tutorial/prologue (the tutorials continue well into the game itself) it’s revealed that our MC (main character) possesses the rare ability to witness and utilize a form of “ancient magic”. We then discover a strange, previously unknown symbol to the wizarding community and alongside your mentor Professor Fig, that kicks off the main plot. In my first impressions I considered this a bit derivative, as if it’s banking off the movie’s success. The game doesn’t waste a single chance to reference something from the books or movies, like the mooncalves first seen in Strange Beasts or the mandrake replanting class from Chamber of Secrets. Some moments are cute, but during the mandrake replanting I found myself thinking we’d explore literally anything else because per my previous point; I’ve seen that already. Other times are more subtle, like how you can literally stand at the entrance to the Chamber of Secrets with a little lore page detailing a little snake etching but no other in-game indication of what it could mean. I prefer the subtle approach to fanservice like that. As stated, some moments are better than others but this game takes the shotgun approach.One of the things that awed me about the game is how absolutely gorgeous it is, down to the atmosphere. Despite what other reviews state, I find the facial animations to be some of the best I’ve seen. There is the occasional oddity where after every spoken line, an NPC will briefly revert back to their neutral expression which can be jarring depending on how stable your game is. It’s often seamless, but sometimes my computer lags a bit (I’m a bit under the minimum requirements) and I just see their faces cancel itself out.As I always say to anyone who will listen, the first once or twice I did the flying class I could not stop smiling. The teacher spoke to me as if I was on an amusement park ride but I didn’t care, as I got a fairly scenic route through the Hogwarts grounds that we didn’t really get in the movies. Tutorial mission thought it might have been, the music cues were perfect for the mood it was going for.Fans of Harry Potter may very well be in two camps. One wants to capture their childhood nostalgia, the idea that they could be whisked away to a whimsical school to be taught reality breaking spells. The other camp perhaps just want a nice action RPG that just happens to be set in the universe and lore that they love. The first camp will absolutely adore the first 10-15 hours, after which the classes will very much dry up. They’re cute, giving the usual “move the mouse in a certain way” minigames. I do wish they were more complex, or there was more to do but I also completely understand that this game is very much marketed towards teens so they need to keep the pace going and the objectives accessible. Meanwhile, the second camp of fans will very much enjoy themselves. The whole prologue of the game can take a few to several hours before the final mechanic of beast-rearing is introduced, so after that the combat takes center stage....And the combat is actually quite great. There can be a good flow between using the right category of spell to cancel out color coded enemy shields, while making sure to counter or dodge as the right prompt presents itself. Players of Arkham, Mad Max, or Middle-Earth will be familiar with the flow. After a while however, the region level locking became a problem as the late game became far too easy. At one point I was a level 35 (cap is 40) but I kept facing level locked enemies like 20 or 30, almost all of which only took four basic attacks to kill. I had to resort to mods to remedy this issue and increase the difficulty. Hard mode in-game does well in raising the reaction times needed, and it also makes enemy shields come up much quicker, often quicker than your cooldowns which forces more spell switching which I enjoy a lot. However for those who catch onto the flow of it, even Hard difficulty can come across as fairly easy. Another thing I went to mods to help with.I feel like this game brings to the table that HP fans have  wanted. If you wanted the school experience, it’s here in in bite sized  chunks, a class or two at a time for you to navigate the wonderfully  designed school with all kinds of bits and bobs to discover. If you’re  one of those HP fans who thought the combative implications of the world  went under explored, then there’s plenty of it to be had here as well  between shooting at wolves, spiders, bandits, rebels, and other  creatures with fake made-up names.    It is perhaps not as much of an open world as players may have wanted.  There’s plenty to explore to find chests and loot, sometimes blocked by  ways you don’t have access to quite yet. The game doesn’t throw every  tool at you immediately to let you loose upon the world and for good  reason; because there’s not a whole hell of a lot to do town by town.  This is not a “pick a direction and go” kind of world, as early on you  get a tutorial notation saying that some activities are straight up  locked until you get certain spells.  The real meat of the game is in its quests. I will say most of the side quests are rather uninspired and after a couple dozen hours I was only really doing them to unlock appearances and crafts for our Room of Requirement, a place you can decorate and utilize as you see fit. But most of the writing in them were fairly basic. You help one goblin get his cart with art supplies, and that’s really the end of that story. Another you help track down a woman’s missing brother, which just introduces the Inferi (undead) of the lore. Game tells you to hit them with fire, and that’s all there is to that story.In fact, a lot of the game is tutorialized in the first half which can be grating for those of us who catch onto how the game works quickly. This was particularly obvious when you are introduced to the Room of Requirement, where a Weasley ancestor spells out every little thing you can do in the room down to making you place five rugs and five wall hangings before the quest continues, as if doing it once isn’t enough to understand the basics. Again I understand that they do this to keep the game accessible for the lower end of age brackets. While we’re talking about that kind of thing, some of  the activities can feel a bit like busywork. I am particularly irritated  at Merlin trials, which are never complex but always tedious. There are times where I couldn’t even find the solution, despite flying around spamming the Revelio (revealing the area, Eagle Vision Style) and then discovering that if you go to far away from the  trial it resets itself.  They’re also the only way to increase your inventory space  (which fills up quickly because loot is absolutely everywhere). I’m okay  with the various bandit camps and animal lairs but it does reek of that  Ubisoft-ness that has tired gaming in the last few years. 100 hours in and I probably have another 20-30 more to go as I continue exploring the nexus mods page. I do not at all regret buying the game and I’m enjoying it greatly. It really was the game I was waiting for, and I really hope the developers take notice and work on expanding the great foundation they laid out for us.

author: KKB.Not.So.Happy
review: Pros:1. Combat is fun; animations are great. Enemies strengths and weaknesses clearly defined and overall very fast paced. 2. The environment is fantastic. Truly feels like you're living in a magical world. You can spend the first 10 hours just exploring hogwarts. Cons:1. Story felt a shallow, voice acting mediocre and the quests can feel more like chores than fun. A typical good guy vs bad guy storyline. Bit boring imo. Same for relationship quests. Also you don't really feel like you have any sort of connection with anyone; its just a chore you have to do to unlock spells. 2. Your choices don't matter. Whether its your wand selection or dialogue choices. All roads lead to the same place. 3. Gear progression is very plain. The process for farming mats for your gear is forced upon the player and can feel like more of a chore than fun. 4. Very low replayability; game at a certain point becomes extremely easy even on the highest difficulty. Many of the items at your disposal like potions, combat plants, seem more like bloat and completely unnecessary in combat situations. Summary: Great game if you're a completionist/Explorer type. If you play games for a good story with complex dialogue options this probably isnt the one. If you like combat the combat system is good but at a certain point (pretty early in the game) you become so strong that you roll over anything and everything pretty easily even at the highest difficulty.

I have a fairly high-end PC and I'm constantly stuttering, freezing, and I've had the game crash or get hardlocked in a menu because I try to pause at the end of a cutscene more times than I can count. I'm really sick of devs releasing unpolished garbage to the PC market.

author: JMann
review: wizard game good

author: Kaiser Lucilius
review: I might change the review when I have completed the game, but right now I am saying it's a 9/10.The music is great and a good mix of the movies and an original score.Personally judging the game on its own it's what I expect from an AAA-produced game, or at least how it should be. So far it hasn’t pushed a lot beyond graphics but it really nice to look at even on the medium settings. Everything just works as it should and the game is very well optimised. You get to do a lot of customization beyond your character's physical appearance you also get to choose their clothing very in-depth.You can save mostly whenever you want which is something I always appreciate, I feel like few things can ruin the experience of a great like not being able to save when you really need to. You can also link up to Pottermore, to get a few goodies. You can basically pick and choose the house you want to join. Thankfully the houses aren’t as factious as I feel they were in the movies, so you can actually just have a nice start at school and make friends which I really feel hits the mark.The only problem I have encountered is with my controller, but that problem might have to do with steam or the controller itself. And some small lighting issues but I am playing on medium graphics so that might be it.The control scheme is fine it’s what you’ve come to expect, but it works, a very tiny problem I feel is with spells like Accio, the strength of the spell is determined by how hard you press the button but they didn’t address it in the game so I had to look it up.Combat is fun, and there is a fair amount of difficulty settings to choose from.There are also a lot of accessibility settings which is really nice.Story wise I am hooked but unable to say if it gets a satisfying payoff since I am only a few hours in.So overall a 9/10.

author: Wraith
review: This game would have been exceptionally great except for one fact. You are a student at Hogwarts. The fact that you are a student at Hogwarts makes 0 sense to the game. You spend most of the time not even near the castle and hardly ever interact with your fellow students. Most of the RPG systems don't really make much sense as a student. Why is my character attending class dressed in full plate armour? I thought Hogwarts was known for their nice uniforms? Uniforms in a school don't work with an RPG armour system like every other RPG known to man has. How is your "armour" supposed to look progressively cooler when every student is supposed to look the same?Also, why are the teachers encouraging a fifteen year old to explore the country side and burn every poacher, bandit and dark wizard alive? Avada Kedavra, quote from the wiki - "When cast successfully on a living person or creature, the curse caused instantaneous and PAINLESS death, without causing any injury to the body, and without any trace of violence." But no, how dare you cast such an evil spell, here, I know, burn the man alive so he can suffer before he dies, if he dies at all, lets hope he lives so he can suffer for the rest of his life!Why am I so lonely in this game all the time!? Where are all my friends and class mates? These characters are ALL boring which is okay because I can't spend any real time with them apart from a quest here and there. There is nothing special about any of them except for Sirona Ryan who's voice sounds like it was recorded from a speak and spell and is so out of place I had to download a mod to hear the ACTUAL TRANSGENDER ACTRESSES VOICE which sounds perfectly normal and lovely btw. But then if they didn't make her voice sound like a robot, nobody would have known she was transgender! Oh no! Thanks for the out of place BS. It truly did not make the game any better for me and really seemed shoehorned in.I'm on PC why am I switching to more action bars. I have at least 30 buttons on my keyboard that aren't bound to anything I could be binding them too. Combat, while still fun yet easy, would have felt a bit less clunky if they included PC only options such as that, which doesn't seem like it would take that long to implement, but what do I know, people only make these sorts of changes in mods all the time...Finally, there is a TON of misinformation about houses out there. Before I played the game I've heard "‎Gryffindor has the most side quests and Ravenclaw has the least" and "Every playthrough is different depending on which house you choose!" Literally none of that is true. A single quest changes and some of the characters may or may not comment on your house... sometimes... maybe. That's it. 99% of dialogue is the same and besides that one quest, none of the game cares what house you choose. I'm gunna be honest, I didn't really need all that but if every single side quest is just an errend with no real story to it (The other children took my smelly marbles aka gobstones can you go find them for me? Yeah, that's not a story, that's busy work), maybe you could have tried a little harder here. I think I would have been fine if the house really only changed the color of your clothes IF the side quests were really meaty and had actual story repercussions but if all they are is a list of tasks to complete then where the hell is my house content?!?!?They did nail the world though, which for me rings very hallow without all of the stuff that they left luke warm. If you don't care about a games story and if you don't mind that most of the game doesn't make much sense, then this game is for you, but it seems that most people don't mind that stuff. I do.Oh yeah, and my character running around repeating Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio, Revelio everywhere he went sure was immersive. Can you imagine a scene where Harry Potter is running around repeatedly casting Revelio, messing with all the random crap around Hogwarts? "Harry, why aren't you in your bloody class?" "I need to find all the butterflies around Hogwarts and take them to their mirrors so I can collect their pages."If this game didn't have Hogwarts in the title, nobody would be playing it.

author: Samuel.Marshall
review: Disappointed. As a fan of original Harry Potter series I was anticipating for this game and hoping that they will not turn it out to a multiplayer, donate-oriented crap. Well, my hoping came true! But not in the way I expected.First of all, the time period is long time before Harry Potter story. So, no beloved and famous characters and nothing from the modern world (except of LOTS of diversity, lgbt and more agenda).I launched the game and the first thing I saw is NO opportunity to launch game in native fullscreen, only borderlss. So you CAN'T choose a resolution. Wow!Then character making, and the second thing I saw is NO opportunity to create a white character. The whitest skin colour available for customization is still not even close to my colour in real life. Fixed it by mods. Wow x2!Then the game started and the third thing I saw is really poor optimization. My PC is pretty modern, but the game was stuttering and lagging a lot. Fixed it by mods again. Wow x3! Shall I continue?Story is undescribably boring and not interesting. I found myself skipping ALL the dialogues after 10 hours of the game (maybe even earlier). The only side quest line I liked is about Sebastian. It has some drama, and interesting story.The activities are just a joke. Map is HUGE and has only 3 types of activities that are repeating, repeating, repeating and repeating...Neverending dunges with hoblins and spiders, and even in main quests and side quests they are sending you to the same caves and dunges to fight spiders, trolls and hoblins. Again and again. The game about Hogwarts has ZERO Hogwarts activities! There is NO competition between faculties (you know, 10 points to Gryphindore! or 5 points to Slytherine!), there's NO quiddich, NO interesting lessons in Hogwarts (except seveal main quests, where you just attend lesson, skip the cut scene and betting back to clearing dunges from spiders). It has NOTHING for the exception of good-looking entourage that you stop enjoying after 3 hours of playing.Just imagine: the protagonist is the choosen one (why and by who - no one cares and eplains normally), you applying for a 5th year of studying knowing only 3 spells, starting attending lessons with the rest studens EQUALLY, and no one is telling you ANYTHING about it. Everyone is equal in this game, guys. No one from opposite faculty is trying to bully you or make some kind of conflict. NOTHING interesting, NOTHING special, NOTHING unique.Even Avada Kedavra is disappointment. it can't kill everyone. Only some types of regular enemies and trolls.Forget about one-shotting bosses. Forget about fun in this game for the exception of first 5-7 hours. Nothing changes in this world, you are not affecting anything by your actions.And you already perfectly know what exactly is expecting you further in this game.This game is a good example of a modern-type of games that keeping releasing year by year.And a good example, that even if you will take a s**t in a plate but put a note "Harry Potter" - the people happly will start eating it, saying this is a masterpiece 10/10, while feeling of nostalgia is covering their eyes and ears.If you change the entourage for anything else - you will get a typical grinding, boring, idealess game that we already saw 100 times.5/10 only for familiar places that I was glad to attend. And that's a very pity.The developers had ALL the chances: the most famous franchise, budget, support... but the lack of creativity.

author: a
review: VERY POORLY OPTIMIZED. I would've enjoyed this game were it not for the FPS drops. I'm running it on a fairly decent rig with a RTX 3070, DLSS in performance mode and *medium settings*, and I am getting ridiculous FPS drops in crowded locations at Hogwarts (sometimes it goes to sub 20fps). None of the fixes people suggest online have worked. This game is extremely badly optimized for PC - not recommended.

review: I used a spell to make my pee pee bigger. Very lit.

author: IFFATH_ZIYARD

author: Sensei Kreese

author: JimiJimo
review: I've been into Harry Potter for as long as I can remember and while my enthusiasm for it has waned over the years my love for it hasn't. So this isn't exactly gonna be an unbiased review but I absolutely love this game, exploring the world has been a delight and exploring Hogwarts has been something I've wanted to do for so long not to mention finally having a proper RPG in this universe where you create your own character is something I think most of us who grew up with the series always wanted. I find myself getting distracted and just getting lost in the world in all the best of ways, can't say for sure if it'll be the same for someone who isn't as into the series as I was but for anyone with even a passing interest in the game's setting, I'm sure it'll be an enjoyable experience. While I do have a few complaints most of them are nitpicks except for one, the performance is pretty bad with constant dips in performance. Even Cyberpunk wasn't this bad at launch for me in terms of performance but otherwise I fully recommend the game especially when the performance is finally fixed.

author: M'igo Kazan
review: The game is fun at first while you focus on story quests to unlock all the basic features you need, but once you unlock Alohomora and can actually explore the world properly, I find it's big but mostly empty, with the dungeons and puzzles being all the same : linear, generic and mostly unrewarding (thanks to loot scaling with yer level, there's not really any unique loot that has a "wow" factor and gives an incentive for exploring, except maybe as a cosmetic), the quests are pretty much all the same concept but with different inane dialogue, and there's just.. nothing worth exploring really, unless you *really* want to clear out the map and complete those collection logs for the cosmetics, so it's a surprisingly linear experienceHeck, even the story is nothing really worth talking about and just something you have to go through to unlock all the spells and features and the few story dungeons that exist are just sorta there, and as unimaginative as the rest.  There's some cool physics puzzles and the game is charming enough, but I actually think it would have done better as a story game, without the open-world elements; keep Hogwarts, Hogsmeade and the story dungeons, and the game would have been much more impactful

author: Korma
review: No spoilers. Played on Hard. PC & PS5[Cons]-Combat isn't all that fun nor engaging.-PC version is prone to slowdowns (reportedly).-Quests are locked behind tutorials disguised as "prerequisites"-Terrible fast travel UI in the main Hogwarts castle.-Legendary gear is everywhere.-Terribly voiced MC on both available voice options.-"Gem" slotting like Diablo for some reason.-Enemies can lunge whole room lengths in a blink of an eye when attacking.-"Q" and "Space" to beat the whole game.-Crafting & Growing has a time lock on it for some reason.-Build your own "house" for some reason.-Game has features as if it were intended for Online play.[Pros]-Game is very pretty.-Flying is fun.-Taming beasts is fun.-Wandering the castle is fun.-Legendary gear is everywhere.-"has a warm and welcoming community"An unbiased 10/10

author: Drew
review: Ok,im not going to not recommend this game like i did for Forspoken,with performance Because i can see the Love,care and passion that has gone into this project from the very start.Its like Skyrim on Steroids.The combat is great and i havnt even got my Broomstick yet and started flying(going everywhere by foot) but you have generous fast travel points.Amazing Customisation,like things to wear you just randomly find in chests and if you only like the stats and not the look you can just apply the look of the item(basic Transmog).Im really enjoying the game!!Now Devs please please Work on the damn performance........

author: KryIsDying
review: I have finally finished my experience, and I will say I'm a little disappointed. Before I give any criticism, I will give credit to where credit is due. This game is gorgeous, and for the first 20 hours I was mesmerized by the magic and scenery. The gameplay was definitely a learning curve for me, but once I got used to the mechanics on controller, it was very fun and satisfying to duel other students and enemies. I also enjoyed customizing my Room of Requirement to my liking and stumbling across interactions and hidden areas throughout Hogwarts itself. These aspects felt like my personal highlights to the game.SO I'm sure I over-hyped myself for the game before the release and was expecting a sandbox-esque rpg with a lot of lore to discover. Unfortunately, Hogwarts Legacy isn't as much of a rpg as it is more of an action-adventure game. Much of the story I found to be very shallow and a lot of the characters (if not most of the characters) I had a hard time caring about throughout the story. The ending, for me, fell flat and lackluster, feeling very rushed and an afterthought.In conclusion, I don't think this game is bad and there were parts of it I did enjoy. I do think that the devs put focus on graphics and design above the story and lore. With that said, I would give the game a 5.5/10, and I would recommend this game for older kids (14-17) who enjoy the Harry Potter series.

author: Sniforge
review: The game overall is a good game.The story is interesting, But the game mechanics leave much to be desired.A lot of the game is copy paste, hogwarts itself is small in scale compare to what it is supposed to be, there's a minecraft harry potter mod that has a better hogwarts than this. You have to unlock the fun elements of this game, so at the beginning it feels weird... you want to explore but you don't have the proper tools... you can't figure out things on your own.. you actually need to do side missions in order for the solution to unlock, which is a horrible mechanic.The school and the map feel empty, the npc's are very VERY outdated, they don't react to you, they are solid walls you can't even touch them or bump into them, you can shoot any spell at them they won't even react, they will just go on with their animations.  This game would've been amazing in 2008, but in 2023... it's disappointing really. I give this a positive only for the story. The rest of the game.... feels outdated.

author: Badger
review: If you're a Harry Potter fan then this game is an easy recommendation. Even if you're not it's still enjoyable, although there are some areas that could have been improved.Pros:- Interesting(and surprisingly large) open world to explore with lots of things to discover and mysteries to solve.- Nice graphics overall but was particularly impressed with the effects and animations.- They definitely nailed the atmosphere from the books and movies.- Some interesting and memorable characters.- Decent story.Cons:- Itemisation was poor. They could have done more with the gear and maybe added some more interesting items to use.- Bit too much talking. The story was ok but at times I just wanted to play the game instead of watching.- Combat was frustrating at times. Casting spells on wrong enemy due to lock on issues. Also a bit boring towards the end.- Enemy variety was poor. Would like to have seen more variety.

author: apollo.media
review: I would summarise my opinion of Legacy with a fairly simple anecdote:There was this cool looking area that I investigated out in the open world. There was a puzzle to get in, which was interesting and made me think. After getting inside and exploring, I found that the prize for my exploration was a chest...Pretty cool, so I figured something rewarding must be inside.Spectacles. Ugly as sin spectacles that were significantly lower than my current ugly as sin spectacles.This is the common theme of Hogwarts Legacy: Lots of places to explore, and virtually nothing of value or interest will come from doing it.Your clothes all look the same, with varying levels of nerd. You're constantly running to a shop to sell off all the crap you have, because none of it holds any originality or value.At some point i missed some chests in an area that would not allow me to return and at first I was frustrated, because I'd lost an opportunity for loot. Eventually I realised that there is absolutely no value in chests. Occasionally you find an item of a higher level than the one you currently have and switch it out. Since most items are quite ugly, you then have to go into the menu and change the appearance of said item to something less painful to look at.The game just feels so... Pointless.Quests are unfulfilling, because there is nothing to look forward to.Take a game like KOTOR: By trying different quests and working for good outcomes, you have the chance to get interesting new companions, cool sets of gear and better weapons. There is a purpose and reward for your effort and hard work.There is absolutely no reward for your time in this game.Granted, not everyone cares about loot, gear and items.The quests I found to be fairly good overall, but... Again, I don't find myself immersed, or impressed.A great example would be a quest to infiltrate a castle, which sounds pretty neat. I chose to go stealth, as that is my preferred playstyle for which the game offers.While undetected and moving through the castle, I was set upon by a group of goblins that just appeared. They somehow knew exactly where I was, but made no attempt to alert the others.This process repeated for the rest of the quest, making the entire experience very dull.You are given the element of choice, but it is completely superficial, which really just wears on you after a while. If I am given choices, I want them to matter. Otherwise, just make the quests linear and hire better writers.Basically, this game has no direction. It is filled with incredible views and areas to explore, but true world building isnt about pretty landscapes and castles - its about character development.Hogwarts Legacy, to its detriment, focuses on the former, not the latter.I'm not a big fan of a black or white recommend system, so I would say that this: Hogwarts Legacy is a game that has its moments, but is poorly executed and severely lacks imagination.It's too bad. I was very much looking forward to this game and have sunk a decent amount of time into it.But, it'll be a one and done for me, as I'm quite sure there isn't anything worth coming back for a second playthrough.If this game fit the bill for you, all the power to ya. But I expected significantly more.
